General Remarks

Here is the complete documentation for 84000 TEI Documents. In the body there is a list of all the specifications for element, model classes, attribute classes, macros, and datatypes. The back matter contains first a set of guidelines for our own markup editors showing the process for the markup stage of our texts, which is then followed by some other appendices with further topics and instructions for markup editors. All of these sections are accessible through links in the table of contents.

NOTE FOR UPDATING THE SCHEMA: This ODD contains some content models that are written directly with RELAX NG in order to shape and restrict the form for published 84000 texts. If these need to be updated in the ODD, these content models, which outline the whole of the <text> are primarily to be found in the <elementSpec>s for the <teiHeader>, <front>, <body>, and <back> elementsSome RELAX NG content models are also defined in the a few <macroSpec> elements that are pointed to from within the content models of these four mentioned <elementSpec>s. All the the <macroSpec>s have been placed at the beginning of the ODD's XML after the <moduleRef>s and <classSpec>s, these are then followed by the <elementSpec>s. See Appendix I for more details on proceedures for updating the schema.

1. Elements

1.1. <TEI>

<TEI> (TEI document) contains a single TEI-conformant document, combining a single TEI header with one or more members of the model.resource class. Multiple <TEI> elements may be combined within a <TEI> (or <teiCorpus>) element. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module textstructure
Attributes Attributes
version specifies the version number of the TEI Guidelines against which this document is valid.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.version
Note

Major editions of the Guidelines have long been informally referred to by a name made up of the letter P (for Proposal) followed by a digit. The current release is one of the many releases of the fifth major edition of the Guidelines, known as P5. This attribute may be used to associate a TEI document with a specific release of the P5 Guidelines, in the absence of a more precise association provided by the source attribute on the associated <schemaSpec>.
Contained by
—
May contain
header: teiHeader
textstructure: text
Note

This element is required. It is customary to specify the TEI namespace http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0 on it, using the xmlns attribute.
Example The following example is a map for an 84000 TEI document
<TEI xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">  <teiHeader>   <fileDesc>    <titleStmt/>    <editionStmt/>    <publicationStmt/>    <sourceDesc/>    <notesStmt/>   </fileDesc>  </teiHeader>  <text>   <front>    <div type="summary"/>    <div type="acknowledgment"/>    <div type="introduction">     <div type="section"/>     <div type="section"/>     <div type="section"/> <!--... etc.-->    </div>   </front>   <body>    <div type="translation">     <div type="chapter"/>     <div type="chapter"/>     <div type="chapter"/> <!--...-->     <div type="colophon"/>    </div>   </body>   <back>    <div type="notes"/>    <div type="listBibl"/>    <div type="glossary"/>   </back>  </text> </TEI>
Schematron
<sch:ns prefix="tei"  uri="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"/> <sch:ns prefix="xs"  uri="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"/>
Schematron
<sch:ns prefix="rng"  uri="http://relaxng.org/ns/structure/1.0"/>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="teiHeader"/>
 <elementRef key="text"/>
 <macroRef key="cache"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element TEI { attribute version { text }?, teiHeader, text, cache }⚓

1.2. <abbr>

<abbr> (abbreviation) contains an abbreviation of any sort. [3.6.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions]
Module core
Member of
model.pPart.editorial
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: hi
character data
Note

For 84000 documents, this element is only used to identify abbreviations in the list of abbreviations within the "Notes" section in the <back>. In this section it should be followed by a <expan> element showing the expanded form of the abbreviation. This element should not be used as the abbreviations appear in the body of the text.
Example
<back>  <div type="notes">   <head type="notes">Notes</head>   <list type="abbreviations">    <head type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-471">     <abbr>Ch.</abbr>     <expan>Chinese</expan>    </item>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-472">     <abbr>X</abbr>     <expan>Xuanzang’s Ch. translation</expan>    </item>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-473">     <abbr>K</abbr>     <expan>Kumārajīva’s Ch. translation</expan>    </item>   </list>  </div> <!--...--> </back>
Content model 
<content/>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element abbr { ( text | hi )+ }⚓

1.3. <author>

<author> (author) in a bibliographic reference, contains the name(s) of an author, personal or corporate, of a work; for example in the same form as that provided by a recognized bibliographic name authority. [3.12.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id) att.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:lang
Derived from att.global
Status Optional
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan written in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti written in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi written in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese written in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada written in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali written in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit written in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit written in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil written in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai written in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese written in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
cs
Czech
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
la
Latin
ru
Russian
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
ja
Japanese in Japanese script (Use Ja-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic written in Roman script.
mixed
This element contains strings mixed with different languages. They will be differentiated within this element by <foreign> tags, or left unwrapped if they are the default English.
role Describes the author's role in the translation of the text. "translatorMain" and "translatorEng" denote the Tibetan to English translators of the current 84000 text while the "translatorTib" denotes the Tibetan translator of the the Kangyur source.
Derived from att.naming
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
key Used to distinguish two or more authors, when there is an alternative attribution to an historical author.
Derived from att.canonical
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.text
ref (reference) Links the author to a profile in the database
Derived from att.canonical
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Member of
model.respLike
Contained by
core: bibl
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

In the case of the 84000 texts, the author element appears in the title statement, <titleStmt>, to identify the translator of the published text, and in the source description, <sourceDesc>, to identify the translator(s) of the source text. The former deals with those responsible for the English translation and the latter lists those who translated the text into Tibetan.
Example
<titleStmt>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’da’ ka ye shes kyi mdo</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">འདའ་ཀ་ཡེ་ཤེས་ཀྱི་མདོ།</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Sūtra on Wisdom at the Hour of    Death</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Atyaya­jñāna­sūtra</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་འདའ་ཀ་ཡེ་ཤེས་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa ’da’ ka ye shes zhes bya ba theg    pa chen po’i mdo</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “Wisdom at the Hour    of Death”</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Āryātyaya­jñāna­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>  <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>  <author ref="contributors.xml#person-115"   role="translatorMain">Translated by Tom    Tillemans’ class in the University of Vienna’s program of Buddhist Translation    Studies<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words    of the Buddha.</author>  <author ref="contributors.xml#person-116"   role="translatorEng"/> </titleStmt>
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl>   <ref>Toh 176 </ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur vol. 60 (mdo sde, ma), folios 175.a–239.a </biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Chönyi Tsultrim</author>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element author
{
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "Bo-Ltn"
    | "Gu-Ltn"
    | "Hi-Ltn"
    | "Ja-Ltn"
    | "Kn-Ltn"
    | "Mr-Ltn"
    | "Mn-Ltn"
    | "Pi-Ltn"
    | "Pra-Ltn"
    | "Sa-Ltn"
    | "Ta-Ltn"
    | "Th-Ltn"
    | "Zh-Ltn"
    | "bo"
    | "cs"
    | "de"
    | "el"
    | "en"
    | "fr"
    | "it"
    | "la"
    | "ru"
    | "zh"
    | "ja"
    | "middle_indic-Ltn"
    | "mixed"
   }?,
   attribute role { list { + } }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   attribute ref { list { + } }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}⚓

1.4. <availability>

<availability> (availability) supplies information about the availability of a text, for example any restrictions on its use or distribution, its copyright status, any licence applying to it, etc. [2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc.]
Module header
Contained by
—
May contain
header: licence
Note

<availability> element appears as part of the <publicationStmt> which is part of the <teiHeader> in every text.
Example For 84000 texts the <availability> element should always appear as follows:
<availability>  <licence>   <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>   <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND      (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It may be copied      or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and not for commercial      advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see the Creative Commons      license.</p>  </licence> </availability>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="licence"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element availability { licence }⚓

1.5. <back>

<back> (back matter) <back> (back matter) is a default <text> structure, contains any appendixes, etc. following the main part of a text, the <body>. [4.7. Back Matter 4. Default Text Structure]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: text
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic head hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
textstructure: trailer
character data
Note

In the 84000 TEI specification the back structure contains the notes, bibliography and the glossary, in that order.
Example
<back>  <div type="notes">   <head type="notes">Notes</head>   <list type="abbreviations">    <head type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-471">     <abbr>Ch.</abbr>     <expan>Chinese</expan>    </item>    <item xml:id="UT22084-060-005-472">     <abbr>X</abbr>     <expan>Xuanzang’s Ch. translation</expan>    </item> <!--...-->   </list>  </div>  <div type="listBibl">   <head type="listBibl">Bibliography</head>   <div type="section">    <head type="section">Tibetan and Sanskrit sources</head>    <bibl xml:id="UT22084-060-005-474">     <title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa dri ma med par grags pas bstan pa zhes bya          ba theg pa chen po’i mdo </title> (<title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­vimala­kīrti­nirdeśa­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>). Toh. 176, Degé        Kangyur, vol. 60 (mdo sde, ma), folios 175b–239a. </bibl>    <bibl xml:id="UT22084-060-005-476"> Study Group on Buddhist Sanskrit Literature.        梵文維摩經 : ポタラ宮所蔵写本に基づく校訂. <title xml:lang="en">Vimalakīrtinirdeśa, A Sanskrit          Edition Based upon the Manuscript Newly Found at the Potala Palace</title>.        Tokyo: Institute for Comprehensive Studies of Buddhism, Taishō Daigaku        Shuppankai, 2006. </bibl> <!--...-->   </div> <!--...-->  </div>  <div type="glossary">   <list type="glossary">    <item>     <gloss type="term"      xml:id="UT22084-060-005-498">      <term>Abhidharma</term>      <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">chos mngon pa </term>      <term xml:lang="bo">ཆོས་མངོན་པ།</term>      <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Abhidharma</term>      <term type="definition">Conventionally, the general name for the Buddhist            teachings presented in a scientific manner, as a fully elaborated            transcendental psychology. </term>     </gloss>    </item> <!--...-->   </list>  </div> </back>
Content model 
<content>notesnotesabbreviationssectionsectionabbreviationslistBibllistBiblsectionsectionsectionsectionglossaryglossarytermpersonplacetextmarkedmatchenBo-LtnboSa-LtnPi-LtnzhZh-LtndefinitionalternativesemanticReconstructiontransliterationReconstructionappendixappendixtitleMainprologuehomageprologuehomage</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element back
{
   (
      element div
      {
         attribute type { "notes" },
         element head { attribute type { "notes" }, head-content },
         (
            (
               element list
               {
                  attribute type { "abbreviations" },
                  head+,
                  element item
                  {
                     attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id
                     {
                        xsd:ID
                     },
                     text,
                     abbr?,
                     expan?
                  }+
               }
             | milestone
            )*
          | element div
            {
               attribute type { "section" },
               attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
               (
                  element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }
                | element list
                  {
                     attribute type { "abbreviations" },
                     head*,
                     element item
                     {
                        attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id
                        {
                           xsd:ID
                        },
                        text,
                        abbr?,
                        expan?
                     }+
                  }
                | milestone
               )*
            }*
         )
      }
    | element div
      {
         attribute type { "listBibl" },
         element head { attribute type { "listBibl" }, head-content },
         element div
         {
            attribute type { "section" },
            attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
            (
               bibl-section-content
             | element div
               {
                  attribute type { "section" },
                  attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
                  (
                     bibl-section-content
                   | element div
                     {
                        attribute type { "section" },
                        attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id
                        {
                           xsd:ID
                        },
                        (
                           bibl-section-content
                         | element div
                           {
                              attribute type { "section" },
                              attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id
                              {
                                 xsd:ID
                              },
                              bibl-section-content
                           }
                        )+
                     }
                  )+
               }
            )+
         }*
      }
    | element div
      {
         attribute type { "glossary" },
         element list
         {
            attribute type { "glossary" },
            element item
            {
               element gloss
               {
                  attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
                  attribute type { "term" | "person" | "place" | "text" },
                  attribute mode { "marked" | "match" }?,
                  element term
                  {
                     (
                        text
                      | term*
                      | foreign*
                      | title*
                      | emph*
                      | distinct*
                      | ptr*
                      | ref-other*
                      | hi*
                      | mantra*
                     )+,
                     attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]lang
                     {
                        "en"
                      | "Bo-Ltn"
                      | "bo"
                      | "Sa-Ltn"
                      | "Pi-Ltn"
                      | "zh"
                      | "Zh-Ltn"
                     }?,
                     attribute type
                     {
                        "definition"
                      | "alternative"
                      | "semanticReconstruction"
                      | "transliterationReconstruction"
                     }?
                  }+
               }?
            }+
         }?
      }
    | element div
      {
         attribute type { "appendix" },
         attribute rend { text }?,
         attribute prefix { text }?,
         element head { attribute type { "appendix" }, head-content },
         element head { attribute type { "titleMain" }, head-content }?,
         element div
         {
            attribute type { "prologue" | "homage" },
            attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
            element head
            {
               attribute type { "prologue" | "homage" },
               head-content
            },
            ( section-content | translation-section* )+
         }*,
         translation-section*,
         translation-chapter*
      }?
   )+
}⚓

1.6. <bibl>

<bibl> (bibliographic citation) contains a loosely-structured bibliographic citation of which the sub-components may or may not be explicitly tagged. [3.12.1. Methods of Encoding Bibliographic References and Lists of References 2.2.7. The Source Description 15.3.2. Declarable Elements]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id)
type characterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
key
Status Optional
Member of
model.biblLike model.biblPart
Contained by
core: bibl desc item l note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr author bibl biblScope date distinct editor emph expan foreign gloss hi lb milestone name note ptr publisher q ref term title
header: edition idno
character data
Note

For 84000 texts, the <bibl> element is used for each bibliographic entry in the bibliography within the <back> section of the text. However, in each 84000 text the <bibl> element is also used once in the <sourceDesc> to describe the bibliographic information for the 84000 text itelf; in this case the <bibl> is more elaborate and contains several child elements, see the second example below:
Example
<bibl xml:id="UT22084-060-005-486">Bagchi, S. (ed.). <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn"> Guhya­samāja­tantra</title>. Buddhist Sanskrit Texts, No. 9. Darbhanga: Mithila Institute of Postgraduate Studies and Research in Sanskrit Learning, 1965. </bibl>
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh83" type="text">   <ref>Toh 83</ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios 71.a–94.b</biblScope> <!--series>Degé Kangyur</series>, <biblScope>vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha)</biblScope>, <citedRange>folios 71a–94a</citedRange-->   <author role="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author>   <author role="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author>   <author role="translatorTib">Yeshé Dé</author>   <location count-pages="48"    work="UT4CZ5369">    <volume end-page="188" number="44"     start-page="141"/>   </location>   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/>   <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC11626"    work="W22084"/>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <textNode/>
  <classRef key="model.gLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.highlighted"/>
  <classRef key="model.pPart.data"/>
  <classRef key="model.pPart.edit"/>
  <classRef key="model.segLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.ptrLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.biblPart"/>
  <classRef key="model.global"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element bibl
{
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   attribute type { text }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   (
      text
    | model.gLike
    | model.highlighted
    | model.pPart.data
    | model.pPart.edit
    | model.segLike
    | model.ptrLike
    | model.biblPart
    | model.global
   )*
}⚓

1.7. <biblScope>

<biblScope> (scope of bibliographic reference) defines the scope of a bibliographic reference, for example as a list of page numbers, or a named subdivision of a larger work. [3.12.2.5. Scopes and Ranges in Bibliographic Citations]
Module core
Member of
model.imprintPart
Contained by
core: bibl
header: sourceDesc
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

For 84000 texts this is typically just used in the <bibl> element in the initial source description, <sourceDesc>. However, it is also possible to mark up the <bibl> entries in the back matter with the <biblScope> if deemed appropriate or necessary in the future.
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl>   <ref>Toh 176 </ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur vol. 60 (mdo sde, ma), folios 175.a–239.a </biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Chönyi Tsultrim</author>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element biblScope { macro.phraseSeq }⚓

1.8. <body>

<body> (text body) contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter. [4. Default Text Structure]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: text
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic head hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
textstructure: trailer
character data
Note

<body> (text body) contains the whole body of a single unitary text, excluding any front or back matter. So in an 84000 TEI encoded document, the body contains the whole translated text. It does not material written by the translator or editors, but just the original text in translation. It is part of the <text>, coming after <front> and before <back>. The body section opens approximately the same way in every document. The front closing tag precedes the body opening tag. That is followed by the div tag with the type attribute containing the "translation" value. This is followed by the head elements, with type values first of "translation" and then "titleMain", and then "titleHon" as shown below. After this comes the chapter or section div's, and so on. Even if there is no chapter division in the body of the translated text, there is minimally one section or chapter div, containing then the whole of the translation, and closing before the "colophon". Structurally the colophon section is equivalent to a chapter, and colophon is a value of a type attribute of a div element. The colophon div closes and then comes the closing div tag of the translation, and then the closing body tag.
Example
<body>  <div type="translation">   <head type="translation">The Translation</head>   <head type="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra</head>   <head type="titleMain">The Inquiry of Jayamati</head>   <div type="section">    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-061-014-13"/>    <p tid="15">     <ref cRef="F.250.b" type="folio"/> Homage to all buddhas and bodhisatvas! </p>    <lb/>    <p tid="16">Thus I have heard at one time. The Bhagavān was residing at the        grove of Anāthapiṇḍada in Jeta Wood in Śrāvastī together with a great assembly        of monks and a great multitude of bodhisatvas. Then, the Bhagavān addressed        the bodhisatva Jayamati as follows. </p>    <lb/> <!--...-->   </div>   <div type="colophon">    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-061-014-16"/>    <p tid="19">This text was translated, edited, and finalized by the Indian scholars Jinamitra and Surendrabodhi, together with the chief editor and translator Yeshé Dé.</p>   </div>  </div> </body>
Content model 
<content>articleprefacearticleprefacetranslationtranslationtitleHontitleMainsubprologuehomageprologuehomagecolophoncolophon</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element body
{
   (
      element div
      {
         attribute type { "article" | "preface" },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "article" | "preface" },
            head-content
         },
         section-content,
         translation-section*
      }
    | element div
      {
         attribute type { "translation" },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "translation" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            attribute key { text }?,
            text
         },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "titleHon" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            attribute key { text }?,
            text
         }?,
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "titleMain" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            attribute key { text }?,
            text
         },
         element head
         {
            attribute type { "sub" },
            attribute tid { text }?,
            attribute key { text }?,
            text
         }?,
         element div
         {
            attribute type { "prologue" | "homage" },
            attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
            element head
            {
               attribute type { "prologue" | "homage" },
               head-content
            },
            section-content,
            translation-section*
         }*,
         ( translation-section | translation-chapter )*,
         element div
         {
            attribute type { "colophon" },
            attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
            element head { attribute type { "colophon" }, head-content },
            section-content,
            translation-section*
         }*
      }
   )?
}⚓

<canonDef>
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id)
type
Status Optional
Sample values include:
ref
Status Required
Member of
macro.paraContent macro.specialPara paragraph
Contained by
core: item note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno

 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
    ⚓

element canonDef
{
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   attribute type { text }?,

   macro.paraContent
}⚓

1.10. <catDesc>

<catDesc> (category description) describes some category within a taxonomy or text typology, either in the form of a brief prose description or in terms of the situational parameters used by the TEI formal <textDesc>. [2.3.7. The Classification Declaration]
Module header
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend)) att.canonical (@key, @ref)
Contained by
—
May contain Character data only
Example
<catDesc>Prose reportage</catDesc>
Example
<catDesc>  <textDesc n="novel">   <channel mode="w">print; part issues</channel>   <constitution type="single"/>   <derivation type="original"/>   <domain type="art"/>   <factuality type="fiction"/>   <interaction type="none"/>   <preparedness type="prepared"/>   <purpose degree="high" type="entertain"/>   <purpose degree="medium" type="inform"/>  </textDesc> </catDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element catDesc { att.global.attributes, att.canonical.attributes, text }⚓

1.11. <catRef>

<catRef> (category reference) specifies one or more defined categories within some taxonomy or text typology. [2.4.3. The Text Classification]
Module header
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend)) att.pointing (@target)
scheme identifies the classification scheme within which the set of categories concerned is defined, for example by a <taxonomy> element, or by some other resource.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.pointer
Contained by
header: textClass
May contain
header: category
Note

The scheme attribute needs to be supplied only if more than one taxonomy has been declared.
Example
<catRef scheme="#myTopics"  target="#news #prov #sales2"/> <!-- elsewhere --> <taxonomy xml:id="myTopics">  <category xml:id="news">   <catDesc>Newspapers</catDesc>  </category>  <category xml:id="prov">   <catDesc>Provincial</catDesc>  </category>  <category xml:id="sales2">   <catDesc>Low to average annual sales</catDesc>  </category> </taxonomy>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="category"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element catRef
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.pointing.attributes,
   attribute scheme { text }?,
   category*
}⚓

1.12. <category>

<category> (category) contains an individual descriptive category, possibly nested within a superordinate category, within a user-defined taxonomy. [2.3.7. The Classification Declaration]
Module header
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
name
Status Required
Legal values are:
source-language
catalogued-in
western-translation
translation-period
RR-filter
text-type-84000
text-type-12-branch
homage-type
audience-type
setting
id
Status Optional
Contained by
header: catRef taxonomy
May contain Character data only
Example
<category xml:id="b1">  <catDesc>Prose reportage</catDesc> </category>
Example
<category xml:id="b2">  <catDesc>Prose </catDesc>  <category xml:id="b11">   <catDesc>journalism</catDesc>  </category>  <category xml:id="b12">   <catDesc>fiction</catDesc>  </category> </category>
Example
<category xml:id="LIT">  <catDesc xml:lang="pl">literatura piękna</catDesc>  <catDesc xml:lang="en">fiction</catDesc>  <category xml:id="LPROSE">   <catDesc xml:lang="pl">proza</catDesc>   <catDesc xml:lang="en">prose</catDesc>  </category>  <category xml:id="LPOETRY">   <catDesc xml:lang="pl">poezja</catDesc>   <catDesc xml:lang="en">poetry</catDesc>  </category>  <category xml:id="LDRAMA">   <catDesc xml:lang="pl">dramat</catDesc>   <catDesc xml:lang="en">drama</catDesc>  </category> </category>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element category
{
   att.global.attributes,
   attribute name
   {
      "source-language"
    | "catalogued-in"
    | "western-translation"
    | "translation-period"
    | "RR-filter"
    | "text-type-84000"
    | "text-type-12-branch"
    | "homage-type"
    | "audience-type"
    | "setting"
   },
   attribute id { text }?,
   text
}⚓

1.13. <cell>

<cell> (cell) contains one cell of a table. [14.1.1. TEI Tables]
Module figures
Attributes Attributes
role (role) indicates the kind of information held in this cell or in each cell of this row.
Derived from att.tableDecoration
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
label
labelling or descriptive information only.
data
data values. [Default]
Contained by
figures: row
May contain
core: abbr bibl distinct emph foreign hi lb note ptr ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: mantra
character data
Note

Represents the data of a specific cell within a <row> within a <table>. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent <cell>s are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a <row> contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child <cell>s will be considered to be "label"s as well.

For further details on tables see Topics: Appendix B.5 Tables.
Example
<!--<table>--> <!--<row>--> <cell>Vajrasattva</cell> <!--etc... more cells--> <!--</row>--> <!--etc... more rows--> <!--</table>-->
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <textNode/>
  <elementRef key="abbr"/>
  <elementRef key="bibl"/>
  <elementRef key="distinct"/>
  <elementRef key="emph"/>
  <elementRef key="foreign"/>
  <elementRef key="hi"/>
  <elementRef key="lb"/>
  <elementRef key="mantra"/>
  <elementRef key="note"/>
  <elementRef key="ptr"/>
  <elementRef key="ref"/>
  <elementRef key="term"/>
  <elementRef key="title"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element cell
{
   attribute role { "label" | "data" }?,
   (
      text
    | abbr
    | bibl
    | distinct
    | emph
    | foreign
    | hi
    | lb
    | mantra
    | note
    | ptr
    | ref
    | term
    | title
   )*
}⚓

1.14. <classDecl>

<classDecl> (classification declarations) contains one or more taxonomies defining any classificatory codes used elsewhere in the text. [2.3.7. The Classification Declaration 2.3. The Encoding Description]
Module header
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
Member of
model.encodingDescPart
Contained by
header: encodingDesc
May contain
header: taxonomy
Example
<classDecl>  <taxonomy xml:id="LCSH">   <bibl>Library of Congress Subject Headings</bibl>  </taxonomy> </classDecl> <!-- ... --> <textClass>  <keywords scheme="#LCSH">   <term>Political science</term>   <term>United States -- Politics and government —      Revolution, 1775-1783</term>  </keywords> </textClass>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="taxonomy"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element classDecl { att.global.attributes, taxonomy+ }⚓

1.15. <consultant>

<consultant>
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributes
role
Status Required
Legal values are:
advisor
Covers a number of roles, including a lama overseeing a project, a Chinese or Sanskrit language consultant, those who have shared previous draft translations, an academic specialist assisting in research, and so forth.
projectManager
dharmaMaster
ref Links the consultant to a profile in the database
Status Optional
Contained by
header: titleStmt
May contain Character data only
Note

States a consultant and their role in an 84000 publication. In 84000 TEI documents, this should be stated at the beginning in the <titleStmt> after the editor but before the sponsor:
Example
<titleStmt>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">bsod nams thams cad bsdus pa’i ting nge    ’dzin</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">བསོད་ནམས་ཐམས་ཅད་བསྡུས་པའི་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན།</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Absorption That Encapsulates All    Merit</title> <!--...various titles...-->  <author ref="translators.xml#team-9"   role="translatorMain">Translated by the    Dharmachakra Translation Committee<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of    84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-46"   role="translatorEng">Khenpo Trokpa    Tulku</author>  <editor role="projectEditor">Andreas Doctor</editor>  <consultant role="advisor">Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche</consultant>  <sponsor ref="sponsors.xml#sponsor-999">anonymous</sponsor> </titleStmt>
Content model 
<content>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element consultant
{
   attribute role { "advisor" | "projectManager" | "dharmaMaster" },
   attribute ref { text }?,
   text?
}⚓

1.16. <date>

<date> (date) contains a date in any format. [3.6.4. Dates and Times 2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc. 2.6. The Revision Description 3.12.2.4. Imprint, Size of a Document, and Reprint Information 15.2.3. The Setting Description 13.4. Dates]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.canonical (@key, @ref)
Member of
model.dateLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Character data only
Note

For 84000 texts the <date> element is simply used to indicate the date of the translation. In each document it should be only used in the <editionStmt> (wrapped within the <edition> element showing just the year) and the <publicationStmt>, where is should be in the format "YYYY-MM-DD" As in the example the example below.
Example
<editionStmt>  <edition>v 1.0 <date>2018</date>  </edition> </editionStmt>
Example
<publicationStmt>  <publisher>   <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit    initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern languages,    and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>  <availability>   <licence>    <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>    <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND        (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It may be        copied or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and not for        commercial advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see the        Creative Commons license.</p>   </licence>  </availability>  <idno xml:id="UT22084-055-001"/>  <date>2016-05-30</date> </publicationStmt>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element date { att.canonical.attributes, text }⚓

1.17. <desc>

<desc> (description) contains a brief description of the object documented by its parent element, typically a documentation element or an entity. [22.4.1. Description of Components]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
type characterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
deprecationInfo
(deprecation information) This element describes why or how its parent element is being deprecated, typically including recommendations for alternate encoding.
<dataSpec ident="teidata.point"  module="tei"  validUntil="2050-02-25">  <desc type="deprecationInfo"   versionDate="2018-09-14"   xml:lang="en">Several standards bodies, including NIST in the USA,    strongly recommend against ending the representation of a number    with a decimal point. So instead of <q>3.</q> use either <q>3</q>    or <q>3.0</q>.</desc> <!-- ... --> </dataSpec>
Member of
model.descLike model.labelLike
Contained by
core: desc item l media note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss hi label list name ptr q ref term title
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

When used in a specification element such as <elementSpec>, TEI convention requires that this be expressed as a finite clause, begining with an active verb.
Example
<desc>contains a brief description of the purpose and intended use of a documentation element, or a brief characterisation of a parent entity </desc>
Schematron A <desc> with a type of deprecationInfo should only occur when its parent element is being deprecated. Furthermore, it should always occur in an element that is being deprecated when <desc> is a valid child of that element.
<sch:rule context="tei:desc[ @type eq 'deprecationInfo']"> <sch:assert test="../@validUntil">Information about a deprecation should only be present in a specification element that is being deprecated: that is, only an element that has a @validUntil attribute should have a child <desc type="deprecationInfo">.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.limitedContent"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element desc
{
   att.global.attributes,
   attribute type { "deprecationInfo" }?,
   macro.limitedContent
}⚓

1.18. <distinct>

<distinct> identifies any word or phrase which is regarded as linguistically distinct, for example as archaic, technical, dialectal, non-preferred, etc., or as forming part of a sublanguage. [3.3.2.3. Other Linguistically Distinct Material]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type specifies the sublanguage or register to which the word or phrase is being assigned
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Member of
model.emphLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

For 84000 texts, our parser italicizes text within this element. In the mark-up process, text that should be italicized but does not fall into the category of foreign text (tagged with the <foreign> element) should be marked up either with the <distinct> or <emph> element. <distinct> indicates that the italics identify any word or phrase that is not foreign, but is regarded as linguistically distinct, for example as archaic, technical, dialectal, non-preferred, etc., or as forming part of a sublanguage. <emph> indicates that the italicized words are not in a foreign language but are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect.
Example
<p tid="115"> “It is as follows: Mañjuśrī, in the great ocean there is a great, precious jewel called <distinct>Fulfilling All Wishes</distinct>. <!--...--> </p>
Example
<p> <!--...--> According to the CMT, this awakening is irreversible and is therefore termed <distinct>indestructible awakening</distinct> (<foreign type="term" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">vajrabodhi</foreign>). <!--...--> </p>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element distinct { attribute type { text }?, macro.phraseSeq }⚓

1.19. <div>

<div> (text division) contains a subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text. [4.1. Divisions of the Body]
Module textstructure
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:id, @xml:lang)
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived from att.global
Status Optional
Datatype ID
rend (rendition) indicates how the element in question was rendered or presented in the source text.
Derived from att.global.rendition
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.word separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
ignoreGlossary
Glossary terms found in the text in this division will not be linked to the glossary in the 84000 Reading Room.
type These are the divs for 84000 translations - used in the front, body or back.
Derived from att.typed
Status Required
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
chapter
summary
introduction
acknowledgment
listBibl
section
translation
chapter
section
colophon
notes
glossary
prologue
preface
homage
prefix Prefix to be displayed for division in Reading Room--overrides index that is automatically generated by the script.
Status Optional
Member of
model.divLike
Contained by
textstructure: div
May contain
core: bibl desc head l label lb lg list milestone note p q
figures: table
textstructure: div trailer
Note

<div> (text division) contains a subdivision of the front, body, or back of a text. All three subsections of the Front are designated by a div tag, which includes a type attribute that holds a value reflecting which subsection it is, for example: <div type="acknowledgment">. Likewise the body has a div tag marking the translation, and within the translation, at least two div's, making the main part of the translation and the colophon. Any further subdivisions of the translation, into chapters or sections require additional div tags. All of the tags also contain the type attribute and translation, chapter, section or colophon values. This works the same way for the back section, with four div tags, at least. Each again has the type attribute and values of notes, listBibl (within listBible at least one div with type section) and glossary.

Note that a prologue or colophon section should be marked as such, e.g., type="prologue" and not be labeled as "section".

The following is the <div> structure of 22084-089-001, Toh 544. It shows only and all of the div tags in the "text", since there are no div tags in the teiHeader. <text>

Example
<text>  <front>   <div type="summary"/>   <div type="acknowledgment"/>   <div type="introduction">    <div type="section"/>    <div type="section"/>    <div type="section"/>   </div>  </front>  <body>   <div type="translation">    <div type="chapter"/>    <div type="chapter"/>    <div type="chapter"/>    <div type="chapter"/>    <div type="colophon"/>   </div>  </body>  <back>   <div type="notes"/>   <div type="listBibl">    <div type="section"/>   </div>   <div type="glossary"/>  </back> </text>
Example Occasionally, for whatever reason the chapter numbers may need to be altered. For example in Toh 543, many chapters are skipped since a Sanskrit source was matched to the chapters in the Kangyur. The number needs to be displayed as such in the header but also needs to have the proper number prefixed in the table of contents and all the milestones contained within the chapter, all of which will be diverging from the number that is automatically generated by the parser. This can be done by adding a single @prefix attribute to the appropriate chapter's <div> element. e.g.:
<div prefix="24" type="chapter"> <!--...--> </div>
So this chapter and all its milestones will now display the "24" prefix in the reading room even though it isn't the 24th "chapter" division in the TEI file.
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:l"> Abstract model violation: Lines may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div. </s:report>
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:p or ancestor::tei:ab and not(ancestor::tei:floatingText)"> Abstract model violation: p and ab may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div. </s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
  <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
   minOccurs="0">
   <classRef key="model.divTop"/>
   <classRef key="model.global"/>
  </alternate>
  <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="0">
   <alternate maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
    <sequence maxOccurs="unbounded"
     minOccurs="1">
     <alternate maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
      <classRef key="model.divLike"/>
      <classRef key="model.divGenLike"/>
     </alternate>
     <classRef key="model.global"
      maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
    </sequence>
    <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
     <sequence maxOccurs="unbounded"
      minOccurs="1">
      <classRef key="model.common"/>
      <classRef key="model.global"
       maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
     </sequence>
     <sequence maxOccurs="unbounded"
      minOccurs="0">
      <alternate maxOccurs="1"
       minOccurs="1">
       <classRef key="model.divLike"/>
       <classRef key="model.divGenLike"/>
      </alternate>
      <classRef key="model.global"
       maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
     </sequence>
    </sequence>
   </alternate>
   <sequence maxOccurs="unbounded"
    minOccurs="0">
    <classRef key="model.divBottom"/>
    <classRef key="model.global"
     maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
   </sequence>
  </sequence>
 </sequence>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element div
{
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   attribute xml:id { text }?,
   attribute rend { list { "ignoreGlossary"+ } }?,
   attribute type
   {
      "chapter"
    | "summary"
    | "introduction"
    | "acknowledgment"
    | "listBibl"
    | "section"
    | "translation"
    | "chapter"
    | "section"
    | "colophon"
    | "notes"
    | "glossary"
    | "prologue"
    | "preface"
    | "homage"
   },
   attribute prefix { text }?,
   (
      ( model.divTop | model.global )*,
      (
         (
            ( ( model.divLike | model.divGenLike ), model.global* )+
          | (
               ( model.common, model.global* )+,
               ( ( model.divLike | model.divGenLike ), model.global* )*
            )
         ),
         ( model.divBottom, model.global* )*
      )?
   )
}⚓

1.20. <edition>

<edition> (edition) describes the particularities of one edition of a text. [2.2.2. The Edition Statement]
Module header
Member of
model.biblPart
Contained by
core: bibl
header: editionStmt
May contain Character data only
Note

Because of the particularities of electronic publishing, P5 Guidelines says that "the term edition may be used for a particular state of a machine-readable text at which substantive changes are made and fixed. The words revision and update, by contrast, are used for minor changes to a file which do not amount to a new edition. No simple rule can specify how ‘substantive’ changes have to be before they are regarded as producing a new edition, rather than a simple update. The general principle proposed here is that the production of a new edition entails a significant change in the intellectual content of the file, rather than its encoding or appearance. " For 84000 texts, the element should include a version number or name and can include the <date> element.
Example
<edition>v 1.0 <date>2016</date> </edition>
Content model 
<content/>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element edition { text, element date { xsd:gYear } }⚓

1.21. <editionStmt>

<editionStmt> (edition statement) groups information relating to one edition of a text. [2.2.2. The Edition Statement 2.2. The File Description]
Module header
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain
header: edition
Note

According to the TEI P5 Guidelines, <editionStmt> (edition statement) is the second component of the fileDesc element and groups information relating to one edition of a text. It is an optional element, but recommended. It follows directly after the </titleStmt>, and proceeds the <publicationStmt>. There are 5 potential child elements that it can contain, but for 84000 texts, the only child element is the <edition> tag, and that element contains in turn the <date> element, the grandchild of the <editionStmt> element.
Example
<editionStmt>  <edition>v 1.0 <date>2016</date>  </edition> </editionStmt>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="edition"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element editionStmt { edition }⚓

1.22. <editor>

<editor> contains a secondary statement of responsibility for a bibliographic item, for example the name of an individual, institution or organization, (or of several such) acting as editor, compiler, translator, etc. [3.12.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend)) att.canonical (ref, @key)
role may be used to specify further information about the entity referenced by this name in the form of a set of whitespace-separated values, for example the occupation of a person, or the status of a place.
Derived from att.naming
Status Required
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
reviser
An editor on the translation team. This includes copyeditors and proofreaders on the translation team that are not 84000 copyeditors/proofreaders (the latter should be markup role="copyEditor" and role="proofreader" respectively).
reviser
Translation editor.
proofreader
A proofreader on the translation team. (Internal proofreaders should be assigned "copyEditor")
associateEditor
Refers to internal editors on the 84000 team assigned to go through a project and deal with follow up.
projectEditor
Refers to internal editors on the 84000 team assigned to go through a project and deal with follow up.
externalReviewer
84000-appointed external reviewer.
copyEditor
84000-appointed copyeditor.
finalReviewer
Does the final review of the translation and TEI before publication. Since 2018, this will have been John, James, or both. For pre-2018 texts it will be Tom Tillemans and/or John.
TEImarkupEditor
84000-appointed markup editor.
ref (reference) Links the editor to a profile in the database
Derived from att.canonical
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
revision
Status Optional
Member of
model.respLike
Contained by
core: bibl
header: titleStmt
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

States an editor and their role in an 84000 publication. In 84000 TEI documents, this should be stated at the beginning in the <titleStmt>, after and <author>s but before any <consultant>s or <sponsor>s.
Example
<titleStmt>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">bsod nams thams cad bsdus pa’i ting nge    ’dzin</title> <!--...list of other titles...-->  <author ref="translators.xml#team-9"   role="translatorMain">Translated by the    Dharmachakra Translation Committee<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of    84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-46"   role="translatorEng">Khenpo Trokpa    Tulku</author>  <editor role="projectEditor">Andreas Doctor</editor>  <consultant role="advisor">Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche</consultant>  <sponsor ref="sponsors.xml#sponsor-999">Anonymous</sponsor> </titleStmt>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element editor
{
   att.global.attributes,
   att.canonical.attribute.key,
   attribute role
   {
      list
      {
         (
            "reviser"
          | "reviser"
          | "proofreader"
          | "associateEditor"
          | "projectEditor"
          | "externalReviewer"
          | "copyEditor"
          | "finalReviewer"
          | "TEImarkupEditor"
         )+
      }
   },
   attribute ref { list { + } }?,
   attribute revision { text }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}⚓

1.23. <emph>

<emph> (emphasized) marks words or phrases which are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect. [3.3.2.2. Emphatic Words and Phrases 3.3.2. Emphasis, Foreign Words, and Unusual Language]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
rend
Status Optional
Sample values include
bold
Member of
model.emphLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: term
character data
Note

For 84000 texts, our parser italicizes text within this element. In the mark-up process, text that should be italicized but does not fall into the category of foreign text (tagged with the <foreign> element) should be marked up either with the <distinct> or <emph> element. <distinct> indicates that the italics identify any word or phrase that is not foreign, but is regarded as linguistically distinct, for example as archaic, technical, dialectal, non-preferred, etc., or as forming part of a sublanguage. <emph> indicates that the italicized words are not in a foreign language but are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect.

<emph> is also used for the word "Warning" in the tantric restriction within the <availability> element, and here it should be given the rend with the value "bold" inorder to render it bold as such.
Example
<note> <!--...--> It should be remembered here that “destructible” = the relative, and “indestructible” = the absolute. Thus, Pratyakṣa­darśa is affirming that the superficial <emph>is</emph> the ultimate, etc. <!--...--> </note>
Example
<availability>  <p type="tantricRestriction">   <emph rend="bold">Warning:</emph> Readers are reminded that according to Vajrayāna    Buddhist tradition there are restrictions and commitments concerning tantra.    Practitioners who are not sure if they should read this translation are advised to    consult the authorities of their lineage. The responsibility for reading this text    or sharing it with others who may or may not fulfill the requirements lies in the    hands of readers.</p> <!--...--> </availability>
Content model 
<content/>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element emph { attribute rend { text }?, ( text | term )+ }⚓

1.24. <encodingDesc>

<encodingDesc> (encoding description) documents the relationship between an electronic text and the source or sources from which it was derived. [2.3. The Encoding Description 2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components]
Module header
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
Contained by
header: teiHeader
May contain
core: p
header: classDecl
Example
<encodingDesc>  <p>Basic encoding, capturing lexical information only. All    hyphenation, punctuation, and variant spellings normalized. No    formatting or layout information preserved.</p> </encodingDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="1">
  <classRef key="model.encodingDescPart"/>
  <classRef key="model.pLike"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element encodingDesc
{
   att.global.attributes,
   ( model.encodingDescPart | model.pLike )+
}⚓

1.25. <expan>

<expan> (expansion) contains the expansion of an abbreviation. [3.6.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions]
Module core
Member of
model.pPart.editorial
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

<expan> (expansion) contains the expansion of an abbreviation. Currently, this element is only being used in the back matter, in the notes section, as part of the source abbreviations list.
Example
<div type="notes">  <head type="notes">Notes</head>  <list type="abbreviations">   <head type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>   <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4730">    <abbr>BHS</abbr>    <expan>Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit</expan>   </item>   <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4731">    <abbr>Chinese</abbr>    <expan>6th century Chinese translation by Narendrayaśas (see Introduction, <ptr target="#UT22084-055-001-11"/> <!--i.7-->)</expan>   </item> <!--...etc-->  </list> </div>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element expan { macro.phraseSeq }⚓

1.26. <extension>

<extension> Indicates additional Toh reference numbers for a text that contains more than one.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Contained by
—
May contain Character data only
Note

Is to be used in the <sourceDesc>/<bibl> element for a text that contains more than one Toh number. Currently there are only two examples of this: Toh 2002 and Toh 2177.
Example
<ref>Toh 2177<extension>2178</extension>  <extension>2179</extension>  <extension>2180</extension>  <extension>2181</extension> </ref>
Content model 
<content>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element extension { text }⚓

1.27. <fileDesc>

<fileDesc> (file description) contains a full bibliographic description of an electronic file. [2.2. The File Description 2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components]
Module header
Contained by
header: teiHeader
May contain
header: editionStmt notesStmt publicationStmt sourceDesc titleStmt
Note

The major source of information for those seeking to create a catalog entry or bibliographic citation for an electronic file. As such, it provides a title and statements of responsibility together with details of the publication or distribution of the file, of any series to which it belongs, and detailed bibliographic notes for matters not addressed elsewhere in the header. It also contains a full bibliographic description for the source or sources from which the electronic text was derived.
Note

Currently, in 84000 texts the <fileDesc> contains the following elements in this order: a title statement (<titleStmt>), a edition statement (<editionStmt>), a publication statement (<publicationStmt>), a source description (<sourceDesc>), and a notes statement (<notesStmt>). Note that in 84000 specifications the placement of the <sourceDesc> and <notesStmt> are switched from that in the standard TEI header module, in which the <notesStmt> comes before the <sourceDesc>

Example
<fileDesc>  <titleStmt>   <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་རྒྱལ་པོའི་མདོ།</title> <!--... etc. a list of all the titles and authors-->  </titleStmt>  <editionStmt>   <edition>v 1.3 <date>2017</date>   </edition>  </editionStmt>  <publicationStmt status="1">   <publisher>    <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit      initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern      languages, and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>   <availability>    <licence>     <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>     <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC          BY-NC-ND (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It          may be copied or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and          not for commercial advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see          the Creative Commons license.</p>    </licence>   </availability>   <idno xml:id="UT22084-044-003"/>   <note>An early mistake in the assigning of UT numbers within the 84000 project      means that these ids diverge slightly from the standard logic.</note>   <date>2017-02-25</date>  </publicationStmt>  <sourceDesc>   <bibl key="toh83" type="text">    <ref>Toh 83</ref>    <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios 71.a–94.b</biblScope> <!--series>Degé Kangyur</series>, <biblScope>vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha)</biblScope>, <citedRange>folios 71a–94a</citedRange-->    <author role="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author>    <author role="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author>    <author role="translatorTib">Yeshé Dé</author>    <location count-pages="48"     work="UT4CZ5369">     <volume end-page="188" number="44"      start-page="141"/>    </location>    <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/>    <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC11626"     work="W22084"/>   </bibl>  </sourceDesc>  <notesStmt>   <note date-time="2019-02-26T08:34:43.421Z"    type="lastUpdated" user="celso">26/02/2019 08:34:43</note>  </notesStmt> </fileDesc>
Content model 
<content/>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element fileDesc
{
   titleStmt, editionStmt?, publicationStmt, sourceDesc, notesStmt?
}⚓

1.28. <foreign>

<foreign> (foreign) identifies a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than that of the surrounding text. [3.3.2.1. Foreign Words or Expressions]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:lang
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan written in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti written in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi written in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese written in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada written in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali written in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit written in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit written in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil written in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai written in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese written in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
cs
Czech
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
la
Latin
ru
Russian
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
ja
Japanese in Japanese script (Use Ja-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic written in Roman script.
mixed
This element contains strings mixed with different languages. They will be differentiated within this element by <foreign> tags, or left unwrapped if they are the default English.
type Identifies a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than that of the surrounding text. Denotes also that the word or phrase in question will appear in italics. The full tag includes the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate language value and also the type attribute with term, quote, or mantra as a value.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
quote
Any untranslated quotations taken from the source text (the translator will typically put these in the endnotes).
“Reverend Ānanda, do not bring shame upon us, but go in silence, lest the outsider sectarians should hear your words.” (Endnote−Tib. <foreign type="quote"  xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzhan mu stegs can spyod pa pa dang kun tu rgyu dang gcer bu pa dang tsho ba pa dag</foreign>; Skt. <foreign type="quote"  xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">anyatīrthika caraka parivrajaka nigranthājīvāḥ</foreign>. I have simply rendered this “outsider sectarians” so as not to burden the reader with irrelevant names, as this expression is a cliché for all the outsider groups occurring in other sūtras.)
term
A foreign term in parenthesis following its translation or a relatively rare foreign term left un-translated. Foreign terms also include short phrases that constitute technical or commonly used terms.
The mind is immaterial, invisible, baseless, and unconscious (Tib. <foreign type="term"  xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">rnam par rig pa med pa</foreign>; Skt. <foreign type="Sa-Ltn"  xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">avijñapti</foreign>; lit. “without means of cognition”).
Note

Note that sometimes there may be some overlap between what distinguishes the italics tag used for a “term” vs. a “quote.” In such cases you can use your own discretion, but in general italics used for a “term” are for specific a word or phrase that is left untranslated usually because it is technical, untranslatable, or for some other reason. In contrast the italics used for a “quote” are for italics used for a word or phrase citing a specific instance in a source text either to corroborate the English translation, or to note some difference between two or more sources. Both tags are rendered the same in the end, so this isn’t a critical call to make. There is no need spend time looking up italics to determine whether or not they are found in sources, but just keep this general principle in mind when distinguishing the proper tag for italics.

key
Status Optional
Note

Used to specify when an segment of foreign text is intended to appear in one version of a text but not another. This is useful when there are slight variations in a mantra or dharani. For example a segment of a dharani maybe arranged to appear in one form Toh 676, but with a variation in Toh 850, which is another version of the same text. The keys are defined in the <sourceDesc> of every 84000 published text.
Member of
bibl-section-content head-content model.emphLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign head item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

84000 uses this element to tag foreign words throughout documents with exception for the titles of texts, which should be tagged with the <title> element. All instances of the <foreign> element must contain the xml:lang with its value following the ISO 639-1 codes; however, for any language that is not usually written in a Roman script (i.e., Sanskrit, Tibetan, Chinese, Pali, etc...), if the language is written in a Romanized script then the first letter should be capitalized and "-Ltn" should be added to the value. For example Sanskrit "sa" becomes "Sa-Ltn", Tibetan "bo" becomes "Bo-Ltn", Chinese "zh" becomes "Zh-Ltn" and so forth. But use, the regular ISO 639-1 code if the native script is used (usually this should only be the case with Tibetan "bo" or Chinese "zh"). Most instances of the <foreign> element should include the type attribute detailed above, although there are a few exceptions when foreign text will not fall into the "term" or "quote" category and this attribute is not needed, for instance, the case of Tibetan Wylie transliteration given in parenthesis after the phonetic rendering of a Tibetan name. However, in general romanized foreign names should not be tagged with the <foreign> element. This tag should only be used for foreign text that are to be italicized according to 84000's style guidelines, as our parser will italicize all instances of foreign text in the web display. There is one exception to this, in that text in the Tibetan and Chinese script should be tagged with the <foreign> element, but will not be italicized in the parser.
Example
<note>With this paragraph begins a list of the “four confidences (<foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">vaiśāradya</foreign>) of a thus-gone one.”</note>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element foreign
{
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "Bo-Ltn"
    | "Gu-Ltn"
    | "Hi-Ltn"
    | "Ja-Ltn"
    | "Kn-Ltn"
    | "Mr-Ltn"
    | "Mn-Ltn"
    | "Pi-Ltn"
    | "Pra-Ltn"
    | "Sa-Ltn"
    | "Ta-Ltn"
    | "Th-Ltn"
    | "Zh-Ltn"
    | "bo"
    | "cs"
    | "de"
    | "el"
    | "en"
    | "fr"
    | "it"
    | "la"
    | "ru"
    | "zh"
    | "ja"
    | "middle_indic-Ltn"
    | "mixed"
   },
   attribute type { "quote" | "term" }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}⚓

1.29. <front>

<front> (front matter) contains any prefatory matter (headers, abstracts, title page, prefaces, dedications, etc.) found at the start of a document, before the main body. [4.6. Title Pages 4. Default Text Structure]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: text
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic head hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
textstructure: trailer
character data
Note

The <front> (front matter) contains any prefatory matter. It is the first section of the <text> structure, so it comes after the <teiHeader>, which is outside of the <text> itself, and before the <body>, which is the second part of the <text> proper. The front matter of an encoded text should not be confused with the TEI header. The TEI Header, serves as a kind of front matter for the computer file itself, not the text it encodes. The <front> contains the written material that does not form part of the translated text, including the summary, acknowledgement and introduction (in that order). These three sections in the <front> are nested within <div> elements which each are appropriately labeled by the value of their type attribute, as in the following example:
Example
<front>  <div type="summary">   <head type="summary">Summary</head>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-046-001-1"/>   <p tid="1"> <!--...-->   </p>  </div>  <div type="acknowledgment">   <head type="acknowledgment"> Acknowledgments</head>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-046-001-2"/>   <p tid="2"> <!--...-->   </p>   <p tid="3"> <!--...-->   </p>  </div>  <div type="introduction">   <head type="introduction">Introduction</head>   <div type="section">    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-046-001-3"/>    <p tid="7"> <!--...-->    </p>   </div>  </div> </front>
Content model 
<content>summarysummarysummaryzhacknowledgmentacknowledgmentprefaceprefaceintroductionintroductionsectionsectionsectionsectionsectionsection</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element front
{
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "summary" },
      (
         element head { attribute type { "summary" }, head-content }
       | section-content
      )+
   }?,
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "summary" },
      attribute xml:lang { "zh" },
      section-content
   }?,
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "acknowledgment" },
      (
         element head { attribute type { "acknowledgment" }, head-content }
       | section-content
      )+
   }?,
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "preface" },
      element head { attribute type { "preface" }, head-content },
      section-content,
      translation-section*
   }*,
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "introduction" },
      (
         element head { attribute type { "introduction" }, head-content }
       | section-content
       | element div
         {
            attribute type { "section" },
            attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
            element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }?,
            section-content,
            element div
            {
               attribute type { "section" },
               attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
               element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }?,
               section-content,
               element div
               {
                  attribute type { "section" },
                  attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
                  element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }?,
                  section-content
               }*
            }*
         }*
      )+
   }?
}⚓

1.30. <gloss>

<gloss> (gloss) identifies a phrase or word used to provide a gloss or definition for some other word or phrase. [3.4.1. Terms and Glosses 22.4.1. Description of Components]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Datatype ID
type Identifies the glossary item as being either a person, place, or term.
Derived from att.typed
Status Required
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
person
place
term
text
mode Used to identify terms in the glossary that may not be applicable to every instance in the text. A <gloss> element with the mode "match" will match with all instances of that string in the text unless they are marked with <term type="ignore">. A term in the glossary with the mode "marked" will only link to terms with the <term> element.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
match
marked
Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: term
Note

In the glossary found in the back material of each 84000 text, the <gloss> element wraps each glossary term with its variations in Tibetan and Sanskrit along with a definition. The <gloss> element is requires the xml:id attribute, and the type attribute declaring whether it is a "term", "person", "place", or "text". The first <term> element (which has no attributes and presents the English translation of the term) will create a link to the glossary in the reading room for each instance of that term as it appears as a string in the text. However, in some cases it may be inappropriate to link certain strings of text that match this term and so optionally the mode attribute may be added with the values of "marked" or "match". A <gloss> element with the mode "match" will match with all instances of that string in the text unless they are marked with <term type="ignore">. A term in the glossary with the mode "marked" will only link to terms with the <term> element. of the term, that are marked also by <term> tags the type attribute with the value of "alternate".
Note

There also may be occasions were the translator has used alternate translations for the same term, or different variations for the spelling of a string that correspond to the same glossary entry. In this case an additional <term > element should be added with the value "alternative". This will cause the parser to link these alternate string instances of the text in 84000's reading room.
Example
<gloss mode="marked" type="place"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4817">  <term>Mucilinda </term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">btang bzung </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">བཏང་བཟུང།</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Mucilinda</term>  <term type="definition">An unidentified mountain mentioned in a number of sūtras,    not apparently connected to the well-known nāga of that name, but perhaps to the    sacred mucilinda tree, known in English mainly as the bayur tree.</term> </gloss>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="term"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element gloss
{
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute xml:id { text },
   attribute type { "person" | "place" | "term" | "text" },
   attribute mode { "match" | "marked" }?,
   term+
}⚓

1.31. <graphic>

<graphic> (graphic) indicates the location of a graphic or illustration, either forming part of a text, or providing an image of it. [3.10. Graphics and Other Non-textual Components 11.1. Digital Facsimiles]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.media (att.internetMedia (@mimeType)) att.resourced (@url)
Member of
model.graphicLike
Contained by
core: author biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: licence publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Empty element
Note

Currently only used to display the creative commons logo in the publication statement of 84000 texts:
