Example
<licence>  <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>  <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND    (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It may be copied or    printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and not for commercial    advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see the Creative Commons    license.</p> </licence>
Content model 
<content>
 <empty/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element graphic { att.media.attributes, att.resourced.attributes, empty }⚓

1.32. <head>

<head> (heading) contains any type of heading, for example the title of a section, or the heading of a list, glossary, manuscript description, etc. [4.2.1. Headings and Trailers]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type classifies the head according to the 84000 typology.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
summary
introduction
appendix
acknowledgment
abbreviations
description
table
nonStructuralBreak
A heading that does not show a structural division and is not represented by a new parent <div> element. Note that this will be displayed with a slightly smaller font than the regular heading and be held in square brackets. To display the heading in the same manner as the other headings without brackets, leave the <head> elemant without a type attribute.
translation
titleHon
Honorifics before the title proper, e.g., "The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra..."
titleMain
sub
subtitle
author
If author is to be named in the heading, as with a preface for instance (see toh 113).
notes
section
chapter
list
listBibl
chapterTitle
prologue
preface
homage
tid
Status Optional
key
Status Optional
Member of
model.headLike section-content
Contained by
core: list
figures: table
textstructure: back body div front
May contain
core: foreign note title
character data
Note

Unlike the div tags, the text between the opening and closing head tags are visible to the reader. So any major section of the front, body or back parts of the text that has a title, wraps that title in a head tag. Head tags need to follow directly after a div tag, or another head tag. Head tags have type attributes with values that often match the text between the tags. You can see this in the following snippet, from the front part of UT22084-060-008.
Example
<div type="summary">  <head type="summary">Summary</head>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-060-008-1"/>  <p tid="1"> In <title xml:lang="en">Teaching the Relative and Ultimate      Truths</title>, the bodhisattva Mañjuśrī is summoned by Buddha Śākyamuni from a    faraway buddha realm to teach in a way that demolishes all dualistic experience.   <!--... etc-->  </p> </div> <div type="acknowledgment">  <head type="acknowledgment">Acknowledgments</head>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-060-008-2"/>  <p tid="2">Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee under the guidance    of Chökyi Nyima Rinpoche. <!--... etc-->  </p> </div>
Example The heading of the main section of the translation typically preceded by the section heading "The Translation" and the title honorifics, each given a separate heading tag:
<div type="translation">  <head tid="211" type="translation">The Translation</head>  <head tid="212" type="titleHon">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra</head>  <head tid="213" type="titleMain">The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant</head>  <div type="section"> <!--... the body of the main translation begins here...-->  </div> </div>
Example Optionally a subtitle may be added after the main title as seen in Toh 438:
<body>  <div type="translation">   <head tid="12" type="translation">The Translation</head>   <head tid="13" type="titleMain">Praise to Tārā with Twenty-One Verses of Homage</head>   <head tid="51" type="sub">and Their Benefits</head> <!--... etc-->  </div> <!--... etc--> </body>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="1">
  <textNode/>
  <elementRef key="foreign"/>
  <elementRef key="note"/>
  <elementRef key="title"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element head
{
   attribute type
   {
      "summary"
    | "introduction"
    | "appendix"
    | "acknowledgment"
    | "abbreviations"
    | "description"
    | "table"
    | "nonStructuralBreak"
    | "translation"
    | "titleHon"
    | "titleMain"
    | "sub"
    | "author"
    | "notes"
    | "section"
    | "chapter"
    | "list"
    | "listBibl"
    | "chapterTitle"
    | "prologue"
    | "preface"
    | "homage"
   }?,
   attribute tid { text }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   ( text | foreign | note | title )+
}⚓

1.33. <hi>

<hi> (highlighted) marks a word or phrase as graphically distinct from the surrounding text, for reasons concerning which no claim is made. [3.3.2.2. Emphatic Words and Phrases 3.3.2. Emphasis, Foreign Words, and Unusual Language]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id)
rend
Status Required
Legal values are:
small-caps
subscript
superscript
Member of
bibl-section-content endnote model.hiLike paragraph
Contained by
core: abbr author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Character data only
Note

In 84000 texts the <hi> element is only used to render (1) "small-caps", (2) "subscript", and (3) "superscript" text. Generally these will be used as follows: (1) "small-caps" Latin capital letters are to be used in the abbreviations for Current Era (CE) and Before Current Era (BCE). (2) According to the Vienna Kangyur sigla system, the second letter sometimes uses a subscript letters. (3) There isn't any regularized use for superscript (superscript footnotes are genrated by the parser and do not need to be entered in the TEI), but for miscellaneous reasons they might be needed, in which case a <hi> rend="superscript" may be used. Note, for "small-caps" in the XML markup, use the lowercase letters, e.g. "ce", they will be rendered as uppercase in the display. However the "subscript" and "superscript" should use lower case or upper case according to the proper sigla or text. See examples below:
Example For marking dates CE or BCE
...active in the eastern Gangetic basin in the fifth century <hi rend="small-caps">bce</hi>.
Example For marking Kangyur sigla
<!--...in notes...--> <note index="10" place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-044-005-209">In K<hi rend="subscript">Q</hi> this title, included within the text, is preceded by this introductory sentence: <!--...etc...--> </note> <!--...in abbreviations section...--> <list type="abbreviations">  <head tid="135" type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>  <item xml:id="UT22084-044-005-111">   <abbr>K<hi rend="subscript">Q</hi>   </abbr>   <expan>Peking 1737 Kangyur</expan>   <item xml:id="UT22084-044-005-111">    <abbr>G<hi rend="subscript">bm</hi>    </abbr>    <expan>rnying rgyud bris ma</expan>   </item>   <item xml:id="UT22084-044-005-112">    <abbr>S</abbr>    <expan>Stok Palace (<foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">stog pho brang bris ma</foreign>)        Kangyur</expan>   </item>  </item> </list>
(See example from reading room.)
Example There are sometimes other uses of small caps. For example in Toh 145 there is a quotation of a dictionary entry with small-caps for entries. In this case there were diacritics used, so in order to rend it we needed to use combining diacritical marks:
<!--In the Intro at i.2--> <p> <!--...-->Commenting on the <hi rend="small-caps">Bodhisattvabhu&#773;misu&#773;tra</hi> [<foreign type="term" xml:lang="la">sic</foreign>], Buddhist exegetes, such as the sixth-century Chinese scholiast <hi rend="small-caps">Jinying    Huiyuan</hi>, describe dhāraṇī as part of <!--...--> </p>
As in the example above a ū with a combining overline ̅ should be done like this: u&#773;. (See how this looks in the reading room.)
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element hi
{
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   attribute rend { "small-caps" | "subscript" | "superscript" },
   text
}⚓

1.34. <idno>

<idno> (identifier) supplies any form of identifier used to identify some object, such as a bibliographic item, a person, a title, an organization, etc. in a standardized way. [13.3.1. Basic Principles 2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc. 2.2.5. The Series Statement 3.12.2.4. Imprint, Size of a Document, and Reprint Information]
Module header
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id)
parent-id
Status Optional
kb-id
Status Optional
Member of
model.nameLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Empty element
Note

In 84000 documents the <idno> element is only used in publication statement. It is used to identify the document by supplying a xml:id attribute, and should be placed just after <availability> inside the <publicationStmt>. When the XML is saved to 84000's database, the xml:id attributes throughout the text will be autmatically generated according to the xml:id value stated here.

A second <idno> element is also found in the <sourceDesc> along with the parent-id attribute.
Example
<publicationStmt>  <publisher> <!--...-->  </publisher>  <availability> <!--...-->  </availability>  <idno xml:id="UT22084-055-001"/>  <date>2018</date> </publicationStmt> <sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh425" type="text"> <!--...-->   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC21412"/>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <empty/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element idno
{
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   attribute parent-id { text }?,
   attribute kb-id { text }?,
   empty
}⚓

1.35. <item>

<item> (item) contains one component of a list. [3.8. Lists 2.6. The Revision Description]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:lang, @xml:id) att.global.rendition (@rend)
Contained by
core: list
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

Used as the child elements of a <list>. In 84000 documents they may be used throughout the text typically to separate items in a formal list or an outline in the introduction. See Appendix B.3 for further details on creating outlines. See the <list> element for documentation on the different types of lists

<item>s may contain the <label> element, to create a bold heading at the beginning of its contents as in the first example of XML markup below:
Example Here is an example of <item>s found in a <list> element.
<p tid="1837">Monks, Māra, the evil one, was aroused by these verses and had a dream with thirty-two omens. <ref cRef="F.148.a" type="folio"/> What are these thirty-two? They are as follows:</p> <list type="bullet">  <item>   <p tid="3007">1. He saw his abode being filled with darkness.</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="3008">2. The abode was filled with dust, and rough with scattered      pebbles.</p>  </item> <!--... etc.--> </list>
(See how this list is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element item
{
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   macro.specialPara
}⚓

1.36. <keywords>

<keywords> (keywords) contains a list of keywords or phrases identifying the topic or nature of a text. [2.4.3. The Text Classification]
Module header
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
Contained by
header: textClass
May contain Character data only
Note

Each individual keyword (including compound subject headings) should be supplied as a <term> element directly within the <keywords> element. An alternative usage, in which each <term> appears within an <item> inside a <list> is permitted for backwards compatibility, but is deprecated.

If no control list exists for the keywords used, then no value should be supplied for the scheme attribute.
Example
<keywords scheme="http://classificationweb.net">  <term>Babbage, Charles</term>  <term>Mathematicians - Great Britain - Biography</term> </keywords>
Example
<keywords>  <term>Fermented beverages</term>  <term>Central Andes</term>  <term>Schinus molle</term>  <term>Molle beer</term>  <term>Indigenous peoples</term>  <term>Ethnography</term>  <term>Archaeology</term> </keywords>
Content model 
<content>person-interlocutorperson-main-speakerperson-topicalmain-subjectsecondary-subject</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element keywords
{
   att.global.attributes,
   element term
   {
      attribute type
      {
         "person-interlocutor"
       | "person-main-speaker"
       | "person-topical"
       | "main-subject"
       | "secondary-subject"
      },
      attribute ref { text }?,
      text
   }*
}⚓

1.37. <l>

<l> (verse line) contains a single, possibly incomplete, line of verse. [3.13.1. Core Tags for Verse 3.13. Passages of Verse or Drama 7.2.5. Speech Contents]
Module core
Member of
model.lLike
Contained by
core: item lg note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi label lb list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: mantra
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

Should be contained within an <lg> element to separate stanzas. Note that the <lg> element is marked with milestones and the tid attribute, but <l> is not.
Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-046-001-1453"/> <lg tid="1836">  <l>“He will empty your city, O evil kinsman;</l>  <l>With your army powerless, you will be without an army and without allies.</l>  <l>When the Self-Arisen One, by his nature, pours down the rain of Dharma,</l>  <l>You will not know what to do or where to go.”</l> </lg>
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:l[not(.//tei:note//tei:l[. = current()])]"> Abstract model violation: Lines may not contain lines or lg elements. </s:report>
Content model 
<content/>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element l
{
   (
      text
    | model.gLike
    | model.phrase
    | model.inter
    | model.global
    | mantra
    | ref-canonical
    | ref-other
   )*
}⚓

1.38. <label>

<label> (label) contains any label or heading used to identify part of a text. [3.8. Lists]
Module core
Member of
model.labelLike section-content
Contained by
core: desc item l note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

Unlike section or chapter tags, label tags do not result in a real structural section of the text. A reader need to click a button to go to the next chapter. The label tag is a less obtrusive heading tag, labeling parts of texts, and not designating major sections. <label>s will appears in bold text in a slight larger type than the rest of the text, but the same color and same font.
Note

One example where you might use the <label> element is in an outline to create a bolder header for one item in the outline, as you can see in the example below.
Example
<div type="section">  <head type="section">Outline</head>  <list>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-055-001-44"/>   <item>    <label>Chapter 1: The Introduction</label>    <p tid="38">The Buddha Śākyamuni is on Vulture Peak Mountain outside Rājagṛha        with a great gathering of bhikṣus and bodhisattvas. Candraprabha asks him for        instruction. The Buddha states that evenness of mind is the one quality that        will bring enlightenment and the attainment of the samādhi called <title xml:lang="en">the revealed equality of the nature of all phenomena</title>,        which is described as having an array of qualities that covers all the various        aspects of the path. On hearing this, a multitude of beings attain various        stages of realization; the earth shakes, and a radiance illuminates the        universe.</p>   </item>   <milestone unit="chunk"    xml:id="UT22084-055-001-45"/>   <item>    <label>Chapter 2: Śālendrarāja</label> <!--... etc.-->   </item>  </list> </div>
(See how this list is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element label { macro.phraseSeq }⚓

1.39. <lb>

<lb> (line beginning) marks the beginning of a new (typographic) line in some edition or version of a text. [3.11.3. Milestone Elements 7.2.5. Speech Contents]
Module core
Member of
bibl-section-content model.milestoneLike paragraph section-content
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell table
header: publicationStmt titleStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain Empty element
Note

Although by and large TEI markup is aimed at semantics, not display, the lb tag is used for display purposes, where there should be a linebreak in the display text, but without the tag would not in fact occur. Typically the use of a <lb> should be avoided unless there is no other convenient way to display the line break in the web display.
Example
<p tid="1869">Such an army of demons formed a big gathering, stretching eighty leagues on every side. Just like this single army, so too the armies of hundreds of zillions of evil demons, residing in the great trichiliocosm, spread themselves around the Bodhisattva in horizontal and upward directions.</p> <lb/> <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-046-001-1474"/> <p tid="1870">On this topic, it is said:</p>
Content model 
<content>
 <empty/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element lb { empty }⚓

1.40. <lg>

<lg> (line group) contains one or more verse lines functioning as a formal unit, e.g. a stanza, refrain, verse paragraph, etc. [3.13.1. Core Tags for Verse 3.13. Passages of Verse or Drama 7.2.5. Speech Contents]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type Used to denote specific types of verses such as "sdom" or "bar_sdom" indexes and so forth.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
sdom
bar_sdom
spyi_sdom
tid Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text.
Status Required
rend
Status Optional
Legal values are:
mantra
This <lg> element contains a mantra. The mantra has been formally and clearly declared and so will set apart with indentation and vertical spacing in the 84000 web display. Not all <lg> elements that contain mantras need to be rendered in this way, but generally we do so, when they are formally and clearly declared in the text.
ignoreGlossary
Glossary terms found in this line group will not be linked to the glossary in the 84000 Reading Room.
Member of
macro.paraContent model.divPart section-content
Contained by
core: item note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: l milestone
derived-module-NewODD: mantra modPassage
Note

The line group, <element>, should be used to designate each stanza of verse. Individual lines of verse, <l>, are contained as child elements within each <lg>. Like the paragraph, <p> element, each <lg> should be preceded by a milestone and itself be identified with the tid attribute. However, the markup editors do not need to enter these manually as the tid will be automatically applied when the file is saved to the database and the <milestones> will be created by the script.
Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-135"/> <lg tid="92">  <l>“Lord of the World, Buddha,</l>  <l>Illuminator, bringer of benefit,</l>  <l>Elucidate what kind of practice</l>  <l>Will bring the attainment of inconceivable wisdom. {1} </l> </lg>
(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Schematron
<sch:assert test="count(descendant::tei:lg|descendant::tei:l|descendant::tei:gap) > 0">An lg element must contain at least one child l, lg, or gap element.</sch:assert>
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:l[not(.//tei:note//tei:lg[. = current()])]"> Abstract model violation: Lines may not contain line groups. </s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="1">
  <elementRef key="l"/>
  <elementRef key="milestone"/>
  <elementRef key="mantra"/>
  <elementRef key="modPassage"/>
  <elementRef key="canonRef"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element lg
{
   attribute type { "sdom" | "bar_sdom" | "spyi_sdom" }?,
   attribute tid { text },
   attribute rend { "mantra" | "ignoreGlossary" }?,
   ( l | milestone | mantra | modPassage | canonRef )+
}⚓

1.41. <licence>

<licence> contains information about a licence or other legal agreement applicable to the text. [2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc.]
Module header
Contained by
header: availability publicationStmt
May contain
core: graphic p
Note

This is only used as the child element to <availability> within the publication statement <publicationStmt>. In all texts it should appear according to the following example:
Example
<availability>  <licence>   <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>   <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND      (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It may be copied      or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and not for commercial      advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see the Creative Commons      license.</p>  </licence> </availability>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="graphic"/>
 <elementRef key="p"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element licence { graphic, p }⚓

1.42. <link>

<link> Used in the <sourceDesc> to define a relationship between one text and another. Currently the only @type is "commentaryOf" and the @targets are unverified toh keys.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributes
type
Status Required
target
Status Required
Contained by
header: sourceDesc
May contain Empty element

1.43. <list>

<list> (list) contains any sequence of items organized as a list. [3.8. Lists]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
type These "type" values are used to identify the types of lists used in various places throughout the text: "glossary" is applied to the main list in the glossary, "abbreviation" is applied to the list of abbreviations within the notes section of the text. In addition to these two standard lists, the <list> element is also used for any outlines, bulleted lists, or other lists that appear with the actual text itself. In this case, the type attribute with the value "section" or "bullet" should be used, and this will effect how the list is displayed by the parser. The type value "section" will render a list of sections, with some vertical spacing between each item in the list; this is ideal for lists where each item is a paragraph or longer. The type value "bullet" will render the list with indentation but without vertical spacing; this is ideal for short items with identifiers (it isn't necessary that there be an actual "bullet" before each item, this is just the name we are using to distinguish the type). The latter two list types may also be used in combination to create an outline. For instance, see the sample of XML markup below for Toh. 116. Note, that an additionally the attribute @rend="dots", "numbers", or "letters" maybe used to create a list with an automatically generated prefix (bullet, numbers, or letters respectively) and a hanging indent(see example below). This can be done in combination with a @type="section" list or a @type="bullet" list. For further information on outlines see Appendix B.3
Status Required
Legal values are:
glossary
abbreviations
section
bullet
rend Renders further changes to the display of lists in HTML and other formats.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
dots
Items in the list will have a generated bullet dot and hanging indent (may be used in combination with @type="section" or @type="bullet").
numbers
Items in the list will have a generated number prefixes and hanging indent (may be used in combination with @type="section" or @type="bullet").
letters
Items in the list will have a generated letter prefixes and hanging indent (may be used in combination with @type="section" or @type="bullet").
Member of
model.listLike section-content
Contained by
core: desc item l note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: head item p
Note

In general <list> elements may be used to demarcate a formal list anywhere in the text. As a standard, <lists> are used in the "notes" section to list the source material abbreviations key and used in the "glossary" section to list individual glossary entries. Additionally, lists may be used to create outlines or formal lists within the text. Each list must contain <item>s, which contain the individual items on a list. When creating an outline or formal list within the text, the type="section" or type="bullet" must be used. In the web display, type="section" will render items with some vertical spacing between each item, type="bullet" will not have vertical spacing, but will be indented. Multiple <list> elements in combination with these types to format an outline. For example see this outline in Toh. 116 and the XML markup in the example below. For further details on creating outlines see Appendix B.3

A list may contain a <head type="list"> element to create a bold heading at the beginning before the first <item> in the list. Within each <item>, a <label> element can be used to the same effect. See in the XML example below from Toh. 11

Note that <list>s along with their <item>s can be generated from the template .docx passed through our XSLT script. In MS Word, lists are auto-generated either by clicking the list icons on the menu bar or by entering a "1" or "*" and on a new line and hitting the space key. These lists will be rendered by the XSLT script with nested <list> and <item> tags. It can render multi-leveled lists or outlines, however they need to be auto-generated list in MS Word for them to pass through the script; you can determine that they are auto-generated when in MS Word the cursor will skip over the bullet point or numbered prefix of the list when passed across with the arrow keys. The first level <list> will be tagged type="bullet" by default, but second level lists and beyond will need the type attribute to be entered manually.
Example The following is an outline, notice that the primary list has the type="section" value and the sub-lists following it are marked up type="bullet". This will create and eloquent outline in the web display where the primary sections will be separated with some vertical spacing, but the sub-lists within the major sections will just be indented. See the web display for this list in Toh. 116 here.
<list type="section">  <item>   <p tid="642">I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery      when lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha      states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and      then the city of the pretas. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="643">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the          Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama          and describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and          praises him.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="644">II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="645">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells,          visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This          very sūtra sounds in their realm.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item> <!--... etc.--> </list>
Example Here is a simple bullet list used within Toh. 100 (See Reading Room display here).
<list type="bullet">  <item>   <p tid="309">i. When the JAA states that “non-arising” and “non-cessation” are      epithets of the Tathāgata, it shows that the Buddha is   <emph>unproduced</emph>.</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="310">ii. The nine examples explain what it means for the Tathāgata to be      non-arising and non-cessation (given in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ratna­gotra­vibhāga</title> as the reason for his being unproduced).</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="311">iii. The explanations of all that has been pacified show that, since      all his elaborations and concepts have been pacified, the Tathāgata is   <emph>effortless</emph> with respect to his own activities.</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="312">iv. The next section shows that the Tathāgata realizes for himself      the gates to the realization of the nature of all dharmas, and goes on to      explain the sixteen features of the Tathāgata’s realization (this links to   <emph>not arisen by understanding from others</emph>).</p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="313">v. One sentence describes the Tathāgata’s great compassion, showing      that he is endowed with unexcelled awareness and compassion.</p>  </item> </list>
Example Here in this outline from Toh. 11 (See reading room display here). The <label> element and the <head type="list"> element are both used to great bold headers:
<list type="section">  <head tid="3187" type="list">I. UNDERSTANDING OF ALL PHENOMENA</head>  <p tid="33">The first fourteen chapters of the text concern the theoretical    understanding of all phenomena, which is the first goal to be realized.    Śāradvatī­putra acts as Lord Buddha’s interlocutor in the first nine chapters,    with Su­bhūti making his initial appearance in chapter 10. </p>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-031-002-47"/>  <item>   <label>Chapters 1 and 2</label>   <p tid="35">In response to a question about what is the transcendent perfection of      wisdom which bodhisattvas are to perfect, Lord Buddha replies that it is the      absence of fixation with respect to all phenomena, all meditative experiences,      all causal attributes acquired by bodhisattvas, all fruitional attributes      manifested by buddhas, and all attainments up to and including omniscience.      along with unconditioned phenomena, such as the abiding nature of all things and      the finality of existence, these are all attributes with respect to which a      great bodhisattva being should cultivate detachment. Bodhisattvas do perceive      such phenomena distinctly, but only on the relative level; in an ultimate sense      they consider them to be illusory, in the manner of a dream and so forth. </p>  </item>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-031-002-48"/>  <item>   <label>Chapter 3</label>   <p tid="37">Fixation may ensue when those phenomena and attributes are considered      as permanent or impermanent, as conducive to happiness or suffering, with self      or without self, empty or not empty, with signs or signless, having or lacking      aspirations, calm or not calm, void or not void, afflicted or purified, arising      or not arising, ceasing or not ceasing, and as entities or non-entities. Deluded      minds would view these phenomena and attributes as absolutely existent whereas      bodhisattvas should train so as to understand that they are all      non-apprehensible—mere designations and conceptualizations. </p>  </item> <!--...etc...--> </list>
Example Here is an example of a bullet list with hanging indents rendered with the @rend="dots" attribute. Note that the bullet dot will be generated by the parser. (See Reading Room Display for this example in Toh 674 here)
<list rend="dots" type="bullet">  <item>   <p tid="35">The name <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshe dpag tu med pa</foreign>      (Aparimitāyus), which occurs a number of times here in Toh 674, is given its longer form      in Toh 675: <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa</foreign>      (Aparimitāyur­jñāna). </p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="36">The name of Aparimitāyur­jñāna’s realm here in Toh 674 is <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">yon        tan dpag tu med pa sogs pa</foreign> (Aparimita­guṇa­saṃcaya, “Accumulation of Immeasurable      Qualities”), but in Toh 675 the first mention of it is just <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">yon tan dpag        tu med pa</foreign> (Aparimitaguṇa, “Immeasurable Qualities”). </p>  </item> <!--...--> </list>
Example Here is an example for the standard list used for abbreviations (See Reading Room display here).
<list type="abbreviations">  <head type="abbreviations">Abbreviations</head>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4730">   <abbr>BHS</abbr>   <expan>Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit</expan>  </item>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4731">   <abbr>Chinese</abbr>   <expan>6th century Chinese translation by Narendrayaśas (see Introduction, <ptr target="#UT22084-055-001-11"/> <!--i.7-->)</expan>  </item>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4732">   <abbr>Commentary</abbr>   <expan>Mañjuśrīkīrti (see bibliography) </expan>  </item>  <item xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4733">   <abbr>Gilgit</abbr>   <expan>6-7th century Sanskrit manuscript (see Introduction <ptr target="#UT22084-055-001-13"/> <!--i.9--> and bibliography under Dutt).</expan>  </item> <!--... etc.--> </list>
Schematron
<sch:rule context="tei:list[@type='gloss']"> <sch:assert test="tei:label">The content of a "gloss" list should include a sequence of one or more pairs of a label element followed by an item element</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="head"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="1">
  <elementRef key="item"/>
  <elementRef key="p"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element list
{
   attribute type { "glossary" | "abbreviations" | "section" | "bullet" },
   attribute rend { "dots" | "numbers" | "letters" }?,
   head*,
   ( item | p )+
}⚓

1.44. <location>

<location>
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributes
count-pages
Status Required
work
Status Required
Contained by
header: sourceDesc
May contain
derived-module-NewODD: volume
Note

The element <location> is found in in TEI module "namesdates" however, it is intended to be used only to refer to geographic locations, whereas here 84000 is using the element to show the texts location in the Kangyur, Tengyur or other collection defined by the work attribute. For each text this should be present in the <sourceDesc>, see the example below.
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh11" type="text"> <!--...-->   <location count-pages="788"    work="UT4CZ5369">    <volume end-page="593" number="31"     start-page="414"/>    <volume end-page="611" number="32"     start-page="2"/>   </location> <!--...-->  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="volume"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element location
{
   attribute count-pages { text },
   attribute work { text },
   volume+
}⚓

1.45. <mantra>

<mantra>
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributes
xml:lang
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan written in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti written in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi written in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese written in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada written in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali written in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit written in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit written in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil written in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai written in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese written in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
cs
Czech
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
la
Latin
ru
Russian
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
ja
Japanese in Japanese script (Use Ja-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic written in Roman script.
mixed
This element contains strings mixed with different languages. They will be differentiated within this element by <foreign> tags, or left unwrapped if they are the default English.
rend (rendition) indicates how the element in question was rendered or presented in the source text.
Derived from att.global.rendition
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.word separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
ignoreGlossary
Glossary terms found in the mantra will not be linked to the glossary in the 84000 Reading Room.
type
Status Optional
Legal values are:
dharani
vidya
vidyamantra
secret_mantra
syllable
key
Status Optional
Note

Used to specify when a mantra or segment of a mantra is intended to appear in one version of a text but not another. For example a mantra maybe arranged to appear in Toh 676, but not in Toh 850, which is another version of the same text. The keys are defined in the <sourceDesc> of every 84000 published text.
Member of
endnote macro.paraContent macro.specialPara paragraph
Contained by
core: item l lg note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

The mantra element is used to document any instance of a mantra string. Note that the parser will italicize mantra elements in dependence upon its xml:lang attribute. It will be italicized for any language value other than "en" (English) or "mixed". If the mantra is "mixed", that is to say fragments of it are represented in more than one language, then those fragments should be further distinguished within the <mantra> element with child <foreign> elements (except for English, which is the default). In this scenario, the italics will then be rendered according to these child <foreign> elements rather then the <mantra> element itself.

Note, that the <mantra> element is also used to wrap single or multiple seed syllables referenced in the text and should be labeled type="syllable" in such cases.

If the text ever clearly defines a string as a "dharani", "vidya", "vidyamantra", or "secret mantra", etc... then this should be indicated by a type ="dharani", "etc." attribute.

Because mantras are presented in many different styles and scenarios a guide for how to mark them up is documented in the appendix. Please see Appendix B.6 for further details about marking up mantras.

Example Here is a simple example of a complete mantra in Sanskrit contained in the main text. As there are many other scenarios that require mantra tags to be applied differently, please see the guide for marking up mantras in the appendix B.6
<p>Then they recited the following mantra:</p> <p rend="mantra" tid="432">  <mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">oṁ tāre svāhā.</mantra> </p>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element mantra
{
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "Bo-Ltn"
    | "Gu-Ltn"
    | "Hi-Ltn"
    | "Ja-Ltn"
    | "Kn-Ltn"
    | "Mr-Ltn"
    | "Mn-Ltn"
    | "Pi-Ltn"
    | "Pra-Ltn"
    | "Sa-Ltn"
    | "Ta-Ltn"
    | "Th-Ltn"
    | "Zh-Ltn"
    | "bo"
    | "cs"
    | "de"
    | "el"
    | "en"
    | "fr"
    | "it"
    | "la"
    | "ru"
    | "zh"
    | "ja"
    | "middle_indic-Ltn"
    | "mixed"
   },
   attribute rend { list { "ignoreGlossary"+ } }?,
   attribute type
   {
      "dharani" | "vidya" | "vidyamantra" | "secret_mantra" | "syllable"
   }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   macro.paraContent
}⚓

1.46. <media>

<media> indicates the location of any form of external media such as an audio or video clip etc. [3.10. Graphics and Other Non-textual Components]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.typed (@type) att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend)) att.timed (@start, @end)
mimeType
Status Required
Legal values are:
audio/mpeg
url (uniform resource locator) Indicate the url, "/audio/..." of the audio file from the folder db/apps/84000-data/audio/
Derived from att.resourced
Status Required
Datatype teidata.pointer
Member of
model.graphicLike section-content
Contained by
core: author biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: desc
Note

Indicates the location of any form of external media. Currently we are using this markup to embed audio clips in the reading room. This element requires that the @mimeType be marked, which for our 84000 texts will be "audio/mpeg" by default. Audio files can be uploaded to 84000-data/audio as long as they are small. If there's a need for longer recordings we'll have to consider a streaming solution. The @url, "/audio/..." will indicate the audio file to be fetched from the folder db/apps/84000-data/audio. See an example in Toh 729.
Example
<figure>  <media mimeType="image/png" url="fig1.png"/>  <head>Figure One: The View from the Bridge</head>  <figDesc>A Whistleresque view showing four or five sailing boats in the foreground, and a    series of buoys strung out between them.</figDesc> </figure>
Example
<media dur="PT10S" mimeType="audio/wav"  url="dingDong.wav">  <desc>Ten seconds of bellringing sound</desc> </media>
Example
<media dur="PT45M" mimeType="video/mp4"  url="clip45.mp4" width="500px">  <desc>A 45 minute video clip to be displayed in a window 500    px wide</desc> </media>
Content model 
<content>
 <classRef key="model.descLike"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element media
{
   att.typed.attributes,
   att.global.attributes,
   att.timed.attributes,
   attribute mimeType { "audio/mpeg" },
   attribute url { text },
   model.descLike*
}⚓

1.47. <milestone>

<milestone> (milestone) marks a boundary point separating any kind of section of a text, typically but not necessarily indicating a point at which some part of a standard reference system changes, where the change is not represented by a structural element. [3.11.3. Milestone Elements]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:id, @xml:lang) att.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Datatype ID
unit provides a conventional name for the kind of section changing at this milestone.
Derived from att.milestoneUnit
Status Required
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
chunk
Member of
bibl-section-content model.milestoneLike section-content
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign item l label lg note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain Empty element
Note

In the texts, we use the milestone tag to develop as artificial demarcations of the text that will eventually allow people to refer to parts of a text in a somewhat standardized manner. Because there are no consistent natural break points in the original Tibetan texts, the 84000 team decided to use milestone tags. They represent small amounts of texts that are in someway semantically cohesive. They are not tied to a specific text length, but they are not more than a few paragraphs. See the instructions for entering milestones into the text in the appendix

Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-046-001-351"/> <p tid="416">When the Bodhisattva saw that they were settled, he offered them a Dharma teaching and made sure that they understood, became inspired, and were filled with joy.</p>
Content model 
<content>
 <empty/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element milestone
{
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute xml:id { text },
   attribute unit { "chunk" },
   empty
}⚓

1.48. <modPassage>

<modPassage>
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributes
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Datatype ID
type
Status Optional
Sample values include:
part
Status Optional
Member of
macro.paraContent macro.specialPara paragraph
Contained by
core: item lg note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element modPassage
{
   attribute xml:id { text },
   attribute type { text }?,
   attribute part { text }?,
   macro.paraContent
}⚓

1.49. <name>

<name> (name, proper noun) contains a proper noun or noun phrase. [3.6.1. Referring Strings]
Module core
Member of
model.nameLike.agent
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Character data only
Note

This is only used as a child in the <publisher> element inside the publishers statement to tag 84000's own name. See the following example:
Example
<publisher>  <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern languages, and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element name { text }⚓

1.50. <note>

<note> (note) contains a note or annotation. [3.9.1. Notes and Simple Annotation 2.2.6. The Notes Statement 3.12.2.8. Notes and Statement of Language 9.3.5.4. Notes within Entries]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
place specifies where this item is placed.
Derived from att.placement
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
end
type
Status Optional
Note

Here the type attribute is only used for the one <note> element found in the <notesStmt> to indicate information about file updates. Type indicates the type of note. This is automated by the forms in operations.
index Gives the number of the note.
Status Optional
date-time
Status Optional
Note

Only used in the <note> in the <notesStmt> to indicate a timestamp for when the note was added. This is automated by the forms in operations.
user
Status Optional
Note

Only used in the <note> in the <notesStmt> to indicate that it shows by who the file was last updated. This is automated by the forms in operations.
update
Status Optional
Note

if type = 'update' then this is the type of update. This is automated by the forms in operations.
import
Status Optional
Note

With in the <noteStmt> allows us to track which file it was imported from and overwrite if we re-import.
value
Status Optional
Note

if type = 'update' then this is the value of the update. This is automated by the forms in operations.
Member of
bibl-section-content model.noteLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope distinct editor expan foreign head item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell table
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

<note> contains an endnote. Though it appears in the TEI encoded text inline, it is displayed separately in the reading room version, where it is displayed as a pop-up in addition to be listed at the end in the "notes" section. It will presumably be displayed as end notes in the PDF version.
Example All of the <note>s in the front matter and body of text require the following attributes: xml:id and place (with the value "end").
<l>When he said the letter <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">aṃ</foreign>, out came the statement: “The emergence of what is efficacious (<foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">amoghotpatti</foreign>).”<note index="3" place="end"   xml:id="UT22084-046-001-3071">Translation is based on the Sanskrit.</note> </l>
Example Occasionally you may need to display a note differently for two duplicate texts with distinct Toh numbers as there may be content or differences that affect one but not the other. It is important that we keep the same index of milestones and notes the same in these parallel versions of duplicate texts. However we may differentiate the content of the notes by using separate <p> elements with key attributes to distinguish the text contained in each file. See for example note 6 in Toh 725/1001:
<note place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-094-006-12">  <p key="toh729" tid="23">Note that there is a discrepancy among various databases for    cataloging the Toh 1001 version of this text within vol. 101 or 102 of the Degé Kangyur. See Toh 1001, <ref target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh1001.html#end-note-UT22084-094-006-12">note 6</ref>, for    details.</p>  <p key="toh1001" tid="24">This text, Toh 1001, and all those    contained in this same volume (<foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzungs, waM</foreign>), are listed as being located in volume    101 of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including    the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Room—list this work as being located    in volume 102. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzungs      ’dus</foreign> section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that    the compilers of the Tōhoku catalog placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Vimala­prabhā­nāma­kālacakra­tantra­ṭīkā</title> (<title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri      med ’od</title>, Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost    certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is    often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar chags</foreign>    (catalog). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation.</p> </note>
[See how this page is rendered in the web display.]
Example There is one <note> element found at in the <notesStmt> within the <teiHeader>. This <note> simply indicates the last update for the file and is unrelated to the endnotes of the text. For this one occurrence, the <note> will have the type, date-time, user, update, and value attributes; and it does not use the xml:id attribute or the index attribute. This will be maintained by the forms in operations and does not need to be manually entered by markup editors.
<notesStmt>  <note date-time="2019-03-03T20:47:51.274Z"   type="lastUpdated" user="celso">03/03/2019 20:47:51</note> </notesStmt>
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <macroRef key="macro.specialPara"/>
  <elementRef key="hi"/>
  <elementRef key="mantra"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element note
{
   att.global.attributes,
   attribute place { list { "end"+ } }?,
   attribute type { text }?,
   attribute index { text }?,
   attribute date-time { text }?,
   attribute user { text }?,
   attribute update { text }?,
   attribute import { text }?,
   attribute value { text }?,
   ( macro.specialPara | hi | mantra )*
}⚓

1.51. <notesStmt>

<notesStmt> (notes statement) collects together any notes providing information about a text additional to that recorded in other parts of the bibliographic description. [2.2.6. The Notes Statement 2.2. The File Description]
Module header
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain Character data only
Note

We use this element within the TEI header to record the update of the file. This does not need to be entered in by the editor as it will automatically be entered when the file is saved to the database.
Example
<notesStmt>  <note date-time="2019-02-26T08:34:43.421Z"   type="lastUpdated" user="celso">26/02/2019 08:34:43</note> </notesStmt>
Content model 
<content/>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element notesStmt
{
   element note
   {
      attribute type { text }?,
      attribute date-time { text }?,
      attribute value { text }?,
      attribute user { text }?,
      attribute update { text }?,
      attribute import { text }?,
      text
   }*
}⚓

1.52. <p>

<p> (paragraph) marks paragraphs in prose. [3.1. Paragraphs 7.2.5. Speech Contents]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
tid Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text.
Status Optional
key Designates a paragraph to only be applicable and only be displayed in one text version according to the key defined in the <sourceDesc>.
Status Optional
type
Status Optional
Legal values are:
tantricRestriction
This paragraph warns the reader that this text has a tantric restrition. Thie <p> should be stated in the text's <availability> in the <publicationStmt>
sponsor
This paragraph details the sponsor for the publication of the text, and this should be placed in the "acknowledgements" found int he front of the text.
rend
Status Optional
Legal values are:
mantra
This <p> element contains a mantra. The mantra has been formally and clearly declared and so will set apart with indentation and vertical spacing in the 84000 web display. Not all <p> elements that contain mantras need to be rendered in this way, but generally we do so, when they are formally and clearly declared in the text.
ignoreGlossary
Glossary terms found in this paragraph will not be linked to the glossary in the 84000 Reading Room.
Member of
bibl-section-content model.pLike
Contained by
core: item list note q
header: encodingDesc licence publicationStmt sourceDesc
textstructure: back body div front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

This is by far the most common tag used in the markup. Pretty much any prose other than special elements, such as titles, finds itself between an opening and closing <p> tag. Note that each <p> element should be numbered by the tid attribute; however, the markup editors do not need to enter these manually as they will be automatically applied when the file is saved to the database.
Note

Most of the <p> elements should be preceded by a <milestone> element. These will be automatically created by the XSLT script, but markup editors should go through and delete some of them according to the guidelines for entering in milestones.
Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-061-014-1"/> <p tid="1">The sūtra is introduced with the Buddha residing in Anāthapiṇḍada’s grove in Jeta Wood in Śrāvastī together with a great assembly of monks and a great multitude of bodhisatvas. The Buddha then addresses the bodhisatva Jayamati, instructs him on nineteen moral prescriptions, and indicates the corresponding effects of practicing these prescriptions when they are cultivated. </p>
Schematron
<s:report test="not(ancestor::tei:floatingText) and (ancestor::tei:p or ancestor::tei:ab) and not(parent::tei:exemplum |parent::tei:item |parent::tei:note |parent::tei:q |parent::tei:quote |parent::tei:remarks |parent::tei:said |parent::tei:sp |parent::tei:stage |parent::tei:cell |parent::tei:figure )"> Abstract model violation: Paragraphs may not occur inside other paragraphs or ab elements. </s:report>
Schematron
<s:report test="ancestor::tei:l[not(.//tei:note//tei:p[. = current()])]"> Abstract model violation: Lines may not contain higher-level structural elements such as div, p, or ab. </s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element p
{
   attribute tid { text }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   attribute type { "tantricRestriction" | "sponsor" }?,
   attribute rend { "mantra" | "ignoreGlossary" }?,
   macro.paraContent
}⚓

1.53. <profileDesc>

<profileDesc> (text-profile description) provides a detailed description of non-bibliographic aspects of a text, specifically the languages and sublanguages used, the situation in which it was produced, the participants and their setting. [2.4. The Profile Description 2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components]
Module header
Contained by
header: teiHeader
May contain
header: textClass
Note

Although the content model permits it, it is rarely meaningful to supply multiple occurrences for any of the child elements of <profileDesc> unless these are documenting multiple texts.
Example
<profileDesc>  <langUsage>   <language ident="fr">French</language>  </langUsage>  <textDesc n="novel">   <channel mode="w">print; part issues</channel>   <constitution type="single"/>   <derivation type="original"/>   <domain type="art"/>   <factuality type="fiction"/>   <interaction type="none"/>   <preparedness type="prepared"/>   <purpose degree="high" type="entertain"/>   <purpose degree="medium" type="inform"/>  </textDesc>  <settingDesc>   <setting>    <name>Paris, France</name>    <time>Late 19th century</time>   </setting>  </settingDesc> </profileDesc>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="textClass" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element profileDesc { textClass? }⚓

1.54. <ptr>

<ptr> (pointer) defines a pointer to another location. [3.7. Simple Links and Cross-References 16.1. Links]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.internetMedia (@mimeType)
target specifies the destination of the reference by supplying one or more URI References
Derived from att.pointing
Status Required
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Member of
bibl-section-content model.ptrLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain Character data only
Note

This element is used for in-text citations. The target attribute will point to the xml:id value of the appropriate <milestone>, <note>, or <bibl> (The value should be preceded by a "#" as in the example below). In the reading room this will create a link with the appropriate number. The milestone number itself will be automatically rendered in the reading room display, so this shouldn't be entered into the <ptr> element itself, but it may be displayed after as a comment for the editor's reference. Note, that links to other texts, i.e., external links, should be done with the <ref> element and not the <ptr> element. For more information on how to create links and references see Appendix B.4

Example
<p tid="17">A passage from chapter 3 in which the Buddha summarizes for Candraprabha the qualities of a tathāgata (<ptr target="#UT22084-055-001-427"/> <!--3.3-->) seems to have been the source for the short Kangyur sūtra <!--...--> </p>
Schematron
<s:report test="@target and @cRef">Only one of the attributes @target and @cRef may be supplied on <s:name/>.</s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element ptr
{
   att.internetMedia.attributes,
   attribute target { list { + } },
   text
}⚓

1.55. <publicationStmt>

<publicationStmt> (publication statement) groups information concerning the publication or distribution of an electronic or other text. [2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc. 2.2. The File Description]
Module header
Attributes Attributes
status Identifies what stage the text is in preparation for publication.
Status Required
Legal values are:
1
Translations completed and published
1.a
Ready to publish
2
Markedup, awaiting final proofing
2.a
Markup in process
2.b
Awaiting markup
2.c
Awaiting copyeditor's OK for markup
2.d
Copyediting complete. Preparing for markup
2.e
Being copyedited
2.f
Review complete. Awaiting copyediting
2.g
In Editorial review
2.h
Awaiting review
3
Current translation projects
4
Application pending
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno licence
character data
Note

For 84000 documents, the <publisherStmt> should contain the <publisher>, <availability>, <idno>, and <date> elements in that order. Recently, we added a <note> about the ids, which may optionally appear between the <idno> and <date>.
Example
<publicationStmt status="1">  <publisher>   <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit    initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern languages,    and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>  <availability>   <licence>    <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>    <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND        (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It may be        copied or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and not for        commercial advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see the        Creative Commons license.</p>   </licence>  </availability>  <idno xml:id="UT22084-044-003"/>  <note>An early mistake in the assigning of UT numbers within the 84000 project means    that these ids diverge slightly from the standard logic.</note>  <date>2017-02-25</date> </publicationStmt>
Content model 
<content>tantricRestriction</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element publicationStmt
{
   attribute status
   {
      "1"
    | "1.a"
    | "2"
    | "2.a"
    | "2.b"
    | "2.c"
    | "2.d"
    | "2.e"
    | "2.f"
    | "2.g"
    | "2.h"
    | "3"
    | "4"
    | ""
   },
   (
      (
         element publisher { ( text | name? | lb* | emph* )+ },
         element availability
         {
            element p
            {
               attribute type { "tantricRestriction" },
               ( text | emph )*
            }*,
            licence
         },
         element idno
         {
            attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID }
         },
         element note { text }*,
         element date { xsd:date }
      )
    | (
         element publisher { name+ }*,
         (
            element idno
            {
               attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID }
            }
          | element idno
            {
               attribute [http://read.84000.co/ns/1.0]kb-id { xsd:ID }
            }
         )+,
         ( element note { text } | element date { xsd:date? } )*
      )
   )
}⚓

1.56. <publisher>

<publisher> (publisher) provides the name of the organization responsible for the publication or distribution of a bibliographic item. [3.12.2.4. Imprint, Size of a Document, and Reprint Information 2.2.4. Publication, Distribution, Licensing, etc.]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.canonical (@key, @ref)
Member of
model.imprintPart
Contained by
core: bibl
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

For 84000 documents, this element should only be used in the TEI header as the child element inside the <publisherStmt>. It should look as follows for all documents:
Example
<publisher>  <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern languages, and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element publisher { att.canonical.attributes, macro.phraseSeq }⚓

1.57. <q>

<q> (quoted) contains material which is distinguished from the surrounding text as a block quote [3.3.3. Quotation]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
source Currently used in knowledgebase files to identify the milestone of a quotation from a separate translation file. Eventually we will workout how to pull the text so if the translation gets updated we won't need to update the knowledgebase article.
Status Optional
Member of
model.common model.hiLike paragraph section-content
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note p ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

84000 decuments uses the <q> element to set off a section of text to appear as a block quote in the web display.
Example For example, in The Play in Full, Toh 95, a two paragraphs from the body of the text are quoted in the introduction. Here they are placed within a <q> element to set them apart as a block quote.
<q>  <p tid="9"> “Blessed One, there is an extensive collection of discourses on the    Dharma that bears the name <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Lalitavistara</title> (<title xml:lang="en">The Play in Full</title>). This teaching illuminates the basic    virtues of the bodhisattvas, showing how the Bodhisattva descended from the    sublime palace in the Heaven of Joy, intentionally entered the womb, and sojourned    in the womb. It shows the power of the place where he was born to a noble family,    and how he surpassed others through all the superior special qualities that he    demonstrated through his actions as a youth. It shows his many unique qualities,    such as his skills in arts, crafts, writing, arithmetic, calculations, astrology,    fencing, archery, feats of physical strength, and wrestling, demonstrating his    superiority to all others in these areas. It shows how he enjoyed his retinue of    consorts and the pleasures of his kingdom. </p>  <p tid="10"> “This teaching proclaims how he attained the result brought about by    the concordant cause of all the bodhisattva activities, showing how he manifested    as a bodhisattva and destroyed the legions of Māra. It explains the ten powers,    the fourfold fearlessness, and the other innumerable qualities of a thus-gone one,    and presents the infinite teachings taught by the thus-gone ones of times past.”  </p> </q>
(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.specialPara"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element q { attribute source { text }?, macro.specialPara }⚓

1.58. <ref>

<ref> (reference) defines a reference to another location, possibly modified by additional text or comment. [3.7. Simple Links and Cross-References 16.1. Links]
Module core
Attributes Attributes  att.cReferencing (@cRef) att.internetMedia (@mimeType) att.pointing (@target) att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id)
rend (rendition) Identifies how this reference will be displayed in the reading room.
Derived from att.global.rendition
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.word separated by whitespace
Note

If it has the value "hidden" it will not be displayed in the reading room. This is useful if these references are unnecessary and would be excessive for the typical reader, but should be embedded in the text for the purposes of research. For example, some of the folio refs for the Sanskrit in Toh. 11 are hidden in this way, but there is a note about their availability in the text's introduction. See the example below.

The value "pending" is only used for references to be linked to other 84000 texts that are not yet published. The URL to the page of the unpublished texts should still be applied to the @target attribute of the <ref>, e.g., target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh9999.html" But the link will not become active until the @rend="pending" is removed. This @target needs to be added so that the ref will be flagged at the time the unpublished text is published. Furthermore, if the reference points to a particular page in the unpublished text, e.g., a folio number, this should be added as an inst attribute so that the appropriate milestone can be located and added to the URL at the time the text is published. See example below.

The value "blank" is used if the corresponding folio in the eKangyur is blank. This should not be linked in the Reading Room view, and a note should be added to the grayed out reference, e.g., "This folio of the Degé Kangyur is blank." See for example Toh 287.
type Identifies the type of a reference
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
bampo
sanskrit
chinese
volume
folio
Note

Typically when folio references are made, they refer to the folio number found within the Dege; however, occasionally the translators may provide bampo reference numbers or folio/page numbers from other language sources and these should be indicated with a type attribute to distinguish them from the Dege folio references. When a text spans two or more volumes, there should be a <type="volume" cRef="V_"/> at the beginning of the new volume.
key Identifies the Toh. number of the text to which a folio reference is linked to.
Status Optional
Note

This is used for texts for which there are multiple copies found in the Kangyur. Usually, if the texts are identical but have different folio numbers, we will just use one TEI file for both texts, but the web display will show the appropriate folio references according to key attribute found within the <ref> element. See the example below.
work Identifies which work the reference is referring to.
Status Optional
Note

This attribute is needed for Kangyur (or Tengyur) folio references that do not refer to the default--for the Kangyur this is the eKangyur (UT4CZ5369). All Kangyur folio references should have a cRef ("canonical reference") attribute. In the reading room, <ref>s will by default link to the eKangyur, so the work attribute is needed or else the parser will erroneously link to that folio in the eKangyur according to the cRef. When the work attribute is present, the parser will create a link to that work or leave the reference unlinked if the alternate work in not in the database.
page Specifies which page index for the linked eKangyur when the index is irregular.
Status Optional
Note

Only to be used with irregular ref order. Further Documentation to be added shortly.
inst Provides instructions (typically just the folio number) for finding the URL of the specific milestone to be linked when the target of a pending unpublished text is published.
Status Optional
Note

When a link is made to an unpublished 84000 text using @rend="pending", if that reference points to a specific folio reference then that should be indicated in the inst attribute with the value of the folio number, e.g., inst="F.100.a". When the target text is published, this specific milestone needs to be manually located by the markup editor, and the inst attribute may then be removed. Note that any brief statement of additional instructions for finding the appropriate milestone can be added to the value, for example, inst="F.100.a-speech by so and so...". If there is no specific page number, but the reference just links to the front page of the text, then do not use the inst attribute.
Member of
model.ptrLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

The are three uses for the <ref> element in 84000 texts:
Example First, most commonly, the <ref> element is used to mark all folio references and bampo references in the text that correspond to the physical Dege pages. The actual reference number should be placed in the cRef attribute. This should always follow the format: F.[folio number].["a" for the recto (front) side or "b" for the verso (back) side], for example "F.82.b". Bampo references should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "bampo" and follow the format "B[bampo number]", for example:
<p tid="81">  <ref cRef="F.1.b" type="folio"/>  <ref cRef="B1" type="bampo"/> I pay homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas. <!--...--> </p>
Example Folio/page reference numbers referring to additional language sources should be marked as such with the @type attribute. If there are a lot of these in order to distinguish these from the square brackets of the Tibetan refs, curly brackets will need to be used instead. since the @cRef attribute will automatically display square ones, the reference should be placed with in the node and the @cRef should not be used:
<p tid="81">  <ref cRef="F.1.b" type="folio"/>  <ref type="sanskrit">{S1}</ref>  <ref type="chinese">{C1}</ref> I pay homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas. <!--...--> </p>
Example Note, there are some texts that are duplicated in multiple sections of the Kangyur. For example The Prophecy of Sri_Mahadevi is found twice in the Kangyur as Toh. 193 and 739. Theses are both word for word exactly the same, but the folio references are going to be different for each duplicate version of the text. So in this situation we just use one TEI file, "061-014_toh193,739" but the folio references are differentiated with the key attribute which will relate each individual <ref> to the corresponding key that is declared within that version's <bibl> element found in the TEI's initial <sourceDesc>. For example, in 061-014_toh193,739's <sourceDesc>:
<teiHeader> <!--...-->  <sourceDesc>   <bibl key="toh193" type="text">    <ref>Toh 193</ref>    <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 246.a–250.b</biblScope>    <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>    <location count-pages="10"     work="UT4CZ5369">     <volume end-page="500" number="61"      start-page="491"/>    </location>    <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14668"/>    <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC11815"     work="W22084"/>   </bibl>   <bibl key="toh739" type="text">    <ref>Toh 739</ref>    <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 94 (rgyud ’bum, tsha), folios        230.a–234.b</biblScope>    <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>    <location count-pages="10"     work="UT4CZ5369">     <volume end-page="468" number="94"      start-page="459"/>    </location>    <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC21415"/>    <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC12480"     work="W22084"/>   </bibl>  </sourceDesc> <!--...--> </teiHeader> <!--...--> <body> <!--...-->  <p tid="9">   <ref cRef="F.246.a" key="toh193"    type="folio"/>   <ref cRef="F.230.a" key="toh739"    type="folio"/> Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. </p> <!--...--> </body>
Now the parser will only display the appropriate folio references, e.g., when you click on Toh. 193 it will show the references for Toh. 193 but not those for 739 and vice-versa.
Example The <ref> element is also used to create links in the Reading Room to other 84000 published texts or other websites. The web address entered in to the value of the target attribute. Note that in-text links should not be made with <ref>s but with the <ptr> element instead. Any links to 84000 that are not yet published can be made with a coded comment <!--Reference Toh ####-->, which will be retrieved and applied when the future text is published. See Appendix B.4 Cross References for more details.
<note index="586" place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-1485"> Unidentified Indian musical instrument. It appears in two lists of instruments in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Lalita­vistara­sūtra</title> (see <title xml:lang="en">The Play    in Full</title>  <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-973">15.39</ref> <!--toh. 95--> and <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-1001">15.67</ref> <!--toh. 95-->) with a stringed instrument preceding and following it, but some recent Tibetan-English dictionaries have “cymbals.”</note>
Example A single <ref> element is also entered into the source description <sourceDesc> in the TEI header, as a child of the <bibl> element to identify the Toh. number of the given text:
<sourceDesc>  <bibl>   <ref>Toh 194</ref>   <biblScope> Degé Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 250.b – 251.a</biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Schematron
<s:report test="@target and @cRef">Only one of the attributes @target' and @cRef' may be supplied on <s:name/> </s:report>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element ref
{
   att.cReferencing.attributes,
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   att.internetMedia.attributes,
   att.pointing.attributes,
   attribute rend { list { + } }?,
   attribute type { "bampo" | "sanskrit" | "chinese" | "volume" | "folio" }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   attribute work { text }?,
   attribute page { text }?,
   attribute inst { text }?,
   macro.paraContent
}⚓

1.59. <row>

<row> (row) contains one row of a table. [14.1.1. TEI Tables]
Module figures
Attributes Attributes
role (role) indicates the kind of information held in this cell or in each cell of this row.
Derived from att.tableDecoration
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
label
labelling or descriptive information only.
data
data values. [Default]
Contained by
figures: table
May contain
