figures: cell
Note

Represents a particular row contained within a <table>. The row itself contains a series of <cell>s as they appear from left to right. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent <cell>s are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a <row> contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child <cell>s will be considered to be "label"s as well.

For further details on tables see Topics: Appendix B.5 Tables.
Example
<row>  <cell role="label">161–63</cell>  <cell role="label">cakra</cell>  <cell>secret</cell>  <cell>navel</cell>  <cell>heart</cell>  <cell>throat</cell>  <cell>forehead</cell>  <cell>crown</cell> </row>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="cell"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="1"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element row { attribute role { "label" | "data" }?, cell+ }⚓

1.60. <sourceDesc>

<sourceDesc> (source description) describes the source(s) from which an electronic text was derived or generated, typically a bibliographic description in the case of a digitized text, or a phrase such as "born digital" for a text which has no previous existence. [2.2.7. The Source Description]
Module header
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain
core: biblScope p
derived-module-NewODD: link location
character data
Note

The <sourceDesc> is located in the TEI header and contains a single <bibl> element giving a description of the source text. All of this information will be displayed on the title page in the reading room.
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh83" type="text">   <ref>Toh 83</ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios 71.a–94.b</biblScope> <!--series>Degé Kangyur</series>, <biblScope>vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha)</biblScope>, <citedRange>folios 71a–94a</citedRange-->   <author role="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author>   <author role="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author>   <author role="translatorTib">Yeshé Dé</author>   <location count-pages="48"    work="UT4CZ5369">    <volume end-page="188" number="44"     start-page="141"/>   </location>   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/>   <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC11626"    work="W22084"/>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>textchaptertranslatorTibSa-LtnBo-LtnPi-LtnZh-LtnboenzhreviserSa-LtnBo-LtnPi-LtnZh-Ltnboenzh</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element sourceDesc
{
   (
      element bibl
      {
         attribute key { string },
         attribute type { "text" | "chapter" },
         element ref { text, element extension { text }* },
         biblScope,
         element series { string }?,
         element citedRange { string }?,
         (
            element author
            {
               attribute role { "translatorTib" }?,
               attribute key { text }?,
               attribute ref { text }?,
               attribute xml:lang
               {
                  "Sa-Ltn"
                | "Bo-Ltn"
                | "Pi-Ltn"
                | "Zh-Ltn"
                | "bo"
                | "en"
                | "zh"
               }?,
               text
            }
          | element editor
            {
               attribute role { "reviser" }?,
               attribute ref { text }?,
               attribute revision { text }?,
               attribute xml:lang
               {
                  "Sa-Ltn"
                | "Bo-Ltn"
                | "Pi-Ltn"
                | "Zh-Ltn"
                | "bo"
                | "en"
                | "zh"
               }?,
               text
            }
         )*,
         location,
         element idno
         {
            attribute parent-id { text },
            attribute work { text }?
         },
         element idno { attribute source-id { text }, attribute work { text } }?
      }+
    | p
   ),
   link?
}⚓

1.61. <sponsor>

<sponsor> States the sponsor of a the 84000 translation.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributes
ref Matches the sponsor to the database
Status Optional
Contained by
header: titleStmt
May contain Character data only
Note

Denotes the sponsor of the 84000 translation; if there is one it should be listed in the <titleStmt> after any <author>s, <editor>s, or <consultant>s.
Example
<titleStmt>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">bsod nams thams cad bsdus pa’i ting nge    ’dzin</title> <!--...list of other titles...-->  <author ref="translators.xml#team-9"   role="translatorMain">Translated by the    Dharmachakra Translation Committee<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of    84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-46"   role="translatorEng">Khenpo Trokpa    Tulku</author>  <editor role="projectEditor">Andreas Doctor</editor>  <consultant role="advisor">Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche</consultant>  <sponsor ref="sponsors.xml#sponsor-999">anonymous</sponsor> </titleStmt>
Content model 
<content>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element sponsor { attribute ref { text }?, text? }⚓

1.62. <table>

<table> (table) contains text displayed in tabular form, in rows and columns. [14.1.1. TEI Tables]
Module figures
Attributes Attributes  att.typed (@type)
tid Numbers the table in the text along with and in the same manner as paragraph, <p>; and line group, <l>, elements.
Status Required
rend Modifies table's display in the HTML
Status Optional
Legal values are:
firstcol-30pc
Renders the first column with 30% width
firstcol-40pc
Renders the first column with 40% width
firstcol-50pc
Renders the first column with 50% width
Member of
model.listLike section-content
Contained by
core: desc item l note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: graphic head lb media milestone note
figures: row
textstructure: trailer
Note

Tables contains an optional heading and a series of <row>s. Generally the style of the table will be generated automatically by the parser and the width of each column and row will be determined by the longest string of text in that column or row; however if the default table is rendered ineloquently in the HTML, as an option the rend attribute may be used to define the width of the first column: @rend="firstcol-30pc" will set the width of the first column to 30% of the width of the full table, "firstcol-40pc" and "firstcol-50pc" will set it to 40% and 50% respectively. This was used, for example, in the appendix of Toh 307 to display the tables there with a consistent column width in relation to each other.

Currently no type is being used, but this may be added to the schema and documentation when it becomes necessary. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent <cell>s are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a <row> contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child <cell>s will be considered to be "label"s as well.

Note, when marking up <table>s the markup editor should check that the table renders properly in the reading room's web display. In addition, the table needs to be checked in the ebook display as well. This can be done by adding the code: ?viewmode=epub to the very end of the url address on the utilities page. In truth, the tables are not compatible with the ebook format, so the parser will instead display them as a bulleted list. The information in this list should be presented in a complete and eloquently readable way, otherwise the parser should be updated.

For further details on tables see Topics: Appendix B.5 Tables.
Example Here is an example from Toh 361, notice that <note>s may be added at the foot of the <table> outside of any <row>s, but still wrapped within the <table>.
<table tid="111">  <head type="table">Deity Families</head>  <row role="label">   <cell>Verses</cell>   <cell>Aspect</cell>   <cell>Vajrasattva</cell>   <cell>Mahāsattva</cell>   <cell>Bodhisattva</cell>   <cell>Samayasattva</cell>   <cell>Vajrayoga</cell>   <cell>Kālacakra</cell>  </row>  <row>   <cell role="label">161–63</cell>   <cell role="label">cakra</cell>   <cell>secret</cell>   <cell>navel</cell>   <cell>heart</cell>   <cell>throat</cell>   <cell>forehead</cell>   <cell>crown</cell>  </row>  <row>   <cell role="label">164–69</cell>   <cell role="label">purifies*</cell>   <cell>threefold existence</cell>   <cell>passion</cell>   <cell>hatred</cell>   <cell>delusion</cell>   <cell>anger</cell>   <cell>attachment</cell>  </row>  <note>* Tentative interpretation.</note> </table>
(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Content model 
<content>
 <sequence maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
  <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
   minOccurs="0">
   <classRef key="model.headLike"/>
   <classRef key="model.global"/>
  </alternate>
  <alternate maxOccurs="1" minOccurs="1">
   <sequence maxOccurs="unbounded"
    minOccurs="1">
    <elementRef key="row"/>
    <classRef key="model.global"
     maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
   </sequence>
   <sequence maxOccurs="unbounded"
    minOccurs="1">
    <classRef key="model.graphicLike"/>
    <classRef key="model.global"
     maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
   </sequence>
  </alternate>
  <sequence maxOccurs="unbounded"
   minOccurs="0">
   <classRef key="model.divBottom"/>
   <classRef key="model.global"
    maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
  </sequence>
 </sequence>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element table
{
   att.typed.attributes,
   attribute tid { text },
   attribute rend { "firstcol-30pc" | "firstcol-40pc" | "firstcol-50pc" }?,
   (
      ( model.headLike | model.global )*,
      ( ( row, model.global* )+ | ( model.graphicLike, model.global* )+ ),
      ( model.divBottom, model.global* )*
   )
}⚓

1.63. <taxonomy>

<taxonomy> (taxonomy) defines a typology either implicitly, by means of a bibliographic citation, or explicitly by a structured taxonomy. [2.3.7. The Classification Declaration]
Module header
Attributes Attributes  att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
Contained by
header: classDecl
May contain
header: category
Note

Nested taxonomies are common in many fields, so the <taxonomy> element can be nested.
Example
<taxonomy xml:id="tax.b">  <bibl>Brown Corpus</bibl>  <category xml:id="tax.b.a">   <catDesc>Press Reportage</catDesc>   <category xml:id="tax.b.a1">    <catDesc>Daily</catDesc>   </category>   <category xml:id="tax.b.a2">    <catDesc>Sunday</catDesc>   </category>   <category xml:id="tax.b.a3">    <catDesc>National</catDesc>   </category>   <category xml:id="tax.b.a4">    <catDesc>Provincial</catDesc>   </category>   <category xml:id="tax.b.a5">    <catDesc>Political</catDesc>   </category>   <category xml:id="tax.b.a6">    <catDesc>Sports</catDesc>   </category>  </category>  <category xml:id="tax.b.d">   <catDesc>Religion</catDesc>   <category xml:id="tax.b.d1">    <catDesc>Books</catDesc>   </category>   <category xml:id="tax.b.d2">    <catDesc>Periodicals and tracts</catDesc>   </category>  </category> </taxonomy>
Example
<taxonomy>  <category xml:id="literature">   <catDesc>Literature</catDesc>   <category xml:id="poetry">    <catDesc>Poetry</catDesc>    <category xml:id="sonnet">     <catDesc>Sonnet</catDesc>     <category xml:id="shakesSonnet">      <catDesc>Shakespearean Sonnet</catDesc>     </category>     <category xml:id="petraSonnet">      <catDesc>Petrarchan Sonnet</catDesc>     </category>    </category>    <category xml:id="haiku">     <catDesc>Haiku</catDesc>    </category>   </category>   <category xml:id="drama">    <catDesc>Drama</catDesc>   </category>  </category>  <category xml:id="meter">   <catDesc>Metrical Categories</catDesc>   <category xml:id="feet">    <catDesc>Metrical Feet</catDesc>    <category xml:id="iambic">     <catDesc>Iambic</catDesc>    </category>    <category xml:id="trochaic">     <catDesc>trochaic</catDesc>    </category>   </category>   <category xml:id="feetNumber">    <catDesc>Number of feet</catDesc>    <category xml:id="pentameter">     <catDesc>>Pentameter</catDesc>    </category>    <category xml:id="tetrameter">     <catDesc>>Tetrameter</catDesc>    </category>   </category>  </category> </taxonomy> <!-- elsewhere in document --> <lg ana="#shakesSonnet #iambic #pentameter">  <l>Shall I compare thee to a summer's day</l> <!-- ... --> </lg>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="category"
  maxOccurs="unbounded" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element taxonomy { att.global.attributes, category* }⚓

1.64. <teiHeader>

<teiHeader> (TEI header) supplies descriptive and declarative metadata associated with a digital resource or set of resources. [2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module header
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
header: encodingDesc fileDesc profileDesc
Note

The following description from the University of Michigan is available as part of a PDF at http://www.lib.umich.edu/files/departments/dpp/20101113_06.pdf "The TEI header (<teiHeader>) is the ‘virtual title page’ of a TEI document. It contains meta data (information about the TEI document). <teiHeader> is the first, mandatory child element of the root <TEI> element; therefore, it appears at the top (‘at the head’) of every TEI document. The header meta data provides: 1. bibliographic record of the electronic text as well as the source from which the electronic text is derived 2. documentation of the encoding and editorial principles used in tagging the electronic text 3. terms for indexing, searching, and retrieval 4. a record of changes made to the electronic document. The header contains many specialised elements not found anywhere in the ‘body’ of a TEI document (that is, everything after the close of <teiHeader>). These elements allow for highly structured descriptions of the document. Many parts of the header allow free-form prose descriptions as an alternative to the highly structured descriptions. Few header elements are required, so a header can be quite minimal."
Example
<teiHeader>  <fileDesc>   <titleStmt>    <title type="mainTitle"     xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus        pa</title>    <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">ཚོང་དཔོན་བཟང་སྐྱོང་གིས་ཞུས་པ།</title>    <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Questions of Bhadrapāla the        Merchant</title>    <title type="mainTitle"     xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bhadra­pāla­śreṣṭhi­paripṛcchā</title>    <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་ཚོང་དཔོན་བཟང་སྐྱོང་གིས་ཞུས་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title>    <title type="longTitle"     xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa tshong dpon bzang skyong gis        zhus pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen po’i mdo</title>    <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “The Questions of        Bhadrapāla the Merchant”</title>    <title type="longTitle"     xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­bhadra­pāla­śreṣṭhi­paripṛcchā­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>    <author role="translatorMain">Translated by Karen Liljenberg and Ulrich        Pagel<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words        of the Buddha.</author>    <author role="translatorEng">Karen Liljenberg</author>    <author role="translatorEng">Ulrich Pagel</author>   </titleStmt>   <editionStmt>    <edition>v 1.3 <date>2017</date>    </edition>   </editionStmt>   <publicationStmt status="1">    <publisher>     <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit        initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddha’s words into modern        languages, and to make them available to everyone. </publisher>    <availability>     <licence>      <graphic url="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/>      <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC            BY-NC-ND (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It            may be copied or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and            not for commercial advantage or personal compensation. For full details,            see the Creative Commons license.</p>     </licence>    </availability>    <idno xml:id="UT22084-044-003"/>    <note>An early mistake in the assigning of UT numbers within the 84000 project        means that these ids diverge slightly from the standard logic.</note>    <date>2017-02-25</date>   </publicationStmt>   <sourceDesc>    <bibl key="toh83" type="text">     <ref>Toh 83</ref>     <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios 71.a–94.b</biblScope> <!--series>Degé Kangyur</series>, <biblScope>vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha)</biblScope>, <citedRange>folios 71a–94a</citedRange-->     <author role="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author>     <author role="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author>     <author role="translatorTib">Yeshé Dé</author>     <location count-pages="48"      work="UT4CZ5369">      <volume end-page="188" number="44"       start-page="141"/>     </location>     <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/>     <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC11626"      work="W22084"/>    </bibl>   </sourceDesc>   <notesStmt>    <note date-time="2019-02-26T08:34:43.421Z"     type="lastUpdated" user="celso">26/02/2019 08:34:43</note>   </notesStmt>  </fileDesc> </teiHeader>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="fileDesc"/>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <elementRef key="encodingDesc"/>
  <elementRef key="profileDesc"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element teiHeader { fileDesc, ( encodingDesc | profileDesc )* }⚓

1.65. <term>

<term> (term) contains a single-word, multi-word, or symbolic designation which is regarded as a technical term. [3.4.1. Terms and Glosses]
Module core
Attributes Attributesatt.global (xml:id, @xml:lang) att.global.rendition (@rend)
type Identifies the term in terms of its relation to the glossary, or its function within the glossary.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
ignore
definition
alternative
semanticReconstruction
transliterationReconstruction
person-interlocutor
person-main-speaker
person-topical
main-subject
secondary-subject
ref (reference) For the <term> element, the @ref attribute should be used when there are three or more glossary entries with the exact same string and the instances of the term within the body of the text need to be distinguished. In such cases, the <gloss> entry should be mode="marked".
Derived from att.canonical
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor emph expan foreign gloss item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
character data
Note

In 84000 texts the <term> element is used for glossary entries or to denote the way a string within the text is to linked to the glossary by the parser. See the following examples:
Example Primarily the <term> element is used to list glossary terms in the back matter of a text. For each individual <gloss> element, which constitutes a single glossary entry, a list of several <term> elements are used (see the example below). The first <term> element, which should have no attritutes, shows the English translation of the term or the string used in for that term as it is found in the text. This first <term> element indicates to the parser which word or string of text to link to the glossary entry, and it will create a link for every instance of that term that is found in the text. The next <term> elements that follow within the <gloss> list the Wylie, Tibetan, and Sanskrit for that term, all indicated by the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate value. After that a definition is given in its own <term> element with the type="definition" attribute. Finally, if there are any alternate translations used for the term within the text that should be linked to this gloss, they are listed last each marked by type="alternative". These instances of alternative strings of text will also be linked to the glossary entry wherever they are found in the text. All of this can be seen in the first example below. For further notes about the glossary see Appendix C.
<gloss type="term"  xml:id="UT22084-046-001-2968">  <term>hearer</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"> nyan thos </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">ཉན་ཐོས།</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">śrāvaka</term>  <term type="definition">A follower of the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on    the monastic lifestyle. Also translated as "<term type="ignore">listener</term>."</term>  <term type="alternative">Listener</term> </gloss>
Example The <term> element may also be used in the text itself to alter the way a string of text is to be linked to the glossary. For example, a string of text can bypass being linked if it is placed within a <term type="ignore"> as like the following example. Alternatively, if the parent <gloss> element for an entry is given the attribute mode="marked" then it will only link to instances in the text that are contained within a <term> element. If there are three or more glossary entries of the same string, then these may be more precisely distinguished within the body of text by adding a @ref attribute pointing to the specific glossary entry to which they refer (In this situations the <gloss> entry should be mode="marked"). For more details on how the glossary functions on the web page see Appendix C.
<!--A Term is bypassed from being linked within the text with the <term type="ignore"> element.--> Indeed he is a Dharma king who <term type="ignore">guides</term> according to the Dharma. <!-- Alternatively, the gloss is given the atribute mode="marked" --> <item>  <gloss mode="marked" priority="0"   type="term" xml:id="UT22084-044-003-185">   <term>appropriate</term>   <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">len pa </term>   <term xml:lang="bo">ལེན་པ་</term>   <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ādāna</term>   <term type="definition">See “appropriation.”</term>   <term type="alternative">appropriated</term>  </gloss> </item> <!-- Only marked up instances in the text will be highlighted --> <p tid="38"> Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, <term>appropriate</term> another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it <term>appropriate</term> different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?” </p>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element term
{
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute type
   {
      "ignore"
    | "definition"
    | "alternative"
    | "semanticReconstruction"
    | "transliterationReconstruction"
    | "person-interlocutor"
    | "person-main-speaker"
    | "person-topical"
    | "main-subject"
    | "secondary-subject"
   }?,
   attribute ref { list { + } }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}⚓

1.66. <text>

<text> (text) contains a single text of any kind, whether unitary or composite, for example a poem or drama, a collection of essays, a novel, a dictionary, or a corpus sample. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
textstructure: back body front
Note

In the case of the 84000 translations, the <text> element is opened right below the <teiHeader> element. It includes within it the translated work, as well as the front and back matter.
Example
<text>  <front>   <div type="summary"/> <!--... etc.-->  </front>  <body/>  <back/> </text>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="front"/>
 <elementRef key="body" minOccurs="0"/>
 <elementRef key="back" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element text { front, body?, back? }⚓

1.67. <textClass>

<textClass> (text classification) groups information which describes the nature or topic of a text in terms of a standard classification scheme, thesaurus, etc. [2.4.3. The Text Classification]
Module header
Contained by
header: profileDesc
May contain
header: catRef keywords
Example
<taxonomy>  <category xml:id="acprose">   <catDesc>Academic prose</catDesc>  </category> <!-- other categories here --> </taxonomy> <!-- ... --> <textClass>  <catRef target="#acprose"/>  <classCode scheme="http://www.udcc.org">001.9</classCode>  <keywords scheme="http://authorities.loc.gov">   <list>    <item>End of the world</item>    <item>History - philosophy</item>   </list>  </keywords> </textClass>
Content model 
<content>
 <elementRef key="keywords" minOccurs="0"/>
 <elementRef key="catRef" minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element textClass { keywords?, catRef? }⚓

1.68. <title>

<title> (title) contains a title for any kind of work. [3.12.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2.5. The Series Statement]
Module core
Attributes Attributes
xml:lang
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan written in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti written in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi written in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese written in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada written in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali written in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit written in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit written in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil written in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai written in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese written in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
cs
Czech
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
la
Latin
ru
Russian
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
ja
Japanese in Japanese script (Use Ja-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic written in Roman script.
mixed
This element contains strings mixed with different languages. They will be differentiated within this element by <foreign> tags, or left unwrapped if they are the default English.
rend (rendition) @rend is used in our TEI specifically for the value "reconstruction," when a Sa-Ltn title is reconstructed from the Tibetan.
Derived from att.global.rendition
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.word separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
reconstruction
A Sanskrit, "Sa-Ltn" title which is reconstructed from Tibetan.
type classifies the title according to the TBRC typology. classifies the title according to the 84000 typology.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
mainTitle
longTitle
otherTitle
Note

This attribute is provided for convenience in analysing titles and processing them according to their type; where such specialized processing is not necessary, there is no need for such analysis, and the entire title, including subtitles and any parallel titles, may be enclosed within a single <title> element.
group Allows the grouping multiple titles together as equivalents in different languages, e.g. short title, long title, etc...
Status Optional
Member of
bibl-section-content head-content model.emphLike paragraph
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign head item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt titleStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

The title tag can be used throughout the TEI document. In the case of the header, it appears with type attributes with values of "mainTitle" or "longTitle" and the language attributes "bo", "eng", "Sa-Ltn", "Bo-Ltn", or "zh" depending on if it is in Tibetan, English, Sanskrit, Wylie, or Chinese. In the case of the header appearance, title denotes the title of the translated work.
Example Below is an example from the <titleStmt> in the teiHeader in Toh 127:
<title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">ting nge ’dzin gyi rgyal po’i mdo</title> <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་གྱི་རྒྱལ་པོའི་མདོ།</title> <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The King of Samādhis Sūtra</title> <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Samādhi­rāja­sūtra</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་ཆོས་ཐམས་ཅད་ཀྱི་རང་བཞིན་མཉམ་པ་ཉིད་རྣམ་པར་སྤྲོས་པ་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་གྱི་རྒྱལ་པོ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin mnyam pa nyid rnam par spros pa ting nge ’dzin gyi rgyal po zhes bya ba theg pa chen po’i mdo</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Mahāyāna Sūtra “The King of Samādhis, the Revealed Equality of the Nature of All Phenomena”</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­sarva­dharma­svabhāva­samatāvipañcita­samādhi­rāja­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title> <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh">三摩地王經</title>
Example When the title tag is used in the front or body or back matter, it can denote the title of any published work, and will be displayed italicized in the web display. All <title> should have a xml:lan attribute with the value appropriate to the language used. Below is an example from Toh 544, from the introduction.
... lesser-known forms of Mañjuśrī, Siddhaikavīra is also the subject of four sādhanas in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Sādhanamālā</title> (Bhattacharyya 1968) where some of his descriptions correspond in detail to the...
Example It should also be used for bibliography entries, for example from Toh 127:
<bibl xml:id="UT22084-055-001-4768">Candrakīrti. <title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dbu ma la    ’jug pa</title> (<title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Madhyamakāvatāra</title>) [<title xml:lang="en">Entering the Middle Way</title>]. Toh 3861, Degé Tengyur vol. 204 (dbu ma ’a), folios 201.b–219.a.</bibl>
Content model 
<content>
 <macroRef key="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element title
{
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "Bo-Ltn"
    | "Gu-Ltn"
    | "Hi-Ltn"
    | "Ja-Ltn"
    | "Kn-Ltn"
    | "Mr-Ltn"
    | "Mn-Ltn"
    | "Pi-Ltn"
    | "Pra-Ltn"
    | "Sa-Ltn"
    | "Ta-Ltn"
    | "Th-Ltn"
    | "Zh-Ltn"
    | "bo"
    | "cs"
    | "de"
    | "el"
    | "en"
    | "fr"
    | "it"
    | "la"
    | "ru"
    | "zh"
    | "ja"
    | "middle_indic-Ltn"
    | "mixed"
   },
   attribute rend { list { "reconstruction"+ } }?,
   attribute type { "mainTitle" | "longTitle" | "otherTitle" }?,
   attribute group { text }?,
   macro.paraContent
}⚓

1.69. <titleStmt>

<titleStmt> (title statement) groups information about the title of a work and those responsible for its content. [2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2. The File Description]
Module header
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain
core: editor lb title
derived-module-NewODD: consultant sponsor
character data
Note

Appears once in the <teiHeader>. It should contain the nine title variations for each text. This should include four "mainTitle"s and four "longTitle"s (for Wylie, Tibetan, English, and Sanskrit); and one "otherTitle" (for Chinese). If any of these nine default titles are not present, they should contain an empty element as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>. It may contain additional title(s) from other sources, but these should be marked as type="otherTitle". Following the titles, there needs to be <author> elements given for each person or group involved in the translation of the text (these authors are the translators of the English, not the original translators of the Tibetan who will be listed later on in the <sourceDesc>). After the <author>s, any <editor>s, <consultant>s, or <sponsor>s may be listed in that order. For these latter three, DO NOT leave empty elements as placeholders if they are not present.
Example
<titleStmt>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">bsod nams thams cad bsdus pa’i ting nge    ’dzin</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">བསོད་ནམས་ཐམས་ཅད་བསྡུས་པའི་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན།</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Absorption That Encapsulates All    Merit</title>  <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Sarvapuṇya­samuccaya­samādhi</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་བསོད་ནམས་ཐམས་ཅད་བསྡུས་པའི་ཏིང་ངེ་འཛིན་ཅེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa bsod nams thams cad bsdus pa’i    ting nge ’dzin ces bya ba theg pa chen po’i mdo</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “The Absorption That    Encapsulates All Merit”</title>  <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­sarva­puṇya­samuccaya­samādhi­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title>  <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh">集一切福德三昧經</title>  <author ref="translators.xml#team-9"   role="translatorMain">Translated by the    Dharmachakra Translation Committee<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of    84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-40"   role="translatorEng"/>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-78"   role="translatorEng"/>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-50"   role="translatorEng"/>  <author ref="translators.xml#translator-46"   role="translatorEng">Khenpo Trokpa    Tulku</author>  <editor role="projectEditor">Andreas Doctor</editor>  <consultant role="advisor">Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche</consultant>  <sponsor ref="sponsors.xml#sponsor-999">anonymous</sponsor> </titleStmt>
(See how this example is displayed in reading room.)
Content model 
<content>translatorMaintranslatorEngpreface</content>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element titleStmt
{
   title*,
   (
      element author
      {
         attribute role { "translatorMain" },
         attribute ref { text }?,
         ( text | lb )*
      }?
    | element author
      {
         attribute role { "translatorEng" | "preface" },
         attribute ref { text }?,
         text*
      }*
    | editor*
    | consultant*
    | sponsor*
   )*
}⚓

1.70. <trailer>

<trailer> contains a closing title or footer appearing at the end of a division of a text. [4.2.4. Content of Textual Divisions 4.2. Elements Common to All Divisions]
Module textstructure
Attributes Attributes  att.placement (@place)
tid Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text. It is also applicable to trailers which replace the <p> element.
Status Required
Member of
model.divBottomPart section-content
Contained by
figures: table
textstructure: back body div front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
figures: table
header: idno
character data
Note

The trailer should be used for the last sentence of a chapter or text that declares it is the end of that chapter or text. This doesn't include colophons. This element functions like the paragraph, <p>, element and may require a milestone preceding it, and the tid attribute. In the final web display the trailer will be italicized. All of the trailers will be separated by a space and italicized in their entirety by the parser, so any <title>s that appear in the trailer should be giving curled quotations marks to indicate that it is a title.
Example
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-080-015-44"/> <trailer tid="1938">This concludes the first chapter, the introduction to the tantra, in the glorious Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa tantra called “<title xml:lang="en">The    Sole Hero</title>.”</trailer>
Example Like the <p> element, the <trailer> may contain <note>s or <ref>s, as like the following example.
<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-512"/> <trailer tid="3265">Conclusion of the third chapter, “Praise of the Buddha’s Qualities.” <note index="248" place="end"   xml:id="UT22084-055-001-513"> According to    the commentary, the title of this chapter is “Mindfulness of the Buddha’s    Qualities.”</note>  <ref cRef="B2" type="bampo"/> </trailer>
(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Content model 
<content/>
    ⚓
Schema Declaration 
element trailer
{
   att.placement.attributes,
   attribute tid { text },
   (
      text
    | lg
    | ref-canonical
    | ref-other
    | model.gLike
    | model.phrase
    | model.inter
    | model.lLike
    | model.global
   )*
}⚓

1.71. <volume>

<volume> Used in the location to define the volume(s) in which the text is located.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes Attributes
number
Status Required
start-page
Status Required
end-page
Status Required
Contained by
derived-module-NewODD: location
May contain Empty element
Note

Identifies the volume of the text. This element is key for determining the alignment of the folio references linked to the eKangyur.
Example
<sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh11" type="text"> <!--...-->   <location count-pages="788"    work="UT4CZ5369">    <volume end-page="593" number="31"     start-page="414"/>    <volume end-page="611" number="32"     start-page="2"/>   </location> <!--...-->  </bibl> </sourceDesc>

2. Model classes

2.1. model.attributable

model.attributable groups elements that contain a word or phrase that can be attributed to a source. [3.3.3. Quotation 4.3.2. Floating Texts]
Module tei
Used by
macro.phraseSeq model.inter
Members model.quoteLike

2.2. model.biblLike

model.biblLike groups elements containing a bibliographic description. [3.12. Bibliographic Citations and References]
Module tei
Used by
model.inter
Members bibl

2.3. model.biblPart

model.biblPart groups elements which represent components of a bibliographic description. [3.12. Bibliographic Citations and References]
Module tei
Used by
bibl
Members model.imprintPart [biblScope publisher] model.respLike [author editor] bibl edition

2.4. model.common

model.common groups common chunk- and inter-level elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
div
Members model.divPart [model.lLike [l] model.pLike [p] lg] model.inter [model.attributable [model.quoteLike] model.biblLike [bibl] model.egLike model.labelLike [desc label] model.listLike [list table] model.oddDecl model.stageLike] q
Note

This class defines the set of chunk- and inter-level elements; it is used in many content models, including those for textual divisions.

2.5. model.dateLike

model.dateLike groups elements containing temporal expressions. [3.6.4. Dates and Times 13.4. Dates]
Module tei
Used by
model.pPart.data
Members date

2.6. model.descLike

model.descLike groups elements which contain a description of their function.
Module tei
Used by
media
Members desc

2.7. model.divBottom

model.divBottom groups elements appearing at the end of a text division. [4.2. Elements Common to All Divisions]
Module tei
Used by
div table
Members model.divBottomPart [trailer] model.divWrapper

2.8. model.divBottomPart

model.divBottomPart groups elements which can occur only at the end of a text division. [4.6. Title Pages]
Module tei
Used by
model.divBottom
Members trailer

2.9. model.divLike

model.divLike groups elements used to represent un-numbered generic structural divisions.
Module tei
Used by
div
Members div

2.10. model.divPart

model.divPart groups paragraph-level elements appearing directly within divisions. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
macro.specialPara model.common
Members model.lLike [l] model.pLike [p] lg
Note

Note that this element class does not include members of the model.inter class, which can appear either within or between paragraph-level items.

2.11. model.divTop

model.divTop groups elements appearing at the beginning of a text division. [4.2. Elements Common to All Divisions]
Module tei
Used by
div
Members model.divTopPart [model.headLike [head]] model.divWrapper

2.12. model.divTopPart

model.divTopPart groups elements which can occur only at the beginning of a text division. [4.6. Title Pages]
Module tei
Used by
model.divTop
Members model.headLike [head]

2.13. model.emphLike

model.emphLike groups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct and to which a specific function can be attributed. [3.3. Highlighting and Quotation]
Module tei
Used by
model.highlighted model.limitedPhrase
Members distinct emph foreign gloss term title

2.14. model.encodingDescPart

model.encodingDescPart groups elements which may be used inside <encodingDesc> and appear multiple times.
Module tei
Used by
encodingDesc
Members classDecl

2.15. model.global

model.global groups elements which may appear at any point within a TEI text. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
bibl div l macro.paraContent macro.phraseSeq macro.specialPara table trailer
Members model.global.edit model.global.meta model.milestoneLike [lb milestone] model.noteLike [note]

2.16. model.graphicLike

model.graphicLike groups elements containing images, formulae, and similar objects. [3.10. Graphics and Other Non-textual Components]
Module tei
Used by
model.phrase table
Members graphic media

2.17. model.headLike

model.headLike groups elements used to provide a title or heading at the start of a text division.
Module tei
Used by
model.divTopPart table
Members head

2.18. model.hiLike

model.hiLike groups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct but to which no specific function can be attributed. [3.3. Highlighting and Quotation]
Module tei
Used by
model.highlighted model.limitedPhrase
Members hi q

2.19. model.highlighted

model.highlighted groups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct. [3.3. Highlighting and Quotation]
Module tei
Used by
bibl model.phrase
Members model.emphLike [distinct emph foreign gloss term title] model.hiLike [hi q]

2.20. model.imprintPart

model.imprintPart groups the bibliographic elements which occur inside imprints. [3.12. Bibliographic Citations and References]
Module tei
Used by
model.biblPart
Members biblScope publisher

2.21. model.inter

model.inter groups elements which can appear either within or between paragraph-like elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
l macro.limitedContent macro.paraContent macro.specialPara model.common trailer
Members model.attributable [model.quoteLike] model.biblLike [bibl] model.egLike model.labelLike [desc label] model.listLike [list table] model.oddDecl model.stageLike

2.22. model.lLike

model.lLike groups elements representing metrical components such as verse lines.
Module tei
Used by
macro.paraContent model.divPart trailer
Members l

2.23. model.labelLike

model.labelLike groups elements used to gloss or explain other parts of a document.
Module tei
Used by
model.inter
Members desc label

2.24. model.limitedPhrase

model.limitedPhrase groups phrase-level elements excluding those elements primarily intended for transcription of existing sources. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
macro.limitedContent
Members model.emphLike [distinct emph foreign gloss term title] model.hiLike [hi q] model.pPart.data [model.addressLike model.dateLike [date] model.measureLike model.nameLike [model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno]] model.pPart.editorial [abbr expan] model.pPart.msdesc model.phrase.xml model.ptrLike [ptr ref]

2.25. model.listLike

model.listLike groups list-like elements. [3.8. Lists]
Module tei
Used by
model.inter
Members list table

2.26. model.milestoneLike

model.milestoneLike groups milestone-style elements used to represent reference systems. [1.3. The TEI Class System 3.11.3. Milestone Elements]
Module tei
Used by
model.global
Members lb milestone

2.27. model.nameLike

model.nameLike groups elements which name or refer to a person, place, or organization.
Module tei
Used by
model.pPart.data
Members model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno
Note

A superset of the naming elements that may appear in datelines, addresses, statements of responsibility, etc.

2.28. model.nameLike.agent

model.nameLike.agent groups elements which contain names of individuals or corporate bodies. [3.6. Names, Numbers, Dates, Abbreviations, and Addresses]
Module tei
Used by
model.nameLike
Members name
Note

This class is used in the content model of elements which reference names of people or organizations.

2.29. model.noteLike

model.noteLike groups globally-available note-like elements. [3.9. Notes, Annotation, and Indexing]
Module tei
Used by
model.global
Members note

2.30. model.pLike

model.pLike groups paragraph-like elements.
Module tei
Used by
encodingDesc model.divPart
Members p

2.31. model.pPart.data

model.pPart.data groups phrase-level elements containing names, dates, numbers, measures, and similar data. [3.6. Names, Numbers, Dates, Abbreviations, and Addresses]
Module tei
Used by
bibl model.limitedPhrase model.phrase
Members model.addressLike model.dateLike [date] model.measureLike model.nameLike [model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno]

2.32. model.pPart.edit

model.pPart.edit groups phrase-level elements for simple editorial correction and transcription. [3.5. Simple Editorial Changes]
Module tei
Used by
bibl model.phrase
Members model.pPart.editorial [abbr expan] model.pPart.transcriptional

2.33. model.pPart.editorial

model.pPart.editorial groups phrase-level elements for simple editorial interventions that may be useful both in transcribing and in authoring. [3.5. Simple Editorial Changes]
Module tei
Used by
model.limitedPhrase model.pPart.edit
Members abbr expan

2.34. model.phrase

model.phrase groups elements which can occur at the level of individual words or phrases. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
l macro.paraContent macro.phraseSeq macro.specialPara trailer
Members model.graphicLike [graphic media] model.highlighted [model.emphLike [distinct emph foreign gloss term title] model.hiLike [hi q]] model.lPart model.pPart.data [model.addressLike model.dateLike [date] model.measureLike model.nameLike [model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno]] model.pPart.edit [model.pPart.editorial [abbr expan] model.pPart.transcriptional] model.pPart.msdesc model.phrase.xml model.ptrLike [ptr ref] model.segLike model.specDescLike
Note

This class of elements can occur within paragraphs, list items, lines of verse, etc.

2.35. model.placeStateLike

model.placeStateLike groups elements which describe changing states of a place.
Module tei
Used by
model.nameLike
Members model.placeNamePart

2.36. model.ptrLike

model.ptrLike groups elements used for purposes of location and reference. [3.7. Simple Links and Cross-References]
Module tei
Used by
bibl model.limitedPhrase model.phrase
Members ptr ref

2.37. model.respLike

model.respLike groups elements which are used to indicate intellectual or other significant responsibility, for example within a bibliographic element.
Module tei
Used by
model.biblPart
Members author editor

3. Attribute classes

3.1. att.cReferencing

att.cReferencing provides an attribute which may be used to supply a canonical reference as a means of identifying the target of a pointer.
Module tei
Members ref
Attributes Attributes
cRef (canonical reference) specifies the destination of the pointer by supplying a canonical reference expressed using the scheme defined in a <refsDecl> element in the TEI header
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.text
Note

The value of cRef should be constructed so that when the algorithm for the resolution of canonical references (described in section 16.2.5. Canonical References) is applied to it the result is a valid URI reference to the intended target.

The <refsDecl> to use may be indicated with the decls attribute.

Currently these Guidelines only provide for a single canonical reference to be encoded on any given <ptr> element.

3.2. att.canonical

att.canonical provides attributes which can be used to associate a representation such as a name or title with canonical information about the object being named or referenced. [13.1.1. Linking Names and Their Referents]
Module tei
Members att.naming[author editor] catDesc date publisher term
Attributes Attributes
key provides an externally-defined means of identifying the entity (or entities) being named, using a coded value of some kind.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.text
<author>  <name key="name 427308"   type="organisation">[New Zealand Parliament, Legislative Council]</name> </author>
<author>  <name key="Hugo, Victor (1802-1885)"   ref="http://www.idref.fr/026927608">Victor Hugo</name> </author>
Note

The value may be a unique identifier from a database, or any other externally-defined string identifying the referent.

No particular syntax is proposed for the values of the key attribute, since its form will depend entirely on practice within a given project. For the same reason, this attribute is not recommended in data interchange, since there is no way of ensuring that the values used by one project are distinct from those used by another. In such a situation, a preferable approach for magic tokens which follows standard practice on the Web is to use a ref attribute whose value is a tag URI as defined in RFC 4151.
ref (reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
<name ref="http://viaf.org/viaf/109557338"  type="person">Seamus Heaney</name>
Note

The value must point directly to one or more XML elements or other resources by means of one or more URIs, separated by whitespace. If more than one is supplied the implication is that the name identifies several distinct entities.

3.3. att.global

att.global provides attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme. [1.3.1.1. Global Attributes]
Module tei
Members author bibl canonDef catDesc catRef category classDecl desc div editor encodingDesc foreign gloss hi idno item keywords mantra media milestone modPassage note ref taxonomy term title
Attributes Attributes  att.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:lang
Status Optional
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan written in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti written in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi written in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese written in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada written in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali written in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit written in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit written in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil written in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai written in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese written in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
cs
Czech
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
la
Latin
ru
Russian
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
ja
Japanese in Japanese script (Use Ja-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic written in Roman script.
mixed
This element contains strings mixed with different languages. They will be differentiated within this element by <foreign> tags, or left unwrapped if they are the default English.
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Status Optional
Datatype ID
Note

The xml:id attribute may be used to specify a canonical reference for an element; see section 3.11. Reference Systems.

3.4. att.global.rendition

att.global.rendition provides rendering attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme. [1.3.1.1.3. Rendition Indicators]
Module tei
Members att.global [author bibl canonDef catDesc catRef category classDecl desc div editor encodingDesc foreign gloss hi idno item keywords mantra media milestone modPassage note ref taxonomy term title]
Attributes Attributes
rend (rendition) indicates how the element in question was rendered or presented in the source text.
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.word separated by whitespace
<head rend="align(center) case(allcaps)">  <lb/>To The <lb/>Duchesse <lb/>of <lb/>Newcastle, <lb/>On Her <lb/>  <hi rend="case(mixed)">New Blazing-World</hi>. </head>
Note

These Guidelines make no binding recommendations for the values of the rend attribute; the characteristics of visual presentation vary too much from text to text and the decision to record or ignore individual characteristics varies too much from project to project. Some potentially useful conventions are noted from time to time at appropriate points in the Guidelines. The values of the rend attribute are a set of sequence-indeterminate individual tokens separated by whitespace.

3.5. att.internetMedia

att.internetMedia provides attributes for specifying the type of a computer resource using a standard taxonomy.
Module tei
Members att.media [graphic media] ptr ref
Attributes Attributes
mimeType (MIME media type) specifies the applicable multimedia internet mail extension (MIME) media type
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.word separated by whitespace
Example In this example mimeType is used to indicate that the URL points to a TEI XML file encoded in UTF-8.
<ref mimeType="application/tei+xml; charset=UTF-8"  target="http://sourceforge.net/p/tei/code/HEAD/tree/trunk/P5/Source/guidelines-en.xml"/>
Note

This attribute class provides an attribute for describing a computer resource, typically available over the internet, using a value taken from a standard taxonomy. At present only a single taxonomy is supported, the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) Media Type system. This typology of media types is defined by the Internet Engineering Task Force in RFC 2046. The list of types is maintained by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). The mimeType attribute must have a value taken from this list.

3.6. att.media

att.media provides attributes for specifying display and related properties of external media.
Module tei
Members graphic media
Attributes Attributes  att.internetMedia (@mimeType)

3.7. att.placement

att.placement provides attributes for describing where on the source page or object a textual element appears. [3.5.3. Additions, Deletions, and Omissions 11.3.1.4. Additions and Deletions]
Module tei
Members note trailer
Attributes Attributes
place specifies where this item is placed.
Status Recommended
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Suggested values include:
top
at the top of the page
bottom
at the foot of the page
margin
in the margin (left, right, or both)
opposite
on the opposite, i.e. facing, page
overleaf
on the other side of the leaf
above
above the line
right
to the right, e.g. to the right of a vertical line of text, or to the right of a figure
below
below the line
left
to the left, e.g. to the left of a vertical line of text, or to the left of a figure
end
at the end of e.g. chapter or volume.
inline
within the body of the text.
inspace
in a predefined space, for example left by an earlier scribe.
<add place="margin">[An addition written in the margin]</add> <add place="bottom opposite">[An addition written at the foot of the current page and also on the facing page]</add>
<note place="bottom">Ibid, p.7</note>

3.8. att.pointing

att.pointing provides a set of attributes used by all elements which point to other elements by means of one or more URI references. [1.3.1.1.2. Language Indicators 3.7. Simple Links and Cross-References]
Module tei
Members catRef ptr ref
Attributes Attributes
target specifies the destination of the reference by supplying one or more URI References
Status Optional
Datatype 1–∞ occurrences of teidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Note

One or more syntactically valid URI references, separated by whitespace. Because whitespace is used to separate URIs, no whitespace is permitted inside a single URI. If a whitespace character is required in a URI, it should be escaped with the normal mechanism, e.g. TEI%20Consortium.

3.9. att.resourced

att.resourced provides attributes by which a resource (such as an externally held media file) may be located.
Module tei
Members graphic media
Attributes Attributes
url (uniform resource locator) specifies the URL from which the media concerned may be obtained.
Status Required
Datatype teidata.pointer

3.10. att.timed

att.timed provides attributes common to those elements which have a duration in time, expressed either absolutely or by reference to an alignment map. [8.3.5. Temporal Information]
Module tei
Members media
Attributes Attributes
start indicates the location within a temporal alignment at which this element begins.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.pointer
Note

If no value is supplied, the element is assumed to follow the immediately preceding element at the same hierarchic level.
end indicates the location within a temporal alignment at which this element ends.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.pointer
Note

If no value is supplied, the element is assumed to precede the immediately following element at the same hierarchic level.

3.11. att.typed

att.typed provides attributes which can be used to classify or subclassify elements in any way. [1.3.1. Attribute Classes 17.1.1. Words and Above 3.6.1. Referring Strings 3.7. Simple Links and Cross-References 3.6.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions 3.13.1. Core Tags for Verse 7.2.5. Speech Contents 4.1.1. Un-numbered Divisions 4.1.2. Numbered Divisions 4.2.1. Headings and Trailers 4.4. Virtual Divisions 13.3.2.3. Personal Relationships 11.3.1.1. Core Elements for Transcriptional Work 16.1.1. Pointers and Links 16.3. Blocks, Segments, and Anchors 12.2. Linking the Apparatus to the Text 22.5.1.2. Defining Content Models: RELAX NG 8.3. Elements Unique to Spoken Texts 23.3.1.3. Modification of Attribute and Attribute Value Lists]
Module tei
Members bibl desc distinct div gloss head idno lg list media note ref table term title
Attributes Attributes
type characterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
<div type="verse">  <head>Night in Tarras</head>  <lg type="stanza">   <l>At evening tramping on the hot white road</l>   <l>…</l>  </lg>  <lg type="stanza">   <l>A wind sprang up from nowhere as the sky</l>   <l>…</l>  </lg> </div>
Note

The type attribute is present on a number of elements, not all of which are members of att.typed, usually because these elements restrict the possible values for the attribute in a specific way.
Schematron
<sch:rule context="tei:*[@subtype]"> <sch:assert test="@type">The <sch:name/> element should not be categorized in detail with @subtype unless also categorized in general with @type</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Note

When appropriate, values from an established typology should be used. Alternatively a typology may be defined in the associated TEI header. If values are to be taken from a project-specific list, this should be defined using the <valList> element in the project-specific schema description, as described in 23.3.1.3. Modification of Attribute and Attribute Value Lists .

4. Macros

4.1. anyAttribute

anyAttribute 
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
anyContent cache
Declaration 
anyAttribute = attribute * - xml:id { text }*⚓

4.2. anyContent

anyContent 
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
anyContent cache
Declaration 
anyContent = element * - idno { anyAttribute, anyContent }*⚓

4.3. bibl-section-content

bibl-section-content 
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back
Declaration 
bibl-section-content =
   (
      element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }
    | p
    | milestone
    | hi
    | lb
    | element bibl
      {
         attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
         (
            title
          | foreign
          | lb
          | ptr
          | ref-other
          | hi
          | note
          | element author { string }
          | element date { string }
          | text
         )+
      }
   )*⚓

4.4. cache

cache 
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
TEI
Declaration 
cache =
   element d83847235e5a1102:notes-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?
 & element d83847235e9a1102:milestones-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?
 & element d83847235e13a1102:folios-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?
 & element d83847235e17a1102:glossary-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?⚓

4.5. endnote

endnote 
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
head-content paragraph
Declaration 
endnote =
   element note
   {
      attribute index { xsd:integer }?,
      attribute place { "end" },
      attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
      ( macro.specialPara | hi | mantra )*
   }⚓

4.6. head-content

head-content 
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back bibl-section-content body front translation-chapter translation-section-head-content
Declaration 
head-content =
   attribute tid { text }?,
   ( string { minLength = "1" } | ( ( endnote | title | foreign )+ & text ) )⚓

4.7. macro.limitedContent

macro.limitedContent (paragraph content) defines the content of prose elements that are not used for transcription of extant materials. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
desc
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate maxOccurs="unbounded"
  minOccurs="0">
  <textNode/>
  <classRef key="model.limitedPhrase"/>
  <classRef key="model.inter"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
macro.limitedContent = ( text | model.limitedPhrase | model.inter )*⚓

4.8. macro.paraContent

macro.paraContent (paragraph content) defines the content of paragraphs and similar elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
canonDef mantra modPassage p ref title
Declaration 
macro.paraContent =
   (
      text
    | model.gLike
    | model.phrase
    | model.inter
    | model.global
    | model.lLike
    | lg
    | mantra
    | modPassage
    | canonDef
    | ref-canonical
    | ref-other
   )*⚓

4.9. macro.phraseSeq

macro.phraseSeq (phrase sequence) defines a sequence of character data and phrase-level elements. [1.4.1. Standard Content Models]
Module tei
Used by
author biblScope distinct editor expan foreign label publisher term
Declaration 
macro.phraseSeq =
   (
      text
    | model.gLike
    | model.attributable
    | model.phrase
    | model.global
    | ref-canonical
    | ref-other
   )*⚓

4.10. macro.specialPara

macro.specialPara ('special' paragraph content) defines the content model of elements such as notes or list items, which either contain a series of component-level elements or else have the same structure as a paragraph, containing a series of phrase-level and inter-level elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
endnote item note q
Declaration 
macro.specialPara =
   (
      text
    | model.gLike
    | model.phrase
    | model.inter
    | model.divPart
    | model.global
    | mantra
    | modPassage
    | canonDef
    | ref-other
    | ref-canonical
   )*⚓

4.11. paragraph

paragraph 
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
publicationStmt section-content
Declaration 
paragraph =
   element p
   {
      attribute tid { xsd:integer },
      attribute type { "sponsor" }?,
      attribute rend { "mantra" | "ignoreGlossary" }?,
      (
         text
       | title
       | ptr
       | endnote
       | foreign
       | ref-canonical
       | ref-other
       | emph
       | distinct
       | q
       | lb
       | hi
       | mantra
       | modPassage
       | canonDef
       | element term
         {
            attribute type { "ignore" }?,
            attribute ref { text }?,
            ( foreign* | text )+
         }
      )+
   }⚓

ref-canonical

Used by
l macro.paraContent macro.phraseSeq macro.specialPara paragraph trailer
Declaration 
ref-canonical =
   element ref
   {
      attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
      attribute type { "folio" | "volume" },
      attribute cRef { text },
      attribute key { text }?,
      attribute rend { "blank" }?,
      attribute work { text }?,
      attribute page { text }?,
      text
   }⚓

   {
      attribute type { "bampo" | "sanskrit" | "chinese" }?,

      attribute cRef { text }?,
      attribute target { text }?,
      attribute inst { text }?,
      attribute work { text }?,
      attribute key { text }?,
      text
   }⚓

translation-chapter

Declaration

   element div
   {
      attribute type { "chapter" },
      attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
      attribute rend { text }?,
      attribute prefix { text }?,
      element head
      {
         attribute type { "chapter" },
         attribute tid { text }?,
         attribute key { text }?,
         text
      },
      (
         element head { attribute type { "chapterTitle" }, head-content }
       | element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }
      )*,
      section-content,
      translation-subsection-lv3*
   }⚓

5. Datatypes

5.1. teidata.certainty

teidata.certainty defines the range of attribute values expressing a degree of certainty.
Module tei
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model 
<content>
 <valList type="closed">
  <valItem ident="high"/>
  <valItem ident="medium"/>
  <valItem ident="low"/>
  <valItem ident="unknown"/>
 </valList>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.certainty = "high" | "medium" | "low" | "unknown"⚓
Note

Certainty may be expressed by one of the predefined symbolic values high, medium, or low. The value unknown should be used in cases where the encoder does not wish to assert an opinion about the matter.

5.2. teidata.count

teidata.count defines the range of attribute values used for a non-negative integer value used as a count.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="nonNegativeInteger"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.count = xsd:nonNegativeInteger⚓
Note

Any positive integer value or zero is permitted

5.3. teidata.duration.iso

teidata.duration.iso defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using ISO 8601 standard formats
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.duration.iso = token { pattern = "[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+" }⚓
Example
<time dur-iso="PT0,75H">three-quarters of an hour</time>
Example
<date dur-iso="P1,5D">a day and a half</date>
Example
<date dur-iso="P14D">a fortnight</date>
Example
<time dur-iso="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the last, which may have a decimal component (using either . or , as the decimal point; the latter is preferred). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first ‘time’ number-letter pair.

For complete details, see ISO 8601 Data elements and interchange formats — Information interchange — Representation of dates and times.

5.4. teidata.duration.w3c

teidata.duration.w3c defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using W3C datatypes.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="duration"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.duration.w3c = xsd:duration⚓
Example
<time dur="PT45M">forty-five minutes</time>
Example
<date dur="P1DT12H">a day and a half</date>
Example
<date dur="P7D">a week</date>
Example
<time dur="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the S number, which may have a decimal component (using . as the decimal point). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first ‘time’ number-letter pair.

For complete details, see the W3C specification.

5.5. teidata.enumerated

teidata.enumerated defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single XML name taken from a list of documented possibilities.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • author/@role
  • bibl/@type
  • cell/@role
  • desc/@type
  • distinct/@type
  • div/@type
  • editor/@role
  • gloss/@type
  • head/@type
  • lg/@type
  • milestone/@unit
  • note/@place
  • ref/@type
  • row/@role
  • term/@type
  • title/@type
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef key="teidata.word"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.enumerated = teidata.word
                                    ⚓
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single ‘word’ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

Typically, the list of documented possibilities will be provided (or exemplified) by a value list in the associated attribute specification, expressed with a <valList> element.

5.6. teidata.name

teidata.name defines the range of attribute values expressed as an XML Name.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="Name"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.name = xsd:Name⚓
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single word which follows the rules defining a legal XML name (see http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#dt-name ): for example they cannot include whitespace or begin with digits.

5.7. teidata.numeric

teidata.numeric defines the range of attribute values used for numeric values.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef name="double"/>
  <dataRef name="token"
   restriction="(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)"/>
  <dataRef name="decimal"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.numeric =
   xsd:double | token { pattern = "(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)" } | xsd:decimal⚓
Note

Any numeric value, represented as a decimal number, in floating point format, or as a ratio.

To represent a floating point number, expressed in scientific notation, ‘E notation’, a variant of ‘exponential notation’, may be used. In this format, the value is expressed as two numbers separated by the letter E. The first number, the significand (sometimes called the mantissa) is given in decimal format, while the second is an integer. The value is obtained by multiplying the mantissa by 10 the number of times indicated by the integer. Thus the value represented in decimal notation as 1000.0 might be represented in scientific notation as 10E3.

A value expressed as a ratio is represented by two integer values separated by a solidus (/) character. Thus, the value represented in decimal notation as 0.5 might be represented as a ratio by the string 1/2.

5.8. teidata.pattern

teidata.pattern defines attribute values which are expressed as a regular expression.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="token"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.pattern = token⚓
Note
A regular expression, often called a pattern, is an expression that describes a set of strings. They are usually used to give a concise description of a set, without having to list all elements. For example, the set containing the three strings Handel, Händel, and Haendel can be described by the pattern H(ä|ae?)ndel (or alternatively, it is said that the pattern H(ä|ae?)ndel matches each of the three strings)
Wikipedia

This TEI datatype is mapped to the XSD token datatype, and may therefore contain any string of characters. However, it is recommended that the value used conform to the particular flavour of regular expression syntax supported by XSD Schema.

5.9. teidata.pointer

teidata.pointer defines the range of attribute values used to provide a single URI, absolute or relative, pointing to some other resource, either within the current document or elsewhere.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • author/@ref
  • catRef/@scheme
  • editor/@ref
  • media/@url
  • ptr/@target
  • term/@ref
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="anyURI"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.pointer = xsd:anyURI⚓
Note

The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax. Note that the values themselves are encoded using RFC 3987 Internationalized Resource Identifiers (IRIs) mapping to URIs. For example, https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/% is encoded as https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/%25 while http://موقع.وزارة-الاتصالات.مصر/ is encoded as http://xn--4gbrim.xn----rmckbbajlc6dj7bxne2c.xn--wgbh1c/

5.10. teidata.probCert

teidata.probCert defines a range of attribute values which can be expressed either as a numeric probability or as a coded certainty value.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef key="teidata.probability"/>
  <dataRef key="teidata.certainty"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.probCert = teidata.probability | teidata.certainty
                                    ⚓

5.11. teidata.probability

teidata.probability defines the range of attribute values expressing a probability.
Module tei
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="double"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.probability = xsd:double⚓
Note

Probability is expressed as a real number between 0 and 1; 0 representing certainly false and 1 representing certainly true.

5.12. teidata.replacement

teidata.replacement defines attribute values which contain a replacement template.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.replacement = text⚓

5.13. teidata.text

teidata.text defines the range of attribute values used to express some kind of identifying string as a single sequence of Unicode characters possibly including whitespace.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • author/@key
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="string"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.text = string⚓
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single ‘token’ in which whitespace and other punctuation characters are permitted.

5.14. teidata.truthValue

teidata.truthValue defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="boolean"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.truthValue = xsd:boolean⚓
Note

The possible values of this datatype are 1 or true, or 0 or false.

This datatype applies only for cases where uncertainty is inappropriate; if the attribute concerned may have a value other than true or false, e.g. unknown, or inapplicable, it should have the extended version of this datatype: teidata.xTruthValue.

5.15. teidata.version

teidata.version defines the range of attribute values which may be used to specify a TEI or Unicode version number.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • TEI/@version
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.version = token { pattern = "[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}" }⚓
Note

The value of this attribute follows the pattern specified by the Unicode consortium for its version number ( http://unicode.org/versions/ ). A version number contains digits and fullstop characters only. The first number supplied identifies the major version number. A second and third number, for minor and sub-minor version numbers, may also be supplied.

5.16. teidata.versionNumber

teidata.versionNumber defines the range of attribute values used for version numbers.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.versionNumber =
   token { pattern = "[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}" }⚓

5.17. teidata.word

teidata.word defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single word or token.
Module tei
Used by
teidata.enumerated Element:
  • div/@rend
  • mantra/@rend
  • ref/@rend
  • title/@rend
Content model 
<content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[^\p{C}\p{Z}]+"/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.word = token { pattern = "[^\p{C}\p{Z}]+" }⚓
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single ‘word’ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

5.18. teidata.xpath

teidata.xpath defines attribute values which contain an XPath expression.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    ⚓
Declaration 
teidata.xpath = text⚓
Note

Any XPath expression using the syntax defined in 6.2..

When writing programs that evaluate XPath expressions, programmers should be mindful of the possibility of malicious code injection attacks. For further information about XPath injection attacks, see the article at OWASP.

Appendix A Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors

Following below are complete step-by-step guidelines for marking up 84000 TEI. To reference how the markup stage is integrated with the entire 84000 workflow, here is link to the Editorial and Publications Workflow document.

Appendix A.1 Check the MS Word Document from Project Management

According to our current workflow, when a text is passed to markup it should be already uploaded to project management. First click on the "Search" tab and locate the file using the Toh number. Once you have found the text click on "edit headers", from there you can expand the "submissions" section (The TEI will be generated from this same screen as well, see below). From here you may click on the document and download it in order to check the document from MS Word. The copyeditors will have entered most of the proper style tags for foreign terms, verses, some of the mantra markup, and so forth. However, when you begin a text it is important to double check the work and make sure the text has been entered properly into the template.
