Also, sometimes you may be asked to apply the style tags into the template yourself, so as you continue to edit TEI markup, you should occasionally read the instructions in the copy editor's template and try to become familiar with them (The latest version of the copy editor's template may be downloaded here). A lot of the tags are set up to be tagged with character and paragraph styles from the template and automatically converted by a script into to correct markup. However, the copy editors may occasionally make some mistakes, and being familiar with the template will help you correct them and inform the copy editors of any issues. Remember, sections can always be corrected from the template, passed through the script again, and pasted into the final TEI so keep the original word document open for reference while you work.

When checking the document please follow check that the following is applied in the DOCX:

  • In general you can corraborate with the instructions written in the template.
  • Check that the text has tagged the appropriate sections using the "Heading 1, 2, or 3" styles to outline the text. Make sure that the style “Heading 4” or higher isn’t used anywhere in the document, as that information will be lost in the conversion process. Any headings for fourth level subsections (or higher) written by the translator should be set to the “Normal” style in the style set and be tagged with <level 4 header> or similar tags. These subsections will need to be manually created with <div> elements when you edit the XML.
  • All the italics have been applied with the various character styles, "foreign-", "title-", etc. (don't worry though, if you miss some, those italics will be given a <fix> tag by the script).
  • Because the markup for mantras has become a bit complicated, we have provided the copy editors an "Option Two" for applying style tags to all the mantras. This instruction was given in case differentiating the different "mantra" styles becomes too distracting from the actual copy editing work. Under "Option Two," the copy editor will tag all of the mantra italics with the character style "Mantra-Other" and you will need to distinguish and apply the appropriate markup to the mantras. You can do this either now, while you are checking the template, or you can pass the template through the script as it is and all the mantras will be tagged <mantra type="input type" xml:lang="input language"> and you can mark them up in the XML. However, I recommend doing this from the template as it will be faster. You can quickly find all the "Mantra-Other" tags by doing an "advanced find and replace" and click on the Format --> "Style" in the search dialog box. Leave the search bar empty and you can quickly go through all the "Mantra-Other" styles in the entire template and apply the correct style from the style pane. See instructions for the mantra markup in the template II. MANTRAS, pp 3–5, or see the full documentation for the mantra markup here in Appendix B.6.
  • All the verses have the "verse" paragraph style applied, and they are formatted correctly with line breaks between lines and paragraph breaks between stanzas (change the display settings to show paragraph marks and line breaks so you can see more clearly whether they are formatted correctly).
  • In some cases the copy editors may have left comments for the markup editors with the MS Word comments feature. The script will convert these into <note> elements that will have the "place" attribute with the value of "comment_from_copyeditor_to_markup_editor." I have intentionally set this up to be highlighted by the schema as an error, so that the copy editors may highlight any unusual formatting or other issues that need to be addressed by the markup editors. You may leave these in and address them as you work on the XML or alternatively keep a backup of the .docx and reference the comments from there. If you don't want to see them in the XML, make a backup of the .docx and select "Delete All Comments in the Document" from the review pane in Word before sending the document through the conversion script.

If the document looks good, you can go ahead and run the script, otherwise make corrections and upload the document again. If so, please use the exact same file name but add "-v2" or "-v3"... etc. for any subsequent versions for example: "T747-bhutadamara-for-markup-apr-16-2020-v2". Upload it to project management with the /Submissions.

Don't worry, you can always go back and do this again later on if you notice some problem in the DOCX.

Appendix A.2 Transform the New DOCX To TEI-XML

Running the Document through the Conversion Script:
  • Again using the "/Submissions" tab in Project Management, click on the document you wish to run through the script, and in the next panel, there will be a checklist on the right side of the screen. Check the "generate TEI" box, and then click save. The app will perform the conversion and the output .xml file can be found in the 84000 Collaboration/apps/84000-import-data folder. There will be a unique folder created with the name of the texts xml:id number. Note that you can convert the glossary through this submissions form as well (although this should be done later after checking the document, see A.7).
  • Occasionally the app may be down or the project management page may give you a permissions error. If it says that permission is denied you should email the lead technician who handles the server's permissions (Dominic). Alternatively, it is also possible to convert the word .docx created in the template through the oXgarage website or it's mirror site. Convert the file to a "TEI P5 XML Document" and run our own .xslt script on the document. The .xslt script is in apps/84000-import-data/xsl. (Instructions for running an .xslt script can be found in Appendix H)
Checking the XML Conversion before You Begin Editing:
  • This should create a file that is closer to what we want. However, the script is definitely not perfect, and many sections will need some reworking.
  • If the "verse" styles were applied appropriately in the template, then the script should put them correctly into <lg> and <l> elements. It should also preserve and convert any italic markup within the verses. The script is able to do both because in MS Word the "verse" is a paragraph style and all the italic markups are character styles. However, for the script to work properly the individual lines of verse need to be separated by line breaks, and the stanzas themselves need to be separated by paragraph breaks. There are instructions for how to do this in the template, but this process can be a bit finicky, so you should double check some of the verses to make sure the conversion has worked properly. Refer to the section on the <lg> element to see how verses need to be formatted.
  • Another note about the script to keep in mind is that the script is designed to automatically create divisions with <div> elements in the markup whenever the copy editors use the "heading 1," "heading 2," or "heading 3" styles in the template. This will create up to three levels of <div>s. As mentioned above any fourth level <div>s or further should be placed into tags by the copy editor and you will need to create the <div>s manually when you edit the XML. Occasionally, the copy editor will put a heading into the "heading 1" or "heading 2" style but they will mistakenly leave the paragraph break at the end of the heading's text in the "normal" style. The script generates the <div> elements according to these paragraph breaks, so in this case, it will not create the proper division. Usually it is easy enough to correct these in either the template .docx or in the .xml, but in some cases it may save you some time if you can identify and fix them before the conversion. For example, this happened in the bibliography of a text, and because the bibliography entries were nested with one <div> instead of two, the script rendered them into <p> elements instead of <bibl> elements as is required.
  • The script has a section for making appendices, which should appear in the <back> after the bibliography. However, since not all the texts have appendices, and since appendices could appear in many different forms such as lists, outlines, Sanskrit sources, etc., the script only converts these into the minimal default paragraphs or verses. You may need to reformat the markup in the section extensively or paste it in from the word file and mark it up from there. If there are more appendices in the future, or a particularly large appendix that needs to be extensively edited, we will develop the script to convert the appendices in a more detailed way.
  • If there is some unusual formatting or other issue that is preventing the script from converting the text properly, one strategy for isolating the problem is to divide the text into three pieces (front material, body, and back material), convert each section one be one, and then paste them into the final .xml. For this purpose we have created a Dummy Template which is just the minimal format for an 84000 text. Try pasting the smaller sections of the text into the Dummy Template and convert them one by one.

Appendix A.3 Merging the Converted XML into the Placeholder File and Editing Headers from Project Management

Merge the Converted XML into the Placeholder File:
  • When you have finished converting the document into an TEI-XML file, it is time to transfer it into the translations folder. There should already be a placeholder file for each of the Kangyur and Tengyur texts. Go to 84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > tei > translations, and you will see the "kangyur" and "tengyur" folders. Each of these folders in turn contain a "placeholders" folder and a "translations" folder. Find the placeholder file right click and select "cut" then move it into the sibling "translations" folder by right and select "paste" (don't use "copy" and "paste" as this will reset the files permissions).
  • You can then begin pasting the text from the XML you just converted into the placeholder text. The placeholder files usually just contain the <teiHeader>, however, most of this is important information and should not be overwritten. The converted XML will have directions in the form of comments, which will tell you specifically what elements within the teiHeader need to be added to the placeholder, and which to be left as is. In general, try to preserve all pertinent information from both sources, and if there is any data that seems to be contradictory, comment out the additional data and make a note of this in your final list of notes and issues.
  • The placeholder's <titleStmt> will require some extra attention; this contains the original collection of titles given to texts when the 84000 project first begin. However, when translations for these texts are made there will likely be many changes that need to be applied to the various titles. There may be additional alternative titles discovered through the translator's research, but there may be some alternative titles found in the placeholder file that the translator did not notice. So when merging the <titleStmt> in the converted XML with the placehoder please use the following protocol:
    • Update any English title to the one used by the translator found in the converted XML.
    • Preserve any alternative titles found in either the converted XML or the placeholder file. Alternative titles should be labeled type="otherTitle"
    • Make sure that the Sanskrit and Tibetan short titles, i.e., "otherTitles", are consistent with the English title in terms of the prensense of the final "འི་མདོ།" or"-sūtra". These should be removed if the word "Sūtra" isn't also found in the corresponding short English title. This presence or absence of "Sūtra" is not significant enough to warrant adding an additional "alternativeTitle"
    • Sanskrit Titles should have the first letter capitalized.
    • There should be a minimum of nine titles: 4 Main Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), 4 Long Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), and 1 Chinese. Any additional variant <title>s (whether coming from the converted file or already present in the placeholder) should be added after this as type="otherTitle". The actual order of the titles doesn't matter because the parser will display them in the same order no matter what order the XML is in, but if one or more of the nine default titles are not present, leave an empty element there as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>. Here is an example of the nine titles from Toh 83:
      <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus pa</title> <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="bo">ཚོང་དཔོན་བཟང་སྐྱོང་གིས་ཞུས་པ།</title> <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="en">The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant</title> <title type="mainTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bhadra­pāla­śreṣṭhi­paripṛcchā</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="bo">འཕགས་པ་ཚོང་དཔོན་བཟང་སྐྱོང་གིས་ཞུས་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ཐེག་པ་ཆེན་པོའི་མདོ།</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">’phags pa tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen po’i mdo</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra “The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant”</title> <title type="longTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Ārya­bhadra­pāla­śreṣṭhi­paripṛcchā­nāma­mahā­yāna­sūtra</title> <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>
      (See how this is displayed in the Reading Room)
    • Any straight single quote marks found in the Wylie should be changed to right curling ones. Note that all the Wylie in the placeholder titles will need to be changed because they have been left as straight quote marks in order to make them compatible with research databases like BDRC when the translator is in the research phase for that text. However, in our publications we only use curled ones.
    • After the titles the main translator or translator group will be listed in an <author role="translatorMain"> along with the phrase "translated by... under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha." This should be added below the last title and it will be corroborated from project management, as will be discussed below.
  • Also check the original word document for additional titles as the conversion script is quite rigid, and some of them might disappear if they were not entered properly.
  • Alternatively, if you prefer, the titles can also be edited from the project management page using the original .docx as a reference. The project management page is linked directly to the teiHeaders in the XML.
  • Occasionally, there will be a Chinese summary in the placeholder file, this should be merged into the TEI by placing the Chinese summary in its own <div> immediately after the English summary, for example:
    <div type="summary">  <head tid="699" type="summary">Summary</head>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-064-001-1"/>  <p tid="1">On Gayāśīrṣa Hill, Buddha Śākyamuni is visited by a great gathering of bodhisattvas... [English Summary Here]  </p> </div> <div type="summary" xml:lang="zh">  <p tid="711">《寶雲經》是最早被翻譯成藏文的佛典之一... [Chinese Summary Here]</p> </div>
    The Chinese will not be displayed in the English web display, but will appear in the Chinese catalog.
  • Note if Chinese characters are found in the sponsorship statement in the Acknowledgements: Sponsors are asked for what statement they would like give in the publication. Occasionally, these may be given in Chinese characters without translation or transliteration. For example here in Toh 543. So if you see this in the acknowledgements it is perfectly acceptable if that is what the sponsors request. Although, if you see it like this do make a note in the Reading Room Revisions sheet to confirm their choice in the final proofing stage.
Edit Text Status from Project Management:
  • Open the project management page. Find the text by searching the Toh number, then click on "edit headers."
  • From here there are various forms that may be used to edit the <teiHeader>. Note that any changes made here, after clicking on the "update" button, will be applied to the TEI file itself. You can use these forms to update the "titles," "location," and "status" in the <teiHeader>. Note that previously, markup would also edit the "contributors" tab, but now this is all handled by the work-flow manager (Line) and so in general, you do not need to concern yourself with the contributor fields or edit them in the TEI; however, do confirm that the "Translator Team" has been selected from the contributors tab and that the corresponding author tag appears in the correct format in the TEI markup. In the TEI this will appear as <author role="translatorMain"> with a ref id, including the name of the translator(s) or group followed by a <lb> (only seen in the TEI) and the phrase "under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha." For example in Toh 83 this appears as:
    <author ref="contributors.xml#team-16"  role="translatorMain"> Translated by Karen Liljenberg and Ulrich Pagel<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.</author>
    It is important that it follows this format along with the accompanying statement as this will be displayed on the cover page in the Reading Room.
  • Click on the "status". From this window you will be able to see various features regarding the text's status, some of which corresponds to data in the <teiHeader>, and some of this data is contained in separate data files. In the right column you will see a checklist for "Current Tasks". Here you can see the text's current stage within the work flow. You may "add to current tasks" as needed.
  • To display the text on the Utilities page, you will need to change the "status" attribute within the <publicationStmt>. It should be at "2.b" during the copyediting phase, and now for the markup you should change it to "2.a." (Although it has probably already been updated by the script). "2.a" is the markup stage, when you are completed with all the markup, it will be reviewed one more time by the lead markup editor and then then they will update the status to "2", ("Markup Completed, and awaiting final proofing before release"). The text will now appear on the Utilities Page. Here you will be able to see how the text will be displayed on the webpage before it is published on the official 84000 page. Click on the link that says "html" next to the text to see the web display.
  • At this point the <teiHeader> should be more or less complete. Since the merge process is a bit complicated, you may refer to the <teiHeader> in Toh 83 for reference. All the headers should follow the same format that has been used in Toh 83.

Appendix A.4 Edit the XML

Appendix A.4.1 Apply the Schema:

  • The schema should already be applied to the placeholder file, but if you need to apply the schema directly it is located in “84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > schema > current > translation.rng.” You will see any schema errors as red bars on the right column in the oXygen window. Checking the schema is the best way to see if the XML is going to work correctly in the parser. If later on you have trouble saving to the database, or if you can save to the database but the web page does not display the text, then start by checking for schema errors in oXygen. If it says that there is an error where you don’t think there is really an error, but you need to check the XML on the web display, you can comment-out that section with comment tags:
    <!-- --> (or highlight and press Ctrl-Shift “,” on PC or Command-Shift "m" on mac). Then you will be able to temporarily block all the seeming schema errors to help identify the problem.
  • You will initially see many schema errors for some missing attributes such as "xml:id"s and "tid"s. Note that all "xml:id" attributes, "tid" attributes in the <p> elements, and "index" attributes in the <note> elements will be added automatically when you save and reload the XML, so you don't need to worry about adding these. However, in the <teiHeader> within the <publicationStmt> there is an element for the id number for the text, <idno>. This should have been already present in the placeholder folder, however if it is missing retrieve it from your manager and enter it in manually as this is needed to generate all the xml:id attributes in the text.
  • In case there is an error in any of the "xml:id" or "tid" attributes due to duplicates, then you can regenerate them by deleting any problematic ones, saving the file, and then re-opening. The "xml:id" and "tid" will be generated wherever they are missing. If not, email the lead technician and they will make sure they are regenerated. It is fine if the "xml:id" attributes are not in order as long as they each have a unique value.

Appendix A.4.2 Some General Guidelines for Editing the XML:

  • While editing the XML, I usually use a previously edited and published TEI document as a model to make sure everything is formatted in the same way. This can be helpful, especially if this is your first time marking up a text or if you haven't done the markup for some time. Toh 83 is our go to as the standard for markup. This is a simple text, one of our earliest publications, and the first place we look when assuring that our markup is consistent. Toh 83 is a good standard, although because it is a simple text it may not have references for how to deal with the markup used in special cases. Here are some other texts with published TEI, which you may refer to for specific markup situations:
    • For a text containing a lot of mantras: see Toh 431
    • For a text with a complex outline (containing 6+ levels of <div>s): see Toh 1-1
    • For a text with extensive Chinese quotations in the notes: see Toh 61
    Also, if you are looking for a specific element try right clicking on the published "translations" folder and searching for a specific example to reference, e.g., "<table" to find a reference of the <table> element.
  • In general, while going through the text, it is important to periodically refer back to the .docx you received from the copy editor. If the document has an unusually formatted outline, some portions of text may be lost in the XSLT conversion. A good way to check this is to open the original .docx and look at the outline of the text (on PC go to “View” and check the box that says “Show Navigation Pane”; on Mac go to “View” > “Sidebar” > “Document Map Pane”; this might be different for other versions of Word). For example, if there are any fourth-level headers or extra divisions in the summary or acknowledgements, these sections may disappear. It is particularly good to check the front material and the bibliography for anything unusual.
  • The template should generate a placeholder for sponsorship in the "Acknowledgements" section, this is just a placeholder for the sponsor so the editors and Line remember to check the sponsorship with Jing Rui before publication. Please leave it as is unless instructions from management say otherwise.
  • The acknowledgements section should be formatted in the following manner:
    • Main translator acknowledgements
    • Supervision of 84000 acknowledgement
    • <break> (convert this to an <lb> element)
    • Sponsorship acknowledgement
    for example:
    <p tid="4">Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee under the supervision of Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche. The translation was produced by Thomas Doctor with help from Benjamin Collet-Cassart and Timothy Hinkle. Thomas also wrote the introduction. Andreas Doctor checked the translation against the Tibetan and edited the text. David Higgins subsequently reviewed the translation and made further edits. Wiesiek Mical assisted by reviewing numerous passages against the available Sanskrit sources. Robert Kritzer generously shared several unpublished articles on the text with us and Vesna Wallace and Mitsuyo Demoto kindly gave us access to drafts of their critical Sanskrit editions of chapters 1 and 3, respectively. </p> <p tid="6">The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.</p> <lb/> <p tid="5">[Sponsored by XXXXX.]</p>
  • When you first get to the <body> of the text, you may notice that the title has been repeated with two lines containing separate <p> and <milestone> tags. For example:
    <body>  <div type="translation">   <head type="translation"> The Translation </head>   <head type="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra</head>   <head type="titleMain">Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality</head>   <milestone unit="chunk"/>   <p> The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra </p>   <milestone unit="chunk"/>   <p> Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality </p> <!--...body of the text...-->  </div> </body>
    The reason for this, is the script has a safeguard to display any text within the first main <div> but not included in the first second level <div>. A not ideal consequence of this safeguard results in this repetition of the first two lines, which simply needed to be deleted manually. So the above example should be edited to look as follows:
    <body>  <div type="translation">   <head type="translation"> The Translation </head>   <head type="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Sūtra</head>   <head type="titleMain">Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality</head> <!--...body of the text...-->  </div> </body>
  • If either one of the introduction, main translation, and/or bibliography have only one section you will probably see this heading at the beginning of their second level <div> element:
    <head>Main Section</head>
    This is actually a placeholder from the template and should be removed, as the heading from the previous <div> element will provide the heading "Introduction" or "The Translation."
  • Most Kangyur texts begin with a short homage, typically this should be followed by a line break <lb> between the homage and the beginning of the text, which needs to be added manually:
    <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-044-005-11"/> <p tid="13">  <ref cRef="F.104.b" type="folio"/> Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas! </p> <lb/> <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-044-005-12"/> <p tid="14">Thus have I heard at one time. <!--...--> </p>
    (Click here to see in Reading Room display) Occasionally there may be a long homage that necessitates its own section. In this case it may be appropriate to create a <div> for the homage itself. The <div> and its accompanying <head> should both be type="homage". See for example in Toh 138:
    <div type="homage">  <head tid="995" type="homage">Homage</head>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-056-006-23"/>  <p tid="27">   <ref cRef="F.187.b" type="folio"/>   <ref cRef="B1" type="bampo"/>Homage to the thus-gone Splendorous    with the Gentle Glow of Light and Fragrance!</p>  <lb/>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-056-006-1876"/>  <p tid="28">Homage to the one with the melodious voice of Mahābrahmā!</p>  <lb/>  <milestone unit="chunk"   xml:id="UT22084-056-006-25"/>  <p tid="29">Having paid homage to him, <!--...etc...-->  </p> <!--...etc...--> </div>
    (Click here to see in Reading Room display)
  • If there were any italics that were missed in the copy editing phase, they will appear with a schema error in an element called "fix." You will need to manually fix these and replace them with the appropriate element, whether it be <foreign>, <title>, <distinct>, <mantra> etc. Sometimes these may be just italicized punctuation that the copy editor or author made by mistake, in which case you can go ahead and remove these tags.
  • Check that all mantras have been properly tagged. Note, that any mantras that have fragments of them written in more than one languages--usually English with Sanskrit seed syllables but this may also include Sanskrit/Tibetan mixed mantras--will be marked as such in the template and be converted to <foreign type="Fragment-in-MixedMantra">. They will appear as errors in the schema which is a signal for you to wrap the complete mantra in a <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> element. Then the @type="Fragment-in-MixedMantra" can be removed with the refactoring tool once they are all wrapped. <mantra>s need to be tagged in precise way, please see Appendix B.6 for details on how to markup the mantras.
  • Double check that the tag <hi rend="small-caps"> is used for any small capital letters in the text. This includes any abbreviations for CE ("Common Era") or BCE ("Before Common Era") in dates. Note that the lowercase letter needs to be used for small-caps, for example:
    In the year 2000 <hi rend="small-caps">bce</hi>
    Then the parser will render this as small capital "BCE".
    (If for some reason you ever need to add diacritics to small-caps, see details about this in the documentation for the <hi> element).
  • Note that some of the Kangyur sigla in the abbreviations and notes use subscript letters. For Kangyur sigla we use the Vienna system, which you can check the spelling here. Most of the sigla use a Capital letter followed by a lowercase one, but the sigla from the Peking Group, Mongolian, and Nyingma Kangyurs use a capital letter followed by subscript letters, and these second letters should have the <hi rend="subscript"> tag. Here either the lowercase or uppercase letter should be used according to the definitive sigla, for example:
    Peking 1737 PK = K<hi rend="subscript">Q</hi>, rnying rgyud bris ma = G<hi rend="subscript">bm</hi>.
    Do not use any unicode for the small caps or subscript such as "ʙᴄᴇ" or "ᵥ" as this won't display consistently in the reading room for all browsers. The script should convert all small-caps and subscript from the template with the proper tag, if "small-caps" and "subscript" were applied in the template using MS Words Font dialog (Format > Font), but these should be double checked in the XML.
  • Typically there will be many left over "<hi>" elements after the script has converted the text. With the one exception of rendering small capital and subscript letters (as shown in the example above) we don't really don't use any of these <hi> elements in our mark up. Most of these are just remnants of formatting from the word document, and the script should convert all of these to type="wordfile-remnant". The refactoring tool is very helpful for removing them. In the oXygen menu go to "Tools" > XML Refactoring, and then select "unwrap element." This operation removes the "<hi>" tags but leave the text within them untouched, however we only want to remove the <hi type="wordfile-remnant"> elements but not the <hi rend="small-caps"> and <hi rend="subscript">elements. To do this, after selecting the "unwrap element" operation, it will ask us for the Target Elements (XPath). For this we should enter the XPath: hi[@type="wordfile-remnant"] This will only remove the <hi> elements with this attribute. Now you can click on "Next" and then "Preview". Note that it will ask you to save all opened editors, so be sure to close any editor windows that you don't want saved. The Refactoring tool is very useful for removing or changing other unwanted markup as well. However, use some caution when making global changes like this. You will want to make sure you aren't removing any important data. Using the preview mode, you can see how a command is going to effect the text. In most cases, we will want to remove all the "<hi type="wordfile-remnant">" tags, but before using the refactoring tool to remove them, be sure to take a quick glance through the text and make sure the <hi> tags are not being used for a significant markup that may have been missed or unrepresented in the copy editing phase. If you are unsure, or if the <hi> tags are too messy to tell, save a backup copy of the markup before removing them with the refactoring tool, then you can check them once more after you finish marking up the text.
  • Look for any weird tags that shouldn't be there like "type="endnote text"" or any other relics from the oxgarage/script conversion.
  • Look for any mistakes: typos, mislabeled tags, etc.
  • Note that ellipses are to be made with three periods and non-breaking spaces (U+00A0) before each of the periods. It should appear as a . . . but the first three spaces should all display "U+00A0" in the bottom right corner of the Oxygen screen. If you need to paste them in use this text file (The proper spaces won't display in this HTML). Also note that the space after the last period should be a regular space (U+0020) so it is still possible to have a break before the next word. Ellipses should be entered in this format by the copyeditors, they will be carried through the scripts so you shouldn't worry about them unless you notice that they are in an improper format.
  • As you do any major work on the text, it is a good idea to occasionally update the version number as a reference for file backups. For guidelines on how and when to do this, see Appendix K: Guidelines for Updating Versions of the TEI Document.

Appendix A.4.3 Editing Folio, Bampo, and Other Page References in the XML:

  • All the references such as [F.100.a], etc. need to be entered into <ref> elements with the "cRef" attribute, thus [F.100.a] should look like this:
    <ref cRef="F.100.a" type="folio"/>
    Note that this is the standard we are using for all folio references: it should be an "F" followed by a period, a number, another period, and the letter "a" or "b." To put the bracketed folios into the <ref> element I usually use a search and replace with regular expressions. To do this open a find and replace box, check the "Regular Expressions" box and search for:
    \[(F\.\d+\.[ab])\]
    Replace with:
    <ref cRef="$1" type="folio"/>
    Or if they forgot to add the second period before that "a" or "b," like "[F.100a]", then search for:
    \[(F\.\d+)([ab])\]
    And replace with:
    <ref cRef="$1.$2" type="folio"/>
    Another situation you might see is double folios for duplicate Toh versions such as, "[(Toh 674) F.212.a] [(Toh 849) F.58.a]". Since you need to copy over the Toh # as the key, you can do that with a regular expression like this, search:
    \[\(Toh (\d+)\) (F\.\d+\.[ab])\]
    And replace:
    <ref cRef="$2" key="toh$1" type="folio"/>
    Regular expressions are very useful for such tasks, just be careful not to search and replace any text or markup you did not intend to. For example, the introduction of a text might quote a folio reference number in the same format in which it was applied in the body of the text, say "[F.100.a]". We definitely don't want this instance placed into a <ref> element, so be careful not to inadvertently replace it with a "replace all" command. Usually when I do a search and replace, I replace a few individual items to make sure it is working properly and there aren't any anomalies before I do a "replace all" command. If you aren't familiar with regular expressions this is a good reference website, and there are a lot of tutorials on youtube too.
  • Sometimes there are other reference numbers used within the texts such as bampo numbers or page numbers referencing another source. All of these should also be placed in <ref> elements using the following conventions:
    • Bampo references should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "bampo" and follow the format "B[bampo number]", for example:
      <ref cRef="B1" type="bampo"/>
    • References to a Sanskrit, Chinese, or other source should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "sanskrit", "chinese" etc. Typically curly brackets should be used to differentiate the Sanskrit or Chinese references from the Tibetan ones. Because the parser automatically generates square brackets around the cRef attribute, the inner node of the <ref> element should be used with typed curly brackets, for example:
      <ref type="sanskrit">{S1}</ref>
    • Note that whatever is placed in the @cRef attribute, will appear in square brackets in the reading room. Occasionally the author or editors may wish to hide a certain of reference number if they are deemed to be unnecessary for the general readership. In this case they may be given the attribute @rend="hidden", which will hide the reference in the reading room while still being marked in the TEI. For example this is done with some Sanskrit <ref>s in Toh 11:
      <ref cRef="1" rend="hidden" type="sanskrit"/>

      Note, here it doesn't matter whether the cRef is used or the inner node is used since it will be rendered invisible in the Reading Room.

  • When a <ref> comes between two paragraphs, it is better to place it at the end of the preceding paragraph rather than the beginning of proceeding one, as this will be less distracting for the reader. The very first <ref>, however, must be placed at the beginning of the paragraph as there is no other choice.
  • When a large text spans multiple volumes a volume reference should be added at the beginning of the new volume just before the first folio reference of the new volume using the following format: <ref type="volume" cRef="V__">. For example in Toh 11, it spans to volume 32 at F.92.b:
    <ref cRef="V32" type="volume"/> <ref cRef="F.92.b" type="folio"/>
    See how this is displayed in Reading Room
    * Usually the new volume will reset to F.1.b, but Toh 11 is a special case and continues with the numbering "F.92.b" on the first page of volume 32. The volumes for the text will be marked in the <location>/<volume> element(s) in the located in the <sourceDesc>.
  • There are some texts that are duplicated in multiple sections of the Kangyur. For example The Prophecy of Sri_Mahadevi is found twice in the Kangyur as Toh. 193 and 739. Theses are both word for word exactly the same, but the folio references are going to be different for each duplicate version of the text. So in this situation we just use one TEI file, "061-014_toh193,739" but the folio references are differentiated with the key attribute which will relate each individual <ref> to the corresponding key that is declared within that version's <bibl> element found in the TEI's initial <sourceDesc>. For example, in 061-014_toh193,739's <sourceDesc>:
    <sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh193" type="text">   <ref>Toh 193</ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 246.a–250.b</biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>   <location count-pages="10"    work="UT4CZ5369">    <volume end-page="500" number="61"     start-page="491"/>   </location>   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC14668"/>   <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC11815"    work="W22084"/>  </bibl>  <bibl key="toh739" type="text">   <ref>Toh 739</ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 94 (rgyud ’bum, tsha), folios      230.a–234.b</biblScope>   <author role="translatorTib">Unknown</author>   <location count-pages="10"    work="UT4CZ5369">    <volume end-page="468" number="94"     start-page="459"/>   </location>   <idno parent-id="O1JC114941JC21415"/>   <idno source-id="O1JC114941JC12480"    work="W22084"/>  </bibl> </sourceDesc>
    Then if you look at each individual folio references they will be differentiated by the key like this:
    ... <p tid="9">  <ref cRef="F.246.a" key="toh193"   type="folio"/>  <ref cRef="F.230.a" key="toh739"   type="folio"/> Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. </p>
    Now the parser will only display the appropriate folio references, e.g., when you click on Toh. 193 it will show the references for Toh. 193 but not those for 739 and vice-versa. Sometimes the page breaks between the folios will be in the same place in the eKangyur but often they are different so you may need to go in and find them all manually if they were not written in by the translator.
  • As a final note on the subject of folio references, on rare occasions there are blank folio pages in the Degé appearing in the middle of texts. These blank pages will be matched with blank pages in the eKangyur; however, the reader generates a segment of preceding and following text from the nearest folio pages and this may be confusing to the reader when the folio reference is clicked in the web display. Therefore it is preferable to add a @rend="blank" attribute to any blank folios, which will suppress the link, and then add a note simply explaining that the page is blank. For example here is such a case in Toh 287:
    What difference is there <ref cRef="F.82.b" rend="blank" type="folio"  xml:id="UT22084-068-021-100028"/> <note place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-068-021-102194">This folio of the Degé Kangyur is blank.</note> ...
    See how this is displayed in the Reading Room.

Appendix A.4.4 Editing Tags that were Entered from the Template with Angular Brackets < > :

  • There are a few special tags that copy editors have been instructed to enter into the template using angular brackets < and >. These include:
    • 1) Modular passages: <module starts> <module ends>
    • 2) Level four sections or above: <level 4 div> </level 4 div> <level 5 div> </level 5 div> etc...
    • 3) Block quotes: <q> </q>
    • 4) Links to other Kangyur/Tengyur texts: <Reference Toh 9999 F.999.a>
    • 5) Double line breaks used to create a section break without a header <break>
    In each of these cases, in order to avoid nesting errors the angular brackets will be transformed by the script into their escape codes &lt; and &gt; respectively. In the xml editor these will appear in dark yellow type and can be easily searched for. Each should be addressed as follows:
    • 1) modular passages, for now should just be replaced with comments, although just the tags themselves not their content, e.g.:
                              ＆lt;module starts＆gt;Knowing and seeing all,＆lt;module ends＆gt;                       
      should be changed to
      <!--module starts-->Knowing and seeing all, <!--module ends-->
      Some day we will create markup for this but for now, they are noted in comments that can be searched later.
    • 2) Level four sections or higher need <div> elements created for them along with any accompanying headers, e.g.:
                              ＆lt;level 4 div＆gt;Section 1.2.1: Vinaya Rules Concerning Pet Alligators＆lt;/level 4 div＆gt;                       
      should be changed to
      <div type="section">  <head type="section">Section 1.2.1: Vinaya Rules Concerning Pet Alligators</head> <!--The content of the section here.--> </div>
    • 3) Block quotes need to be changed into <q> elements. Any <p> or <lg> elements should be placed inside any <q> elements, e.g:
      <milestone/> ＆lt;q＆gt; <milestone/> <lg>  <l>“Space has no abode;</l>  <l> It is free from elaboration, and stainless.</l>  <l>Your mind is the same as space,</l>  <l>And you are free of any point of reference: </l>  <l> I bow to you!”</l> </lg> ＆lt;/q＆gt;
      should be changed to
      <milestone/> <q>  <lg>   <l>“Space has no abode;</l>   <l> It is free from elaboration, and stainless.</l>   <l>Your mind is the same as space,</l>   <l>And you are free of any point of reference: </l>   <l> I bow to you!”</l>  </lg> </q>
      Occasionally the copy editors might forget to put in tags for block quotes. Therefore, refer back to the original .docx if it seems like a section should be put into block quotes. Add a note to the final list of questions and issues if there is a section that was not set apart as a block quote that you believe should have.
    • 4) Links to other Kangyur/Tengyur texts should be created with <ref>, or if those texts are not yet published they should be set as precisely coded comments, e.g.:
      See <title xml:lang="en">The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant</title>＆lt;Reference Toh 0282＆gt;. See <title xml:lang="en">The Perfection of Wisdom in One Million Lines</title>＆lt;Reference Toh 4570＆gt; (a forthcoming 84000 publication).
      should be changed to
      See <title>  <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/toh83.html">The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant</ref> </title> See <title xml:lang="en">The Perfection of Wisdom in One Million Lines</title> <!--Reference Toh 4570--> (a forthcoming 84000 publication).
      Note that the links to future not yet published texts must follow the exact format up to the four digit Toh number as in the example above (although additional folio numbers, chapters etc... may be optionally added after the four digit number). Please add these <ref> links and coded comments if they have been missed by the translator or copy editor. Note, that internal links are not made with the <ref> element, but rather with the <ptr> element. The compiled guidelines regarding how to create links are in the topics sections, see Appendix B.4 on Cross References and Links for more details.
    • 5) Replace ＆lt;break＆gt; with a simple <lb> tag.

Appendix A.4.5 Keep an Eye Out for Unwanted Blank Spaces:

This is unfortunately an issue that occasionally occurs through the conversion scripts. It typically happens when multiple tags are set next to each other, such as the spaces between <mantra> tags and <note>s. Occasionally this will create an unwanted space that was not in the original Word doc. We are currently working on improving the scripts to resolve this and prevent these unwanted spaces from being generated, but in the meantime keep an eye out for extra spaces, particularly ones that appear after a <foreign> or <mantra> tag and before a note or punctuation.

For example see the unwanted spaces after the foreign term "mthong", and the ones before and after "khums" in the following example:

Here the imperative thong (“admit / release”), however, could easily be a scribal error for <foreign type="term" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">mthong</foreign> , “behold.” KY, K, and N have the imperative “subsume!” ( <foreign type="term" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">khums</foreign> ).

Appendix A.4.6 Other Issues to Check For while Editing the XML:

  • Within the notes section of the text the template and script will create an abbreviations section even if there isn't one. If there isn't any abbreviations section in the original docx. you can delete the abbreviations header but leave the section for notes. It should just look like this:
    <div type="notes">  <head type="notes">Notes</head> </div>
  • If the translator used Kangyur sigla in the notes but didn't create an abbreviations section, you may need to add one. See details for this in Appendix B/Topics: Abbreviations.
  • Any formal lists or outlines within the text should be marked up with the <list> element, which must also have the type attribute with the value "section" or "bullet." "Section" should be used for longer items of text, and it will render them with some vertical spacing between each item. "Bullet" should be used for shorter items and will create some horizontal indentation (it isn't necessary for there to be actual "bullets" in the list, this is just what we have named it). These types can be used in any combination to create an outline. For further details on outlines and some examples see Appendix B.3.
  • There may be times when a stanza of verse was missed and not placed into "verse" tags when being copy edited in the MS Word template. If that is the case you will notice each line of verse appearing in <p> tags rather than <l> tags. It is good to refer back to the original Word doc if you are in doubt, from there it should be clear according to the line breaks whether or not a stanza of verse was intended or not.
  • Occasionally there may be tables in a document. For instructions on how to markup tables see Appendix B.5 Tables.
  • Check that all the <div> elements are marked up with the proper type attributes. See the documentation for the <div> element to see the list of acceptable values. Note that a "prologue" or "colophon" should be marked as such and not as a "section." Also, each <div> should be accompanied by a <head> that has its own matching type attribute; however, there is one exception to this, <div type="section"> may be left without a <head> if the author did not provide one, this will usually be the case in the Introduction, Main Translation, or Bibliography whenever there is just one section and by default it is placed into a second level <div type="section"> wrapped within a first level <div type="introduction"> or <div type="translation">. In this case the parser will read the <head>s from the main first level <div> and the second level <div type="section"> will not require an additional <head>.
  • The script doesn't distinguish between chapters and sections, so the type value for all the "chapters" needs to be applied manually. Also, "chapter"s should contain a <head> type="chapter" element with some kind of enumeration, i.e., "chapter one," "chapter two," etc. If there is a formal title it should be contained in a <head> type="chapterHead" element following the first <head>. For example:
    <div type="chapter">  <head type="chapter">Chapter 32</head>  <head type="chapterTitle">The Teaching on the Nature of All Phenomena</head> <!--...chapter text...--> </div>
  • Some texts have <trailer>s at the end of each chapter, for example in Toh. 11:
    <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-031-002-1980"/> <trailer tid="3216">This completes the twenty-second chapter from the <title xml:lang="en">Transcendent Perfection of Wisdom in Ten Thousand Lines</title>, entitled “Cultivation.”</trailer>
    Be default the script will convert every paragraph into a <p> element, so these <trailer>s should be manually applied if they appear at the end of each chapter. Please give each <trailer> its own milestone.
  • All of the trailers will be separated by a space and italicized in their entirety by the parser, so any <title>s that appear in the trailer should be giving curled quotations marks. You will probably need to add these as the italicization could likely have been unnoticed in the copy editing phase. e.g.:
    <trailer tid="1938">This concludes the first chapter, the introduction to the tantra, in the glorious Caṇḍa­mahā­roṣaṇa tantra called “<title xml:lang="en">The    Sole Hero</title>.”</trailer>
  • Some texts contain appendices. These will be located in the back section of the text. Usually the markup can be applied in the same way as in the main section, however, for Sanskrit Appendices (those that contain a Sanskrit edition of the text)see Topics: Appendix B.9 Sanskrit Appendices for some further notes about marking up these sections.
  • As you are working with the TEI texts, you may encounter various problems that require you to search for specific pieces of code or text within the markup. The XQuery/XPath Builder is a useful tool for searching for specific instances of text. See Appendix J, for further details on how to use the XQuery/XPath Builder.

Appendix A.5 Edit Milestones

Milestones should be generated automatically by the script before every <p> element and <lg> element; however, we don't use milestones as uniformly as this, and many of the milestones will need to be taken out (for instructions on how to do this see appendix D). It is important to do an actual visual check of the milestones as they appear in the web display. From the Reading Room, take the perspective of the reader; there should be enough milestones to map out the text, but they should not be distracting to the actual narrative of the text.

Appendix A.6 Check the Alignment for Folio References

Web Display:

First, we need to check to make sure the Folio References displayed on the web page are in alignment with the eKangyur. This require some minimal knowledge of Tibetan, so please have another editor check this for you if you don't know how to read Tibetan.

When you check the web display, go to the main translation and click on a folio reference, e.g., "[F.100.a]." This should cause the eKangyur text to pop up. Make sure that the eKangyur page that pops up is the correct page that corresponds to the English translation. You don't need to go through every folio in the text, just check the first two folio refs and the very last one.

Most likely they will already be aligned from the original placeholder data and a correction will not be needed. However, due to a blank page or error in the eKangyur the alignment of the pages might be off by one or more pages. The alignment may be adjusted in the <location>/<volume> element found in the <sourceDesc>; here the start-page and end-page define the span of the folio alignment according to the pages numbers of the eKangyur.

For texts that span two or more volumes, this will be defined by multiple <volume> elements and you should individual check the first and last folio for each volume. Then a <ref type="volume" cRef="V_"/> element needs to be added just before the first folio reference of the new volume. For example, Toh 11 spans two volumes:
<location count-pages="788"  work="UT4CZ5369">  <volume end-page="593" number="31"   start-page="414"/>  <volume end-page="611" number="32"   start-page="2"/> </location>
and it jumps to volume 32 at F.92.b which is marked up as follows in the TEI:
<ref cRef="V32" type="volume"/> <ref cRef="F.92.b" type="folio"/>
See how this is displayed in Reading Room
* Note, usually the new volume will reset to F.1.b, but Toh 11 is a special case and continues with the numbering "F.92.b" on the first page of volume 32.

Check Folios Utility for Anomalies:

Please also check the Folios Utility from the main Utilities page. The folio utility will show you all the folio references along with their matching correlation in the eKangyur and then flag any anomalies. The anomalies will usually include the following:

  • Occasionally there may be a missing folio reference. It could be that the original translator missed it or due to some formatting the original references were commented out or removed.
  • A folio reference may have been entered incorrectly (e.g. missing a period between the number and letter, "2b").
  • Differences between the spanning pages stated in the header and that found in the eKangyur. Although they are intended to be identical, there may be pagination differences between the Dege print the eKangyur is based on, W4CZ5369, and the official Dege print we use and reference in our <biblScope>, W22084 (Although the eKangyur uses the volume order from W22084).
  • Occasionally there may be anomalies reproduced from the original printed Dege, and certain page numbers may have been skipped or duplicated for various reasons.
  • Occasionally there may be an error in the pagination found in the eKangyur. Use this spreadsheet here if you would like to report them.

Any missing or erroneous folio references will need to be corrected. If it is the eKangyur numbering that is different or in error, there will be a flag on the Folio Utility page and the message, "Logically F.XXX.a/b" appearing next to the reference. You should just make sure that our displayed cRef is the correct one for the official W22084 print and that the English corresponds to the correct page in the eKangyur (whatever its page number might be). When the the eKangyur pagination is different from our official W22084 one, please note this in your list of final issues to be reviewed at the end of markup.

Note, that if the text contains duplicate versions within the Kangyur (such as Toh. 212/520/980), the folio alignment will need to be checked for each version individually.

***Special Case for Volumes 81, 83, and 88 of the Degé Kangyur/eKangyur*** There is a variation due to the addition of texts in the post par phud printings, which includes our eKangyur in volumes 81, 83 and 88, which are not in the par phud printing such as W22084. In volumes 81 and 83, this only concerns some texts added to the very end of the volume, but for volume 88 the Bodhimaṇḍasyālaṃkāralakṣadhāraṇī (byang chub snying po’i rgyan ’bum gyi gzungs) has the same Tibetan title as Toh 509, but a different Sanskrit title (Toh 509 is Bodhigarbhālaṃkāralakṣadhāraṇī). While this is confusing, it is also presumably the reason why the extra text was inserted at this point. If the orginal translator used a par phud printing this then off sets Volume 88 by 17 folios for all texts after Toh. 508. In this situation, because the folio references will not match up with those in the eKangyur, our solution has been to put use both folio references. The one that links to the eKanyur will be the default <ref> element and the <ref> that refers to the alternate printing (likely W22084) should have this stated by a work attribute within the <ref> element. See for example from toh. 520:

<ref cRef="F.41.a" key="toh520"  work="W22084"/> <ref cRef="F.58.a" key="toh520" type="folio"/>

Here in the web display both references will be visible but only the one without the "work" attribute will have a clickable link to the eKangyur.

Please add a note after the first folio instance that explains this issue to the reader. If the text includes duplicates at different Toh numbers, then the note will need alternate messages, which are applied by using the @key attribute in the <p> elements within the note. The template for the note is as follows:

<note place="end">  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 88 TEXT]">Two sets of folio references have been included in this translation due to a discrepancy    in volume 88 (<foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">rgyud ’bum</foreign>, <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">na</foreign>) of the Degé Kangyur between the 1737 <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par      phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings. In the latter case,    an extra work, <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bodhi­maṇḍasyālaṃkāra­lakṣa­dhāraṇī</title> (Toh 508, <title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">byang chub      snying po’i rgyan ’bum gyi gzungs</title>), was added as the second text in the volume,    thereby displacing the pagination of all the following texts in the same volume    by 17 folios. Since the eKangyur follows the later printing, both references    have been provided, with the highlighted one linking to the eKangyur viewer.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT-->  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT]">In the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of the text there is a slight discrepancy in the folio numbering between the 1737 <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings of the Degé Kangyur. Although the discrepancy is irrelevant here, further details concerning this may be found in <ref target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix>   </ref> of the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

That way the alternate text will display a shorter note that simply references the longer one (For example, see how the note is displayed differently in Toh 212 and Toh 520).

To confirm that the W22084 folio is correct please use the Dege-scan checking script. Note, that BDRC, AIBS, and even the Vienna site are not reliable in terms of distinguishing the "par phud" vs "post par phud" pagination in Vol. 88.

***Special Case for Volume 100, 101, 102, and 103 of the Degé Kangyur*** These volumes are all misplaced by one volume in the eKangyur, so "volume 100" will be "volume 101" in the eKangyur, etc. If this is indeed the case, the adjustment should be made in the <location> found in the <sourceDesc>, however the <biblscope> should not be changed but reflect the correct volume as the text appears in the BDRC. For example, here is the <sourceDesc> for Toh 846a:

<sourceDesc>  <bibl key="toh846a" type="text">   <ref>Toh 846a</ref>   <biblScope>Degé Kangyur, vol. 100 (gzungs ’dus, e), folio 3.b.(p.6)</biblScope>   <location count-pages="1"    work="UT4CZ5369">    <volume end-page="6" number="101"     start-page="6"/>   </location> <!--...-->  </bibl> </sourceDesc>

Additionally, a note about this discrepancy should be placed somewhere in the introduction. As before, if the text includes duplicates at different Toh numbers, then the note will need to include alternate messages applied by using the @key attribute in the <p> elements within the note. The template for this note is as follows:

<note place="end">  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 100-103 TEXT]">This text, Toh <fix>###</fix>, and    all those contained in this same volume (<foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">    <fix>XXXX, X</fix>   </foreign>), are listed as being located in volume  <fix>###</fix> of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the    eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Room—list this work as being located in volume <fix>###</fix>.    This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzungs ’dus</foreign> section    are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku    catalog placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the  <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Vimala­prabhā­nāma­kālacakra­tantra­ṭīkā</title> (<title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od</title>,    Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come    right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in    the same volume as the Kangyur <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar chags</foreign> (catalog). Please note this discrepancy    when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT-->  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT">Note that there is a discrepancy among various databases for    cataloging the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text within vol. <fix>###</fix> or <fix>###</fix> of the Degé Kangyur. See Toh <fix>####</fix>, <ref target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix>   </ref>, for    details.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

See an example how the note is displayed Toh 729 and Toh 1001


Please place the note in the introduction wherever it makes sense, for instance when explaining where the text is found in the Kangyur, and so on. Adapt it to the volume number, e.g., "gzung ’dus e", or as appropriate if the text appears in two volumes. If needed you can see how it was adapted and placed in the following examples that have already been approved by the editors of the texts: Toh 846, 846a, 847 (145), 848 (522), 980 (212, 520).

Appendix A.7 Transform and Edit the Glossary

Appendix A.7.1 Set Up the Glossary Document:

  • Note that there are now two format options available for the Glossary: (1) The Glossary may be entered into an Excel spreadsheet, ".XLSX" file type; or, (2)The glossary may be entered into the 84000 Glossary Template, ".DOCX" file type. There are some advantages for using the template instead of Excel: (1) Italics may be tagged with the various styles (foreign terms, titles, mantras etc...) from the template, which will then be converted into the proper XML tags by the script. (2) The spell checker’s automatic underlining is available, unlike in Excel. (3) You will be able to avoid the general glichiness of working in Excel (apostrophes, unwanted cells going through script, etc...). The 84000 Glossary Template is posted on the Translator Tools page under the "copyeditors" tab. If you wish, you may transfer the tables over in to this template (instructions for how to do so are explained within the template), however you should first check the Tibetan column in the Excel file for apostrophe errors (see below "Using a Macro to Correct Initial Apostrophes" or instructions in template).
  • Before transforming the glossary with the script, whether from Excel or the Template, make sure that the tables are formatted properly. In Excel, there should be three or four sheets labeled "Terms", "People", "Places", and on occasion there will be a fourth sheet that should be labeled "Texts", in the template these are preloaded tables with the same four headings. If the labels of the sheets/headings aren't spelled exactly like this, then the script won't apply the correct type to the <gloss> elements. Each sheet/table needs to have five columns that are to be exactly arranged as follows: (A) Tibetan Wylie, (B) Sanskrit, (C) Translation, (D) Definition, and (E) Alternatives.
  • Note that occasionally you may get a glossary with an additional column of Chinese terms. If this is the case, add Chinese as a sixth column (F). If you need to edit the Chinese from the table side by side with the Tibetan and Sanskrit, that is fine just be sure to move the Chinese column into the sixth place before you convert the file or else the cells will be applied incorrectly by the script.

Appendix A.7.2 Using a Macro to Correct Initial Apostrophes:

  • When you receive a glossary file in an Excel spreadsheet format, it’s likely there will be hidden apostrophes in the wylie column. This happens when a straight apostrophe is typed at the beginning of the word, as in the case of an a-chung prefix, "འ". Excel uses straight apostrophes to override the cell's format when typing numbers so that it considers it as text. In the process it hides this initial apostrophe, although there actually is an apostrophe in the cell, i.e., it disappears unless one actually clicks on the cell and looks in the text box at the top of the screen. In some cases the translator may have entered two apostrophes by mistake, or put one where there shouldn't be one. In all cases, these will need to be corrected, as the translator should not use straight apostrophes in the wylie text at all, but only use left curving apostrophes (’) (otherwise the script will not display proper Tibetan Unicode below them). Interestingly, the invisible apostrophes are not carried over if you copy a table and paste it into the Glossary Template, However, these initial apostrophes still need to be checked because the author may have thought they had correctly placed one into the beginning of a cell, but then the apostrophe will have disappeared and won't get carried over to the Template. To make this check and fix any errors, you should run the following macro in Excel. This macro will convert each initial straight apostrophe. However, most often these are a spelling error in the wylie transliteration and will need to be corrected (each instance must be verified in a Tibetan dictionary). To make these instances easy to find, the macro also adds “111” so that it’s easy to make a search for these cells. The “111” is just a marker and will obviously need to be removed too.
  • In case you don't know how to run a macro in Excel, there are many tutorials available on Youtube for both PC and Mac. There might be some differences depending on the version of your Excel software, but they should be pretty straightforward. You may be prevented from running a macro if the file is "shared"; you may have to go to the "Review" tab, click on "Share Workbook," and uncheck the box to share the file with other users (this might be slightly different on Mac). Then you should be able to run the macro without any problem. Here is the macro. Paste the following code into a module window and hit "run":

    Sub AposChange()
    Dim Rng As Range, Cell As Range
    ThisWorkBook.Activate
    Set Rng = Cells.SpecialCells(xlConstants)
    Cells(Rows.Count, Columns.Count).Copy
    For Each Cell In Rng
    If Cell.PrefixCharacter = "'" Then
    Cell.Value = "111 ’" + Cell.Value
    Cell.PasteSpecial Operation:=xlPasteSpecialOperationAdd
    End If
    Next Cell
    Application.CutCopyMode = False
    End Sub

  • Here is an example. When you look at the spreadsheet you will see:
    ’khor ba ’jig
    But in the file there is actually a hidden apostrophe:
                    '’khor ba ’jig
    So after running the macro script it will become:
    111 ’’khor ba ’jig
    In this example there should be no hesitation about what to remove, but in other cases you may need to check in the dictionary.
  • Note this macro only runs on one sheet at a time, and it only works on the first sheet in a .xlsx document, so you will need to copy the second and third sheet into new spreadsheet files, open each sheet separately in Excel, and then run the macro separately for each. (Sorry this is such a long process, this is probably a good reason for us to do all the glossaries from an MS Word template in the future.)

Appendix A.7.3 Transform the Glossary with the XSLT Script:

  • This transformation may be done through the submissions form in the project management app, just the same way you converted the main text, (see instructions again at A.2). Alternatively you may convert the file through oxgarage, (currently this is needed if the .docx from the glossary template is used, although the submissions form will be updated to import this soon). Go to oxgarage at: http://www.tei-c.org/oxgarage/ or its mirror. Select either the option to change a Spreadsheet “Microsoft Excel .xlsx” (if using spreadsheet), or the option to change a Document “Microsoft Word .docx” (if using the Template), convert this to “TEI P5 XML Document.”
  • Download and open the XML in oXygen and use the .xslt stylesheet to transform the XML document. To do this:
    • A. Click on “Configure Transformation Scenarios” (it should be a wrench with a red arrow on the oXygen ribbon).
    • B. Select “New” > “XML transformation with XSLT.”
    • C. For the XSL URL: click on the drop-down menu next to the folder and select “Browse Data Source Explorer.”
    • D. Select the appropriate script in the apps/84000-import-data/xsl folder: It is the script called "oxGto84000-gloss.xsl" If you get a permissions error email the tech specialist (Dominic) and ask him to give you permissions to open the file.
    • E. For the “Transformer” confirm that “Saxon-PE 9.8.0.12” or the latest "Saxon-" transformer is selected from the drop-down menu.
    • F. Click on the “Output” tab and check the box that says “Open in Editor.”
    • G. Click OK, and then select “apply associated” (the transformation scenario you just made should be ticked under “projects”).
  • If you get the script to work, or have someone else convert it for you, you can then paste it into the XML text you are working on. Use another already-published TEI file as a model.
  • The script should be able to convert all three sheets in the combined .xlsx file in one go and create the appropriate type attribute (term, person, or place) if the sheets were labeled properly. However, if one of the sheets isn't converting properly, try breaking the three sheets into three separated .xlsx files and converting each one individually.

Appendix A.7.4 Editing the Glossary:

  • Edit the glossary. Note that when you save the file to the database it will add the “xml:id” automatically so you don’t need to worry about adding these. You will probably need to remove several empty <item> elements that were converted from empty cells at the bottom of each sheet. Also remove entries that were converted from the spreadsheet's headings i.e., Tibetan, Sanskrit, Translation, Definition, etc.
  • If Chinese terms were in the sixth column of the table, those Chinese terms will be assumed to be Chinese characters and will be set to xml:lang="zh" by default. If they are actually romanized transliteration of Chinese then the xml:lang attribute should ="Zh-Ltn"
  • Note that the database will also automatically generate Tibetan script and add it as a <term xml:lang="bo"/> element based on the Wylie glossary entries. The code should look within the glossary for any <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn"/> and create the matching "bo" term wherever there isn't one. So be sure to save the file, close it, reopen, and check that the Tibetan entries have been properly added.
  • Check for errors and make sure the tags are nested properly. Use a previously-edited 84000 TEI XML as a model. You might want to save it first so that it automatically adds all the attributes and so forth.
  • If you used the spreadsheet, then by default the script will place all italics found in the definitions column into <fix> tags, and you will need to go in and change these into the proper tags and add the proper type and xml:lang attributes as needed. For the template these tags should all be generated according to the styles used within the template (or it will tag them with <fix> if any italics were missed).

Appendix A.7.5 Check for Errors in the Wylie Input:

  • Often many spelling typos can slip through into the glossaries without even the editors being aware. The markup provides a final check to assure that spelling errors don't fall through and contaminate the cumulative glossary. You are in an apt position to do this because the script will generate Tibetan Unicode from the Wylie input and spelling errors are much easier to spot in the Tibetan script displayed from the reading room or glossary editing app. You can either check the entries Tibetan spelling now, or if you prefer do it when you look through the final web display (Step A.10), just please be sure to make a thorough check at some point in the markup process. The following are some helpful tips and resources for checking the Tibetan spelling:
  • The Glossary App from Project Management is very helpful, and for shorter texts this is the easiest way to check that the terms are spelled correctly, by seeing their direct correspondence in the eKangyur. To open the Glossary App go to Project Management and select the "Edit Glossary" link next to the text.
  • Unfortunately the Glossary App currently has a lot of lag and will not be efficient for larger texts. For larger texts, I suggest downloading the eKangyur text and searching it with a fast text editor that displays Tibetan Unicode (Atom, Sublime Text, Notepad++). To obtain a digital eKangyur version of any text for searching in the text editor, go to Utilities and click on the version that says "...bo.txt" for example, "toh83-bo.txt". I prefer to search the files with a line break at each folio ref and simplify the confusing tags. To do this use the following regex:

  • SEARCH:

    {{page:{number:\d+,folio:(\d+[ab]),volume:\d+}}}

    REPLACE:

    \n[f$1]

  • Go through every glossary item, if anything looks like it could be misspelled, or if you are not certain about the spelling of that term, check it against the eKangyur.
  • Particles: Beware of misspelled particles; very often an incorrect case particle (དུ་ཏུ་སུ་-ར་ -- ཀྱི་གྱི་གི་-འི་), these are very easy for the editors to miss, and if they slip through they will create problems for the cumulative glossary, so if anything looks suspicious please double check it against the eKangyur.
  • Archaic Spelling Forms: Occasionally there are archaic spellings or alternate spelling preserved in the eKangyur, so if something looks misspelled, please confer first with the Kangyur, as it does contain many unusual spelling forms that I assume we want to preserve.
  • Tibetan Transliterated Sanskrit: It is very important to always check terms containing transliterated Sanskrit, as very often these will not have been entered with correct extended Wylie. As extended-Wylie is very precise, if anything is entered incorrectly, it will create gobbledygook in the Tibetan Unicode field. Often the translator has not used proper Wylie at all, and so all of the transliterated terms will need to be re-entered from the eKangyur. (By the way, this is not ideal, the translator may have consulted the Pedurma or other Kangyur editions when corroborating the spelling of glossary terms; if they did this but did not use proper extended-Wylie then that corroborative research will have to be thrown out and we will need to fall back on the eKangyur--either that or ask the translator to redo it.) Note that the easiest and laziest way to assure the extended-Wylie is correct is to paste the Tibetan Unicode into the THLib transliteration app. It's good to forward this to any translators or editors that may be unaware.
  • Errors in eKangyur: There are indeed some errors in the eKangyur. If you see suspicious spelling or a singular transliterated Sanskrit term in the eKangyur it may be good to occasionally check. Use the Dege Scan Checking script here. If you notice an error please report it in the spreadsheet here.
  • Delete Tibetan Field: Remember to delete Tibetan Unicode field after making a correction to the Wylie field. Otherwise the Tibetan Unicode will not be regenerated and the error will remain.

At this point all the basic editing for the Glossary should be complete. However, there is still some work to be done regarding how the glossary terms are being linked within the text. However, this step is better done on step A.10 when you are going through and looking at the web display. This section will also refer you to Appendix C which explicitly define the guidelines for how the Glossary terms are to be linked in the Reading Room. However, don't worry about this yet, the guidelines will step you through that process when you reach that stage at A.10 below.

Appendix A.8 Add Optional Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit Chains

Next, optional soft-hyphens should be entered for any long Sanskrit chains. The guidelines for doing this are shown in Appendix E: Guidelines for entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit.

Appendix A.9 Add Links For References (Both In-Text and External)

  • Create links for any references in the text, e.g., "see page ###" or "see Bibliography." Links for in-text references are created with the <ptr> element and external references (to other 84000 texts or other web pages) are created with the <ref> element. Links to Kangyur/Tangyur texts that are not yet published should be marked with a the coded comment <Reference Toh #### F.###.b>.
  • It is also important to check the introduction and endnotes for any intext references to chapters or sections and add <ptr> tags anywhere the reader might want to follow a link. In the introduction the translator may have pointed out sections of the translation using Dege folio references; unless these mentions are specifically referring to the Tibetan source text or the structure thereof, these folio references should be changed to the milestone numbers generated in the Reading Room -- according to what can be referenced most conveniently by the reader.
  • For further guidelines for creating links see Appendix B.4: Cross References and Links.

Appendix A.10 See how the Text Looks on the Web Page

  • Go through the text again in web display, making sure everything looks okay.
  • It is helpful at this point to put the web page in “editor mode.” This underlines the linked glossary terms for you. Otherwise, in the regular display, it underlines them but then they will disappear after a few seconds, which will be frustrating when your are checking the links.
