An additional benefit of editor mode is that all of the collapsed sections of the text (Intro, Translation, Notes, etc...) will be expanded by default, so that you can more easily search for terms in the web display with CTRL-F. To put the page in editor mode, simply add the following text to the end of the URL web address: ?view-mode=editor
  • At this point you should check to see that the glossary is linking to the right terms. In the summary and introduction in particular there may be many instances of a word linking to the glossary when it shouldn’t, for example in the phrase “in terms of…” the word “term” might link to the glossary for the technical meaning of “term”; or to take another example, in the phrase “with respect to…” the word “respect” might link to “respect” as in devotion (these are just two out of many examples). Note, the translator guidelines [G4] instructs translators to flag instances of glossary terms that are only relevant to specific passages with the “†” symbol. They are also instructed to specify glossary entries as verbs (vb), nouns (n), or adjectives (adj) in cases where the glossary entry is only intended to link to one form of the word and not others, for example "play" or "appropriate". If they have done so then, don't leave these markers in the text, but replace them with the markup described in the following section. However, it is likely that a lot of these terms will be missed so you should also scan through the text in editor mode for any of these improperly linked terms.
  • Also check that the highlighted terms correspond to their definition given in the Glossary. For example, although term ཁམས་ can refer to the 18 dhatus, it can also sometimes refer to the 4 or 5 elements (earth, air, fire, water and space--although usually the term འབྱུང་པ་/པོ་ is used for this set). Both cases may be translated by the English word "element," but if the definition only mentions the 18 dhatus, then instances of the latter case of the 4 or 5 elements should not be linked.
  • To fix these instances add the <term type="ignore"> tag to the ones that should not be linked. Optionally the mode attribute may be added to the <gloss> element in the glossary. If the mode is set to mode="match" (this is the default mode, by the way), you will be able to block strings in the text you don't want to link by marking them with this <term type="ignore"> tag. If you change it to mode="marked", it will only link with strings in the text that are tagged with the <term> element (you will need to mark each instance of the term individually in this case).
  • In these cases you can save yourself some time when choosing between the "marked" or "match" modes. It is good to think about which mode will require the least amount of tags. Usually this will be the default "match" mode, but it varies from case to case.
  • In some cases there may be three or more glossary entries with the same word. For example, if three people in the text have the same name. In this case, the instances may be distinguished using mode="marked" and adding @ref ids to all the instances of that name marked with a <term> element. Please see Appendix C for details and examples of this.
  • If there are any instances in the web display where there is a term in the glossary that is showing "0 instances in this text" (in the right-hand column of the glossary), you should find out if that term is actually in the text. There may be a spelling error, a diacritic error, or some other reason why it isn't linking to the glossary entry. Sometimes there is a glossary term that really isn't in the text (possibly because it was in the introduction and later removed). If this is the case make a note about it in the final list of questions and issues to address when you have finished the text.
  • There are several subtle points for polishing the final glossary. In some cases alternatives may need to be added to link particular terms and in some cases the glossary terms will need to be checked against the original Tibetan. So we have created a separate Appendix C that explains how the glossary works, along with a few further tips for editing it. Please take a look at Appendix C here.

Appendix A.11 Search Other Published Texts for Links to the Text You Have Just Finished

As has been mentioned above, any cross references that should be linked to future publications have been marked by a coded comment: <Reference Toh #### F.###.b>. After the four digit Toh number the folio number is optional, you can also add "-#" if it is a large text divided into chapters like the Vinaya, but the initial of this string up to the fourth digit of the Toh number must follow this exact format. This is so the comment may be found in a search at the time when that future text is published.

Conjointly, now that you have nearly completed the markup for a new text to be published, you should search through all of the previously published texts for this same string with the Toh number of this text you are just about to complete. It is important that this step is done after the milestones have been finalized, as cross links usually will linked by targeting those specific milestones.

To search for references in previously published texts, go to the data source explorer in oxgyen and right-click on the "translations folder" (For now just the Kangyur translations will suffice, but the Tengyur translations will need to be searched as well whenever we start publishing those).

After right-clicking select "Find/Replace in Files". With this command you can search all the published files for the following string: Reference Toh ####

(be sure that the "Ignore extra whitespaces" box is checked. This will ensure that the code is found even if it occurs across a line break.)

So for example you would search Reference Toh 0120 for Toh 120. Now you will find any cross references that need to be updated. Go into those texts and update those links by removing the comment and adding a <ref> that targets the URL of the appropriate milestone. For guidelines on creating cross textual links see Appendix B.4: Cross References and Links.

Appendix A.12 Final Details

A few final things to look out for while going through your final run of the text:

  • Check for extra unwanted blank spaces.
  • Check the long title, main title in the translation, and title in trailer; check the use of the terms "Mahāyāna" vs. "Great Vehicle" is this consistent? It's fine if varying terms are used in the notes and introduction but these instances in the translation itself should be consistent.
  • Double check links and make sure they go to the right places.
  • Make sure links aren't missing. Sometimes if the little "#" is missing or misplaced in the "target" attribute in the <ptr>s then the reference won't appear at all and you will see text like "(see above, .)" without anything coming after it.
  • Do a search for comment tags that may refer to issues that haven't been addressed. To find them you can do a quick search for "<!--".
  • Search through the text and correct any erroneous straight apostrophes and quote marks. Note that the translator guidelines says to use typographical apostrophes and quote marks (‘ ’ “ ”) not straight ones (' "). All Wylie Tibetan transliteration of the a-chung character should use a right-curling apostrophe ’ not a left-curling one. One exception to this rule is for strings of Sanskrit transliteration which may use a straight apostrophe ' to represent the avagraha character; this is allowed so long as it is done consistently. Otherwise straight apostrophes should be avoided unless there is some pertinent reason to include them. These straight apostrophes and quotes are easy to miss and often can slip unnoticed into our publications, so please run the following searches before submitting your final markup:
    • (1) Check for straight apostrophes ' : This is easily done with a search-and-replace command for the ' character. Just make sure you check each one, most of them will need to be replaced with right-curling apostrophes but some will need to be replaced with a left-curling one.
    • (2) Check for straight double quote marks " : This is a little trickier as straight quote marks are used in the XML tags. To find them in the text and ignore all the tags open the CTRL/SHIFT/H, select "All open files" in the scope and search for the straight double quote " but in the field that says "Restrict to XPath:" enter the code //text() this will search for the straight double quote only in the text but not the tags.
    • (3) Check for left-curling apostrophe in Wylie Transliteration: Again use the XPath/XQuery and search for //*[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(data(), "‘")]
    • (4) Occasionally the unicode for a "modified word apostrophe" (U+02BC) may have been entered into the document. These look identical in the Oxygen editor and in most fonts in general. However they display inconsistently with each other in the Reading Room and can interfere with data searches in the Tibetan Wylie. Since this unicode has been depreciated in most word processors it is unlikely to occur, but you should check for any (U+02BC)s by searching the following character: ʼ and all of these should be replaced with right curling single quote marks (U+2019), which you can paste using this character here: ’ (They look the same but they are not. Notice with the Unicode identifier at the bottom of the screen in Oxygen)
  • For any links created with the <ref> element be sure that none of the links were accidently set to forward the reader to a page on collaboration or in one of the editor view modes. This can be checked by doing a simple search for "view-mode" and "read.84000-translate.org".
  • Within the text's introduction and body <note>s should always be flush with the preceding character with no space between them. Occasionally, the <note> element may be separated by a linebreak in the XML when it is formatted or when it originally went through the script. To correct these instances you can search the regular expression: \s+<note place="end" and replace with <note place="end"
  • Check folio <ref>s inside <mantra>s. There is currently a rare bug where if there is a folio reference, e.g., <ref type="folio"/> inside a <mantra> element and that element is flush with the preceding <p> element, then the folio ref will not link in the reading room. For example:
    <p><mantra>This is a mantra. <ref cRef="F.102.a" type="folio"/></mantra></p>
    In this example the folio reference F.102.a will not display the eKangyur when it is clicked in the reading room. In this rare situation where they are directly next to each other (if there is any characters between them like a quote mark, space, or letter this problem doesn't occur), the fix for this is to simply put a single line break between the <p> and <mantra>. So from the example above:
    <p> <!--A line break is placed here in the XML-->  <mantra>This is a mantra. <ref cRef="F.102.a" type="folio"/>  </mantra> </p>
    (This is a line break in the XML itself NOT an <lb> element). This will not alter the text in anyway as it appears in the reading room but it will fix the broken link for F.102.a to the eKangyur. To search for this issue you can simple search with this regular expression: <p[^>]+?><mantra . This will find any <mantra>s flush against the <p> element, and you can add the line break or just ignore it if there is no <ref>s inside the mantra. This is an issue that you should check if there are any formatted mantras in the text. Eventually we will bring this up with eXist to fix this bug, but in the meantime this should be checked like this at the end of markup.
  • Address any final schema errors. Occasionally, the schema may need to be updated to accommodate a new type of formatting. Or, if a note uses a term in a language that hasn't been used in a published text yet, then that ISO 639-1 code may need to be added to the schema. In either case contact me about this (Celso) and I will add adjust the schema as needed.
  • Note any formatting or anything else that just looks wrong or awkward.
  • Make note of any grammar or editing errors that you think may have been missed in the copy editing phase. You can also add this to your final list of questions and issues.
  • Run Automated Tests from Utilities
    As a final step run the series of automated tests from the Translations Tab on the Utilities Page. You will find a link next to the text title that says "Run tests". Note these are the same tests that are performed from the "Tests" tab, but this "Run tests" link only performs them on the individual text (running tests on all the texts at once uses a lot of the server's resources so this should only be done when testing global updates). It the server will perform a series of tests and display the results. If any of the tests fail, click on that entry and it should display the explanation for the error. Most of these you should be able to resolve, but on occasion there may be an error that is difficult to diagnose or sometimes there is a unique anomaly causing the error and the test itself needs to be updated. In either case please notify the lead tech (dominic.latham@84000.co) about any of the test failures that can't be resolved.

Appendix A.13 List any Outstanding Issues from the Reading Room Revisions Sheet

  • As you work on the text, make a running list of any problems or issues that you cannot fix yourself and make this into a final list of questions and issues. There are often a lot of things that come up: some of them should be addressed by the project editor, some by a copyeditor and some issues may need be updated in the schema or addressed by the technician. This list should be pasted into the Reading Room Revisions spreadsheet, which you can access through this link. There are several sheets within this document. Use the sheet entitled "Texts in Markup" and create a new heading for the text you are working on. There are also workflow instructions for how to post issues within the Reading Room Revisions sheet itself, at the very top of the "Texts in Markup" sheet.
  • You may find solutions to these issues as you go, and if you just need your solutions or corrections to be checked by one of the editors, then assign the first "status" column with the orange label "check". Otherwise assign any new issues as "new".
  • From the "Pending on" column you can assign this issue to appropriate party to check:
    • Any copyeditor issues (spelling, grammar, and style issues) may be assigned to Laura (laura.goetz@84000.co), or as a backup Konchog (konchog@84000.co).
    • Any authoritative editorial issues should be assigned to the project editor for that text.
    • In general we want to avoid burdening the editorial directors (John and Andreas), with editorial problems that could be resolved by the project editors, but sometimes there may be some important issues that require a directorial decision. In such cases, first check with the manager of publications, Mike (mike.engle@84000.co) and he will forward such issues to the directors as is necessary.
    • If the text is displaying correctly but the schema needs to be updated (a new element or value, e.g., xml:lang needs to be validated) Notify Celso (celso.wilkinson@84000.co).
    • Any technical issues to do specifically with the webdisplay/parser should be addressed to Dom (dominic.latham@84000.co) and cc Celso as well.
  • As mentioned in the sheet's workflow instructions, you can assign issues to specific parties by making a comment and typing the "@" or "+" character, then selecting them from a drop down list. Or, if you prefer it's fine to just email that person directly. It's best to give a suggestion for how the issue may be resolved either from the "comments" column or by email if necessary.
  • Occasionally, for issues that everyone may want to discuss, you can also notify or email one of the departments as a whole with the following groups:
    • 84000-markup-editors@googlegroups.com -- address all markup.
    • 84000-copyeditors@googlegroups.com -- all copyeditors.
    • all_editors@84000.co -- addresses all project editors (cc's John and Andreas for overview).
  • As these issues are resolved please clean up your text's section in the review sheet. For anything that is fully resolved you can mark its status as "archive" and move it to the "resolved archive" sheet (or just delete it if it is inconsequential). If it seems to be an issue that may come up again and may be useful to reference in the future, you can also add it to the "reference archive" sheet.
  • When all the final issues have been resolved or noted for the final review in the Reading Room Revisions sheet, notify the lead markup editor; the markup will be reviewed one more time them and then they will update the status to "2", ("Markup Completed, and awaiting final proofing before release").
  • If there are any parts of this TEI editor's checklist that need to be clarified or updated you can contact Celso to make those updates. You can either assign the task to him on the Reading Room Revisions Sheet or email him at celso.wilkinson@gmail.com.

return to table of contents

Appendix B Topics

Appendix B.1 Italics

In a given text, words or phrases may be italicized for different reasons. The need to express both presentation information (that text is italicized) as well as the semantic information about why it is italicized must be addressed. That is why instead of simply using the <hi> element, for example, the voices below form the markup menu for text that needs to be italicized:

  • <distinct> terms, words, or phrases singled out (in any language, but use this only when a "foreign" tag is not applicable).
  • <emph> words or phrases italicized for emphasis or rhetorical effect.
  • <foreign xml:lang=""> foreign words or phrases in any language.
  • <foreign type="term" xml:lang=""> a foreign term or phrase other than a quote or title, such as a term or phrase in parentheses following its translation, or a foreign term or phrase left untranslated.
  • <title xml:lang=""> title of a work (in any language).
  • <foreign xml:lang="__-Ltn"> Wylie or other type of Roman transliteration (excluding European languages, which should not have the "-Ltn" appendage).
  • <foreign type="quote" xml:lang=""> quotations from other texts.
  • <mantra> should be used to italicize complete mantras, however this is a bit more complex because some parts of mantras maybe translated into English. See Appendix B.6 for more about how to markup mantras.

Note that sometimes there may be some overlap between what distinguishes the italics tag used for a “term” vs. a “quote.” In such cases you can use your own discretion, but in general italics used for a “term” are for specific a word or phrase that is left un-translated usually because it is technical, untranslatable, or for some other reason. In contrast the italics used for a “quote” are for italics used for a word or phrase citing a specific instance in a source text either to corroborate the English translation, or to note some difference between two or more sources. Both tags are rendered the same in the end, so this isn’t a critical call to make. There is no need spend time looking up italics to determine whether or not they are found in sources, but just keep this general principle in mind when distinguishing the proper tag for italics.

Note that Tibetan script and Chinese characters should be given the xml:lang value of "bo" and "zh" respectively, while Tibetan, Chinese, and Sanskrit romanized transliteration should have the values of "Bo-Ltn," "Zh-Ltn," and "Sa-Ltn" respectively. For other languages use the list of ISO 639-1 codes to find the appropriate xml:lang value. Most often an Asian language will be translated into the Roman script and, therefore, the first letter of the ISO 639-1 code should be capitalized followed by "-Ltn". Thus a Thai term "th" in Romanized script should be coded "Th-Ltn." If the term is a European language or the native script of that language is used, then use the two letter code as usual, e.g., "fr" (French), "la" (Latin), etc.

For the most part, these tags should be added during the copy editing phase in the 84000 Template.docx. In this phase they will be added as styles in MS Word, but will be transformed into the appropriate tag by our scripts. However, as we can't add a style for every language in the template, the markup editor will need look up and edit the tags for any uncommon languages, which will be marked through the script as xml:lang="Input Language." The markup editor should also keep an eye out for errors, or italicized text that was missed. However, the script should render all unmarked italics with a "<fix>" tag, which will be highlighted as an error by the schema.

Appendix B.2 Divisions and Headings

Appendix B.2.1 Types of Divisions

Div elements are used to mark different sections within a text. This is of particular importance as the <head> tag can only follow directly after a "div" marker or another <head> tag. The main sections of the text are marked as follows:

  • <div type="summary"> Wraps the Summary section.
  • <div type="acknowledgement"> Wraps the Acknowledgement section.
  • <div type="prologue"> Wraps the Prologue (if there is one).
  • <div type="preface"> Wraps the Preface (if there is one).
  • <div type="introduction"> Wraps the Introduction.
  • <div type="translation"> Wraps the entire translation.
  • <div type="notes"> Wraps the notes section; this section is needed for displaying abbreviations.
  • <div type="listBibl"> Contains a group of bibl elements, wraps the bibliography.
  • <div type="appendix"> To wrap the appendix of a text, e.g. a Sanskrit Appendix (if there is one).
  • <div type="colophon"> Wraps the colophon. (Note, the schema only allows this nested as a second level div after all second level "sections" and/or "chapters")

Within those major document units or divisions, there are other sub units, especially chapters or their equivalent. Both chapter and section refer to the same hierarchical level in the XML. Chapters are the type value used in the body of the text when they have been specified as chapters by the translator. Section is used for equivalent level sectioning that has not been called a chapter. Examples for the latter are sectioned bibliographies, where the whole of the bibliography has multiple sections organized by source type. In that case <div type="section"> is used instead of <div type="chapter">. From a structural point of view, however, they are the same.

  • <div type="chapter"> Wraps a chapter that is part of the translation.
  • <div type="section"> Wraps a section of the TEI document.

For example:

<div type="chapter">  <head type="chapter">Chapter 26</head>  <head type="chapterTitle">Turning the Wheel of Dharma</head> <!--...--> </div>

and

<div type="listBibl">  <head type="listBibl">Bibliography</head>  <div type="section">   <head type="section">Tibetan Sources</head> <!--...-->  </div>  <div type="section">   <head type="section">Sanskrit Sources</head> <!--...-->  </div> </div>

Appendix B.2.2 Heading for the Body of the Main Translation

The heading of the main section of the translation typically preceded by the section heading "The Translation" and the title honorifics (if applicable), each given a separate heading tag:

<div type="translation">  <head tid="211" type="translation">The Translation</head>  <head tid="212" type="titleHon">The Noble Mahāyāna Sūtra</head>  <head tid="213" type="titleMain">The Questions of Bhadrapāla the Merchant</head>  <div type="section"> <!--... the body of the main translation begins here...-->  </div> </div>

Optionally a subtitle may be added after the main title as seen in Toh 438:

<body>  <div type="translation">   <head tid="12" type="translation">The Translation</head>   <head tid="13" type="titleMain">Praise to Tārā with Twenty-One Verses of Homage</head>   <head tid="51" type="sub">and Their Benefits</head> <!--... etc-->  </div> <!--... etc--> </body>

Appendix B.2.3 Changing the Chapter Numbers

Occasionally, for whatever reason the chapter numbers may need to be altered. For example in Toh 543, many chapters are skipped since a Sanskrit source was matched to the chapters in the Kangyur. The number needs to be displayed as such in the header but also needs to have the proper number prefixed in the table of contents and all the milestones contained within the chapter, all of which will be diverging from the number that is automatically generated by the parser. This can be done by adding a single @prefix attribute to the appropriate chapter's <div> element. e.g.:
<div prefix="24" type="chapter"> <!--...--> </div>
So this chapter and all its milestones will now display the "24" prefix in the reading room even though it isn't the 24th "chapter" division in the TEI file.

Appendix B.3 Outlines and Lists

Sometimes the introduction of a text will provide an outline, particularly in the case of a longer or more complicated text. Within the TEI XML these outlines should be constructed using the <list> and <item> elements. For a complex outline with many levels of subsections, the outline itself should be contained in a list, and each section should be contained in an <item> within that list. Then, for each sub section, a new <list> element should be nested within those <item>s, which in turn contains its own subsections with <item> elements, and so forth for as many subsections as necessary. Note that if the <list> is marked up as type="bullet" it will be indented. A good way to render the outline in a clear way is to mark up the first list as type="section" and all subsequent lists as type="bullet"; then the major sections will be separated by vertical spacing and all the subsections will be indented. For an example see the following outline from "The Baskets Display" (Toh 116): The XML markup from this outline in Toh. 116 is shown below.

<list type="section">  <item>   <p tid="642">I. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni is in the Jetavana Monastery when      lights appear, transforming the monastery’s appearance. Bodhisattva      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin questions Buddha Śākyamuni about this, and the Buddha      states that the cause of the lights is Avalokiteśvara visiting Avīci hell and then      the city of the pretas. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="643">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara appears in the          Avīci hell and liberates beings. As a result, Yama’s creatures go to Yama and          describe Avalokiteśvara’s arrival. Yama goes to Avalokiteśvara and praises          him.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="644">II. Sūtra narrative: Buddha Śākyamuni responds to a question from      Sarvanīvaraṇaviṣkambhin about whether Avalokiteśvara has left the hell. </p>   <list type="bullet">    <item>     <p tid="645">1. Buddha Śākyamuni’s narrative: Avalokiteśvara leaves the hells,          visits the city of the pretas, and liberates them from their suffering. This          very sūtra sounds in their realm.</p>    </item>   </list>  </item> <!--... etc.--> </list>

This will allow the outline to be properly displayed in the 84000 reading room. For more simple outlines that have a one-level list, use the <list> with type="bullet" if the items are one or two sentences long (for an example, see Toh. 11 here), and use type="section" if the items are longer sections of text (see also Toh. 11 here). The "bullet" and "section" types can be used in alternation however they are needed, just note that "section" will have vertical spacing between each item, and "bullet" will be indented.

The <head> element resting within the <list> tag, but outside of the <item> tag can be used to create a bold heading at the top of a list. Alternatively, within an <item> tag a <label> attribute may be used to the same effect. See Toh. 11 again for an example, along with the following XML markup from that same section:

<list type="section">  <item>   <list type="section">    <head tid="3187">I. UNDERSTANDING OF ALL PHENOMENA</head>    <p tid="33">The first fourteen chapters of the text concern the theoretical        understanding of all phenomena, which is the first goal to be realized.        Śāradvatī­putra acts as Lord Buddha’s interlocutor in the first nine chapters,        with Su­bhūti making his initial appearance in chapter 10. </p>    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-031-002-47"/>    <item>     <label>Chapters 1 and 2</label>     <p tid="35">In response to a question about what is the transcendent perfection          of wisdom which bodhisattvas are to perfect, Lord Buddha replies that it is          the absence of fixation with respect to all phenomena, all meditative          experiences, all causal attributes acquired by bodhisattvas, all fruitional          attributes manifested by buddhas, and all attainments up to and including          omniscience. along with unconditioned phenomena, such as the abiding nature of          all things and the finality of existence, these are all attributes with          respect to which a great bodhisattva being should cultivate detachment.          Bodhisattvas do perceive such phenomena distinctly, but only on the relative          level; in an ultimate sense they consider them to be illusory, in the manner          of a dream and so forth. </p>    </item>    <milestone unit="chunk"     xml:id="UT22084-031-002-48"/>    <item>     <label>Chapter 3</label>     <p tid="37">Fixation may ensue when those phenomena and attributes are          considered as permanent or impermanent, as conducive to happiness or          suffering, with self or without self, empty or not empty, with signs or          signless, having or lacking aspirations, calm or not calm, void or not void,          afflicted or purified, arising or not arising, ceasing or not ceasing, and as          entities or non-entities. Deluded minds would view these phenomena and          attributes as absolutely existent whereas bodhisattvas should train so as to          understand that they are all non-apprehensible—mere designations and          conceptualizations. </p>    </item> <!--...etc...-->   </list> <!--...etc...-->  </item> <!--...etc...--> </list>

Note, that there is one additional style option, in which the attribute @rend="dots", "numbers", or "letters" may be used to create a list with an automatically generated prefix (bullet, number, or letter respectively) and a hanging indent. This can be done in combination with a @type="section" list or a @type="bullet" list. Here is an example from Toh 674:

<list rend="dots" type="bullet">  <item>   <p tid="35">The name <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshe dpag tu med pa</foreign>      (Aparimitāyus), which occurs a number of times here in Toh 674, is given its longer form      in Toh 675: <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshe dang ye shes dpag tu med pa</foreign>      (Aparimitāyur­jñāna). </p>  </item>  <item>   <p tid="36">The name of Aparimitāyur­jñāna’s realm here in Toh 674 is <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">yon        tan dpag tu med pa sogs pa</foreign> (Aparimita­guṇa­saṃcaya, “Accumulation of Immeasurable      Qualities”), but in Toh 675 the first mention of it is just <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">yon tan dpag        tu med pa</foreign> (Aparimitaguṇa, “Immeasurable Qualities”). </p>  </item> <!--...--> </list>

Note that <list>s along with their <item>s can be generated from the template .docx passed through our XSLT script. In MS Word, lists are auto-generated either by clicking the list icons on the menu bar or by entering a "1" or "*" and on a new line and hitting the space key. These lists will be rendered by the XSLT script with nested <list> and <item> tags. It can render multi-leveled lists or outlines, however they need to be auto-generated list in MS Word for them to pass through the script; you can determine that they are auto-generated when in MS Word the cursor will skip over the bullet point or numbered prefix of the list when passed across with the arrow keys. The first level <list> will be tagged type="bullet" by default, but second level lists and beyond will need the type attribute to be entered manually.

Appendix B.4 Cross References and Links

Appendix B.4.1 Internal Links Created with the <ptr> Element:

See also the style guide for cross references in google doc.

  • Milestones:
    Cross references in the text that refer to milestones will be added using a <ptr> element with the "target" attribute. The value of the target should be a hashmark ("#") followed by the xml:id value of the milestone that is to be linked. For example:
    See <ptr target="#UT22084-060-005-1"/> <!--2.3-->.
    The milestone number as it appears on the web page may be listed as a comment afterwards, but it should not be entered as text as the parser will automatically show the milestone number in the web display. This way even if the milestones shift around it will still display and link to the correct milestone on the web page.

    One important point about adding references to the introduction: When you mark up introductions with internal <ptr> references to the translation, replace any Degé folio references (e.g F.108.a) with milestone references. For most readers that will make much more sense. Of course the translators have no choice, because at the time they put such cross-references in there are no milestones.

    If you can’t identify exactly the passage and its milestone, you can leave it as the folio reference, and ask the editors to make the change during the final proofing. And, of course, if the reference is really all (and only) about a Tibetan passage in the source text, and the translation is irrelevant, a folio reference makes more sense.

  • Notes and Bibliography:

    Notes and Bibliography entries work in exactly the same way:, for the target attribute, simply use the xml:id value contained in the <note> or <bibl> element that needs to be linked. You can also link to the general bibliography section with the target value "#bibliography." For example:

    <note>See <ptr target="#bibliography">bibliography</ptr> </note>

Appendix B.4.2 External Links Created with the <ref> Element:

  • Links to Other Texts or Web Addresses:

    If there is a link to a milestone in a different text, rather than using a <ptr>, the <ref> element is used, which should also have a "target" attribute followed by the URL address of the text, followed by a hash tag, followed by the xml:id of the milestone in that other text. For example:

    <note index="586" place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-1485"> Unidentified Indian musical instrument. It appears in two lists of instruments in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Lalita­vistara­sūtra</title> (see <title xml:lang="en">The Play in Full</title>  <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-973">15.39</ref> <!--toh. 95--> and <ref target="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-1001">15.67</ref> <!--toh. 95-->) with a stringed instrument preceding and following it, but some recent Tibetan-English dictionaries have “cymbals.”</note>

  • Links to other websites can be made with the <ref> element in the same manner:

    Kyoto: Educational Department of the West Hongwanji, 1924. <ref target="http://web.mit.edu/stclair/www/smaller.html">web.mit.edu</ref>

    Note that hyperlinks in the original MS Word .docx should go through the XSLT script and be outputted in this form.

  • ***Don't forget, when you create a link to another 84000 text, use the public distribution URL (http://read.84000.co) NOT the collaboration URL; the general readership doesn't have a password to collaboration.

  • Note, if there is an ampersand "&" in the url address this will be read incorrectly in the TEI. The ampersand character itself should be replaced by the ampersand character code "&amp;". The link should now work properly.

Appendix B.4.3 Pending Links to as yet Unpublished Kangyur/Tengyur Texts:

  • When another Kangyur/Tengyur text is referenced that has not yet been published, the editors have been instructed to enter a coded comment in the form: <Reference Toh ####>, sometimes with the folio reference added when it is specified. Of course, you should check to see if the text has been published in the meantime, but if it is still pending, then we should mark the link with a <ref> tag containing the @rend="pending" attribute. This will suppress the link making it inactive, but it will be flagged by our apps when the text is published. However it is important that the correct URL for the unpublished text is entered in the @target attribute so that our apps will pick it up. The URL will follow this form https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER TOH NUMBER HERE].html. Here is an example of a link to a Tengyur text found in the bibliography of Toh 185:
    <bibl xml:id="UT22084-061-005-707">Nāgārjuna. <title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">mdo kun las btus pa</title> (<title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">   <ref rend="pending"    target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh3934.html">Sūtrasamuccaya</ref>  </title>). Toh 3934, Degé Tengyur vol. 110 (dbu ma, ki) folios 148.b–215.a.</bibl>

    ***Note that there is no leading "0"s in the URL, so if the reference code says "Reference Toh 0224" then the URL should be entered as "-toh224.html".

    This is the format to use for all general links to unpublished texts, in which the link will eventually open to the title page of the texts. However, in cases where a specific section of that text is mentioned, which should usually indicated by a folio page reference, the folio reference or other instruction for locating the specitic citation should be added to the <ref> tag in an @inst attribute. For example:
    <note place="end">This sūtra is quoted by Nāgārjuna in the <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">   <ref inst="F.185.a" rend="pending"    target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh3934.html">Sūtrasamuccaya</ref>  </title>. </note>
    Then when Toh 3934 is published. This <ref> tag will be called and the @inst attribute will instruct markup to locate the appropriate milestone and add it with a hashtag to the URL. e.g. https://read.84000.co/translation/toh3934.html#UT22084-999-999-9999.

Appendix B.4.4 Style Guidelines for Adding Kangyur and Tengyur Links:

  • Please read these additional style guidelines concerning how and when to embed these internal/external links. There are important points here about arranging the bibliography entries and how to cite other texts consistently. The guidelines are placed here in a separate google doc so that we may edit and collaborated on these guidelines as we move forward.

Appendix B.4.5 Activating Pending Links:

  • When a text is published and changed to status="1", any cross references to it may be checked from the cross-reference app in Utilities. These links will need to be individually updated in their respective texts. There are important style guidelines to be followed when doing so. Please read the style guidelines in the googledoc here before updating them.

Appendix B.4.6 Linking to Dunhuang Texts on the IDP (International Dunhuang Project) Website

  • Often texts will cite Dunhuang texts. These texts are referenced using the IDP's abbreviations, e.g."IOL Tib J 149", "IOL Tib J 705", etc... The page for the specific text can be found by entering the abbreviation directly into the IDP's search bar here (on the left side where it says "Search the IDP Database"). You should check that the page exists and if it is publicly available. However there is an issue with linking directly with this page. If you open the page it will use an URL with an id number in it such as http://idp.bl.uk/database/oo_scroll_h.a4d?uid=1846009887;bst=1;recnum=5001;index=1;img=1 It seems the part of the URL "uid" shifts so this link will become dead. Instead this alternative URL should be used:
                      http://idp.bl.uk/database/oo_loader.a4d?pm=[ENTER THE IDP ABBREVIATIION HERE];img=1 
    So for example if you want to link to "IOL Tib J 149", then use this URL http://idp.bl.uk/database/oo_loader.a4d?pm=IOL Tib J 149;img=1. This will ensure the link remains stable. For an example, see this note, n.35 from TOH 196.

return to table of contents

Appendix B.5 Tables

Occasionally translators may present a table in their translation. Tables can be used anywhere in the text or even contained within an endnote. The XSL script should be equipped to convert tables from the DOCX document to the TEI XML; however, attributes need to be applied to the <table>s, <row>s, and <cell>s manually (see for example the role="label" attributes found in the <row>s in the XML sample below). Also each table should be checked against the original DOCX to assure that there weren't any errors in the conversion process. So far there have note been many tables in 84000 publications but here is one example from TOH 361:

<table tid="111">  <head type="table">Deity Families</head>  <row role="label">   <cell>Verses</cell>   <cell>Aspect</cell>   <cell>Vajrasattva</cell>   <cell>Mahāsattva</cell>   <cell>Bodhisattva</cell>   <cell>Samayasattva</cell>   <cell>Vajrayoga</cell>   <cell>Kālacakra</cell>  </row>  <row>   <cell role="label">161–63</cell>   <cell role="label">cakra</cell>   <cell>secret</cell>   <cell>navel</cell>   <cell>heart</cell>   <cell>throat</cell>   <cell>forehead</cell>   <cell>crown</cell>  </row>  <row>   <cell role="label">164–69</cell>   <cell role="label">purifies*</cell>   <cell>threefold existence</cell>   <cell>passion</cell>   <cell>hatred</cell>   <cell>delusion</cell>   <cell>anger</cell>   <cell>attachment</cell>  </row>  <note>* Tentative interpretation.</note>  <note>** Alternate common designations in brackets.</note>  <note>*** Reordered to match v. 171cd.</note> </table>

(See how this example is displayed in reading room.)

As you can see a <table> contains an optional heading and a series of <row>s. Each <row> in turn contains a series of <cells> representing the way they are to be rendered from left to right. Add the very bottom of the table after the final <row>, any <note>s may be placed here regarding the table itself. In the example above there are three such <note>s marked by asterisks. These are not endnotes, as they do not have the place="end" attribute, so they will be rendered at the bottom of the table rather than becoming additional endnotes. Optionally, paragraphs <p> may be placed at the bottom of the table in a similar manner, still within the <table> but after the final <row>.

Currently there is no need to distinguish how the table should be rendered, but as this becomes necessary, any rendition information should be supplied using the global rend attribute, at the table, row, or cell level as appropriate. Currently no type is being used, but this may be added to the schema and documentation when it becomes necessary. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent <cell>s are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a <row> contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child <cell>s will be considered to be "label"s as well. These labels will be rendered in bold type in the HTML web display.

Note, when marking up <table>s the markup editor should check that the table renders properly in the reading room's web display. In addition, the table needs to be checked in the ebook display as well. This can be done by adding the code: ?viewmode=epub to the very end of the url address on the utilities page. In truth, the tables are not compatible with the ebook format, so the parser will instead display them as a bulleted list. The information in this list should be presented in a complete and eloquently readable way, otherwise the parser should be updated.

Appendix B.6 Mantras

Documenting all mantras with <mantra> tags.

The tags used for mantras are a bit complicated because our final markup as it is found in the final XML needs to document all of the strings of mantra, but not all the mantra’s text will necessarily be italicized, as in some cases mantras will be translated into English with leftover fragments of foreign italicized terms in the form of seed syllables or untranslatable words (Hung! Phet! etc...). Therefore, as a general rule all mantras, whether in the main text or notes should be marked by a <mantra> tag, however, the italics will be determined by the parser according to the xml:lang attributes in the mantra element: if the value is "en" or "mixed" the mantra won't be italicized, but with any other language value all the text within the <mantra> tag will be italicized. In the case of a mixed translated English/Sanskrit mantra, the Sanskrit fragments within the parent <mantra> need to be additionally marked up with <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn"> elements in order to render the italics. See examples below in "a. General Scenarios."

Tagging mantras with styles in MS Word

To help stream line this process the mantras will be partially marked up by styles converted from the copyeditor template in MS Word, however because MS Word can't layer multiple character styles, we can't tag the foreign fragments and the mantras at the same time. To resolve this conundrum, we have come up with the following solution: If the mantra is full and complete in one language, it can be tagged with the appropriate style in the template, but if the mantra is mixed, then just the italicized fragments should be tagged with a "Fragment-in-MixedMantra" style. This will in turn create a <foreign> element that contains a type="FragmentinMixedMantra" attribute. Then since "FragmentinMixedMantra" is not a valid type value in our schema it will show up as an error, which will signal you to wrap the whole mantra in a <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tag. Finally after these mixed mantras have been wrapped in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tags from their beginning to end, all of the type="FragmentinMixedMantra" attributes can be removed with the refactoring tool: Within the Tools --> XML Refactoring tool, use the "Delete Attribute" opperation, then for element enter in: mantra/foreign[@type="FragmentinMixedMantra"] and for the attribute enter in: type This will insure that only the type attributes will be removed that have the value "FragmentinMixedMantra" and it will also only remove those of <foreign> elements within <mantra>s, this way it will ensure that all of them have first been properly wrapped in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> elements.

Placing some mantras in indented blocks.

In terms of style, whenever there is a formally declared mantra, it will often be placed into an indented block paragraph. This is not configured by the <mantra> tag, but rather by adding a rend="mantra" attribute to the parent <p> or <lg> element which is to be rendered as an indented block by the parser. However, this will not always the case, depending on the length, frequency, and context of the mantra, the translator and/or copy editors may wish to place the mantras in regular paragraphs or verses. This is a stylistic choice that will vary from case to case. All of the rend="mantra" attributes will be created by the script wherever the "Mantra-Block" or "Mantra-Block-Verse" paragraph style is used within the copyeditor's template. So in general, this will be dealt with in the copyediting phase and markup editors will not need to apply these rend attributes, but you should be aware how this markup works.

Dhāraṇis and seed syllables.

Seed syllables that are mentioned in the text for the purposes of visualization or explanation should also be marked up as <mantra>s, but they need to be distinguished with the type="syllable" attribute (see example below a.iv).

For all dhāraṇis, that is if a string or phrase is declared to be a dhāraṇi by either the text itself or the translator, then these should be tagged in the same way, but a type="dharani" attribute should be added to the <mantra> element. Currently "dhāraṇi" styles have not been added to the template, instead copy editors are informed to make a comment whenever dharanis are present. The markup editor need to add the appropriate type="dharani" so be sure to keep an eye out for this while going through the mantras in the XML. There are also some mantras self described as "vidyā", "vidyāmantra", "secret mantra", etc. in some texts (see Toh 270, 543) which can be tagged in the same way.

See below examples for all the scenarios in which <mantra> markup occurs and how to properly mark them up:

a. General Scenarios:

  • i. When the complete mantra in Sanskrit is contained in the main text:

    <lg tid="30">  <l>“There are mantra syllables for this,</l>  <l>So please listen to me, Lord of the World!</l> </lg> <p rend="mantra" tid="464">  <mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">syād yathedam siddhe susiddhe satve are araṇe bale mahābale    jambhe jaṭile akhane makhane khakhane kharaṭṭe kharaṅge haripiṅgale temiṅgile temiṅgile temiṅgile    temiṅgile nimaṃgalye svāhā | </mantra> </p>

    *<mantra> tag will be italicized by parser.
    *rend attribute in the parent <p> or <lg> will determine if the mantra is indented as a block.

    (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

  • ii. When there is mixed translated English/Sanskrit mantra with a note that contains the complete mantra in Sanskrit:

    <lg rend="mantra" tid="1456">  <l>“In the east, ‘<mantra xml:lang="mixed">    <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Oṁ</foreign>, bring      downfall! Pātanī, <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">svāhā</foreign> to you!’   <note index="639" place="end"     xml:id="UT22084-079-008-2057">Skt., <mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">oṁ pāta pātanīsvāhā</mantra>.</note>   </mantra>  </l> <!--...--> </lg>

    *Mixed mantra is placed in <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> tags (need to be applied by markup editor since MS Word can't double wrap tags).
    *Note, the language values that are included in xml:lang=“mixed” are all declared by its child <foreign> elements with the exception of the default “en” English.
    *Italics will be determined by the <foreign> tags and not the parent <mantra> tag.
    *Any left over type="FragmentinMixedMantra" tags are to be removed with the refactoring tool after completing mantra markup.

    (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

  • iii. When the complete mantra in Skt is contained in the text and spans notes:

    <l>On the eyes, <mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">oṁ tuttāre<note index="116" place="end"    xml:id="UT22084-079-008-532"> The Degé      (90a.3) has <foreign type="quote" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ture</foreign> (<foreign type="quote" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tu re</foreign>)      in this position.</note> svāhā</mantra>.</l>

    *Note, When a fragment of a mantra is mentioned in a note quoting an alternate source, do not use a use a <mantra> elment instead use a <foreign type="quote">. However if it is a complete mantra within the note then the <mantra> element should be used.

    (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

  • iv. A syllable referred to in isolation in the text:

    <lg tid="440">  <l>“He should visualize a sun disk</l>  <l>With blazing light rays,</l>  <l>And at its center the syllable <mantra type="syllable" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">hrīḥ</mantra>,</l>  <l>Shining with red light. {2.4.15}</l> </lg>

    (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

  • note. In general, with English/mixed mantras we should include the final period or exclamation mark within the tag, as the mantra is usually a complete sentence and sometimes spans more than one sentences so it makes sense to include them for consistency. However, if the mantra is entirely in Sanskrit, then this punctuation should be excluded if possible. Quotations at the boundaries of the mantra should be excluded from the tag wherever possible.

b. Unusual Scenarios:

  • i. A mantra spans multiple lines of a verse (Toh. 544 1.37):

    <lg rend="mantra" tid="314">  <mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">   <l>eraṇḍasya vane kāko gaṅgātīram upasthitaḥ |</l>   <l>pibatu dūtaḥ pānīyaṃ viśalyā bhavatu gurviṇī ||</l>  </mantra> </lg>

    *Note in this scenario the <mantra> element may wrap around the <l> but if the mantra is contained in a single line, then it should go inside the <l>.
    -Note that for <lg rend="mantra"> element the parser will also display this as an indented block.

    (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

  • ii. A mantra has Sanskrit mixed with Tibetan words:

    <mantra xml:lang="mixed">  <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Oṁ āḥ hūṁ vajra guru padma</foreign>  <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">thöthreng tsal</foreign>  <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">vajra samaya jaḥ siddhi phala hūṁ āḥ</foreign> </mantra>

    (There is not yet a published example of this, but we may see this when we start publishing Nyingma texts).

  • iii. A mantra is entirely translated into English (Toh. 544 1.38):

    <lg rend="mantra" tid="316">  <mantra xml:lang="en">   <l>The crow in a thicket of palma christi </l>   <l>Roosting on the bank of Ganges— </l>   <l>The messenger—may he drink water! </l>   <l>May the pregnant woman be delivered of her child!</l>  </mantra> </lg>

    *Since the mantra is all in English it will not be italicized by the <mantra xml:lang="en"> tag.

    (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

  • iv. 4) When a text explicitly defines a string to be a dhāraṇi (or other designation "vidyā", etc...), this should be indicated by a @type=”dharani”, @type=”vidyā” attribute in the <mantra> element:

    <p> <!--...--> samyaksaṃbuddhas gathered there, and those tathāgatas recited this dhāraṇī: </p> <p rend="mantra" tid="640">  <mantra type="dharani" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Namaḥ saptanām saṃyak­saṃbuddha­koṭinām tadyathā Oṁ cale    cule cunde<note index="298" place="end"    xml:id="UT22084-051-004-798">According to the Tibetan      and Cambridge. The Vaidya and Sāmaśrami have <foreign type="quote" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">cunye.</foreign>   </note> svāhā</mantra>. </p> <p>Note, this sort of classification can be a bit ambiguous. I've recently added other terms that were self-declared in texts such as "vidyā" "vidyā mantra" "secret mantra" (only used the latter when it was distinguished in the same text from other "mantra"s). At some point we could ask a specialist in the topic about which classifications are necessary or useful and update our markup as such.</p>

    (See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

c. Character Style Tags

The following character style tags in the Copyeditor's Template will be converted into the following markup by the conversion script:

  • Mantra-Full-English --> <mantra xml:lang="en">
  • Mantra-Full-Sanskrit --> <mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">
  • Mantra-Full-Tibetan --> <mantra xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">
  • Sa-Fragment-in-MixedMantra --> <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn" type="FragmentinMixedMantra">
  • Ti-Fragment-in-MixedMantra --> <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn" type="FragmentinMixedMantra">
  • Mantra-Syllable-Sanskrit --> <mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn" type="syllable">
  • Mantra-Syllable-Tibetan --> <mantra xml:lang="Bo-Ltn" type="syllable">
  • Mantra-Other --> <mantra xml:lang="input-value" type="input-value">
d. Paragraph Style

The following paragraph style tags in the Copyeditor's Template will be converted into the following markup by the conversion script:

  • Mantra Block --> <p rend="mantra">
  • Mantra Block-Verse --> <lg rend="mantra">
e. Blocking glossary terms from linking to Sanskrit/foreign mantras.

Optionally a @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribut may be added to any <mantra> element. Typically we want to do this for any Mantra left in untranslated Sanskrit since the complex spelling declinations will cause the terms to be linked inconsistently. However it is likely appropriate to leave such terms linked when the mantra has been translated into English. Know that in either case, @rend="ignoreGlossary" will block the entire mantra from linking; or terms can instead be blocked individually by adding <term type="ignore"> tags.

f. Regarding Homages

Typically, the homage preceding just before a mantra should not be included in the mantra tag nor the indented paragraph. This can sometimes be confusing since separate homages sometimes appear as part of the mantra proper. All of this should be worked out earlier in the workflow by the editors and copy editors, but in case you need to confirm this, here are some guidelines concerning the mantras and their homages given by Wiesiek Mical:

Most of the time there is no ambiguity. There are three things to look for when deciding whether the homage is part of the mantra or not, each of the three usually sufficient on its own to decide:

  • 1) The presence of tadyathā. If it is there, then the homage that precedes it is not part of the mantra, as in this mantra of Mahāśvetā (all examples quoted below are from the Mañjuśrīmūlakalpa):
    Sanskrit Source:
    namaḥ samantabuddhānām acintyādbhutarūpiṇām / tadyathā / oṁ śvete śrīvapuḥ svāhā //
    In Translation:
    Homage to all the buddhas whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable! The [vidyā] is:
    <mantra>Oṁ, you with the white splendorous body! Svāhā!</mantra>
    <lg tid="266">  <l>“Homage to all the buddhas,</l>  <l>Whose forms are wondrous and inconceivable!</l>  <l>The next <term>vidyā</term> is:</l> </lg> <p rend="mantra" tid="267">“<mantra type="vidya" xml:lang="mixed">   <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Oṁ</foreign>, you with the white, splendorous    body! <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Svāhā</foreign>!</mantra> </p>

    See in Reading Room

  • 2) But the tadyathā is not always there, as in this heart mantra of Mañjuśrī:
    Sanskrit Source
    namaḥ sarvabuddhānām / oṁ maṁ //
    In Translation
    “Homage be to all the buddhas!
    <mantra>Oṁ maṁ!</mantra>
    <p tid="50"> “Homage to all the buddhas! </p> <p rend="mantra" tid="51">“<mantra xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Oṁ maṁ</mantra>!”</p>

    See in Reading Room

    It is almost a rule (exceptions are few) that the homage begins with namaḥ, and the mantra that follows it begins with oṁ, so the oṁ will usually marks the beginning of the mantra.
  • 3) The third criterion to go by is that the homage addresses the buddhas (or the buddhas and bodhisattvas) in general, whereas the mantra addresses the deity—both examples given above make this clear, even though, in the second, Mañjuśrī is not addressed by name.
    The above three criteria may be used to decide that the homage is not part of the mantra. So how to know when the homage is part of the mantra?
    The main criterion is that the homage in such cases will typically begin with oṁ and address specifically the deity of the mantra (not the buddhas in general). This is illustrated by the example quoted by Celso—Oṁ, homage to Cakravartin, the invincible uṣṇīṣa of the tathāgatas, invisible at the top of their head, (oṁ namo • apratihata­tathāgatoṣṇīṣāya • anavalokita­mūrdhni cakra­varti)—where the homage addresses the uṣṇīṣa king Cakravartin, i.e. the deity that this mantra is invoking. The homage is therefore part of the mantra.
    Even if the oṁ is missing (due to textual corruptions?), if the homage specifically addresses the deity, it still should be treated as part of the mantra:
    Sanskrit Source
    namo bhagavate • apratihatoṣṇīṣāya / ehi ehi bhagavan dharmarāja / pratīccheyam arghyaṃ… //
    In Translation
    <mantra>Homage to the blessed, invincible uṣṇīṣa! Come, come, o blessed Dharma lord! Take this welcome-offering… </mantra>
    <p rend="mantra" tid="10116">“<mantra xml:lang="mixed">Homage to the blessed,    invincible <term ref="UT22084-088-038-15836">uṣṇīṣa</term>! Come, come,    O blessed Dharma lord! Take this welcome offering of water, fragrances,    flowers, incense, refreshments, and lamps, and protect me! <foreign xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Svāhā</foreign> to you, one of invincible strength    and power!</mantra> </p>

    See in Reading Room

    Also, there are innumerable mantras that consist entirely of homage. In these cases, the presence or absence of oṁ is often the only differentiator between a mantra and just homage. For example, oṁ namaḥ śivāya is a mantra, and namaḥ śivāya on its own would by just homage.

Appendix B.7 Punctuation

  • Ellipses: Ellipses are to be made with three periods and non-breaking spaces (U+00A0) before each of the periods. It will look like this: watch out for . . . the rabbit, however please do not copy and paste the ellipsis from here, there is a problem with this ODD being transferred into the readable HTML format, and so the non-breaking spaces have been changed to regular ones. Instead, you may copy the ellipsis from this text file saved on google drive (Don't open the file from Google docs, this will also change them into regular spaces). When you paste the ellipsis into the TEI and place the cursor in front of each space the first three spaces should all be non-breaking and it will display "U+00A0" in the bottom right corner of the Oxygen window. Note that the fourth space after the last period should be a regular space (U+0020) so it is still possible to have a break before the next word. Ellipses should be entered in this format by the copyeditors, they will be carried through the scripts so you shouldn't worry about them unless you notice that they were entered in an improper format. In Oxygen, if you place the cursor before any space or character it will show you the unicode at the bottom of the screen. If you need to correct any ellipses paste them in from the text file.
  • Soft Hyphen: See guidelines for soft hyphens in Appendix E.

Appendix B.8 Abbreviations Section

As for when Kangyur abbreviations should be used here is a note from John:

I see this as needing an adapted approach, depending on the number and kind of notes, in several steps:

  • 1) I think in texts where there aren’t many notes about variants in different Kangyurs — let’s say a maximum of about 10 notes — it's probably easier for our readers if we simply spell out “Degé Kangyur” or “Stok Palace Kangyur” each time.
  • 2) If there are more notes than that, but they almost all refer to one Kangyur, we could say “Degé Kangyur” the first time and just “Degé” in subsequent mentions, and an abbreviations list is unnecessary.
  • 3) If there are quite a lot of notes and they refer to several different Kangyurs, or the Chinese, Sanskrit versions, etc., then we should definitely have an abbreviations list and use the sigla alone in all such notes.

This should be covered by the editors, but they may not have created an abbreviations section. If there are a lot for sigla used in the notes (situation 3 above), but there is not abbreviations section, then please create one modeled on other texts.

When the abbreviations for alternative Kangyur editions are used, you should follow the Vienna system.

Sigla with supscript letters should use the <hi rend="subscript"> tag, using the matching case used in the official sigla, e.g.,
K<hi rend="subscript">Y</hi>
.

Appendix B.9 Appendices: Sanskrit and Other Appendices

General Notes on Appendices:

The headings, <head>, are used in the same manner as within the body of the text, and use the same possible @type attributes as is appropriate to the content, e.g., "prologue", "chapter", "section", etc.

The headings will appear in the table of contents and should be clearly labeled according to what they are ("Sanskrit Text", "An Outline of the Present Day Ordination Rite", etc.) so they can be easily found and referenced by the reader from the table of contents.

Here is an example from Toh 381:

<div type="appendix">  <head tid="2197" type="appendix">Sanskrit Text</head>  <div type="prologue">   <head tid="2198" type="prologue">Introduction to This Sanskrit Edition</head>  </div>  <div type="chapter">   <head tid="2246" type="chapter">Chapter A1</head> <!--...etc...-->  </div> </div>

See Toh 381 in Reading Room.

Sanskrit Appendices:
  • If it is a Sanskrit Appendix the initial heading should be labeled "Sanskrit Text" and then any sub headings may be labeled appropriately as chapters, sections, etc.
  • To distinguish between the numbers in the appendix's chapter headers from those in the main translation add an "-A" to each number, e.g., "Chapter A1", "Chapter A2"...
  • Often the translator will have typed untagged milestones into the Sanskrit appendices. If possible we would like to arrange our own milestones so that the milestone index generated in the reading room by the parser match up with these, and then the original milestones from the word doc may be commented out. For example see Toh 437, and if you look in the original TEI you will see the orginal milestones in the appendix have been commented out. However, there are some cases when this will not be possible because some complexity in the correlation. This was the case in Toh 543 where the text was translated from a Sanskrit manuscript in which chapters omitted in the Tibetan were skipped. In this case the final milestones were left in as is, and an explanation was added in the appendix's prologue.
  • Note, that often there will be entries in the glossary that may be Sanskrit names or terms that also appear in the Sanskrit appendix. However since these won't be linked consistently due to Sanskrit's complex spelling declinations, we generally want to avoid linking the Sanskrit body of the appendices all together. This can be done by adding an @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute to either the <p> or <div> elements you would like to be blocked. Ostensibly there will be terms in the English prologue/introduction to the appendix that we would won't to link, so these @rend attributes can be applied and adjusted according to the need.

Appendix B.10 Keys: Using the @Key attribute to distinguish the content in duplicate texts with separate Toh numbers

Certain elements allow for the key attribute: <ref>, <p>, <foreign>, and <mantra> elements. These can be used to allow for content to appear in one version of a text but not another. The key corresponds to the key of the specific Toh version of the text, e.g. "toh999", which is defined for each Toh version in the <sourceDesc> However, it is important the we keep the numbered index for all notes and milestones the same throughout all duplicate versions of a text. Therefore the @key attribute is invalid for milestones and notes.

*** Be careful not to add a @key to a <p> that contains a child <note> within it, as that will cause the note to disappear in the other versions and distrupt the index of the notes causing problems for the notes cache.

Here is an overview for how and when to use the key attributes:

  • Inside <ref> elements: This is used to simply provide the alternate folio number, which will link to the proper page of the eKangyur in the reading room. This is very common. E.g., at the beginning of Toh 729:
    <p tid="15">  <ref cRef="F.222.a" key="toh729"   type="folio" xml:id="UT22084-094-006-20"/>  <ref cRef="F.160.a" key="toh1001"   type="folio" xml:id="UT22084-094-006-21"/> Homage to the Three Jewels! </p>

    Here F.222.a will display in Toh 729 and F.160.a will display in Toh 1001. [See in web display]

  • Inside <p> elements: Principally this is used inside of <note> elements since we do not want to use them on the notes themselves to avoid altering the index. Although we typically don't put <p> elements in <note>s, we can add them in this case in order display a different message depending on the Toh number of the text. The common example of this is for text that are cross listed with the dharani volumes 100-103, which have a discrepancy regarding the volume number found in the Degé, or with the volume 88 texts which have 17 folio number shift between the par phud and post-par phud editions (see Appendix A6). In such cases, a detailed explanation should be given in the relevant version, but a simpler placeholder version that simply references the full note can be used in the other versions (because in order to keep the index number consistent the other versions have to say something). An example of this markup would look like this:
    <note place="end"  xml:id="UT22084-999-999-999">  <p key="toh9999A">The folio reference here has a particularity here is a long explanation that is only relevant in this version...</p>  <p key="toh9999B">In the Toh 9999A version of this text the folio references have a particularity; see Toh 9999A, <ref target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh9999A.html#end-note-UT22084-999-999-999">note 1</ref> for details.</p> </note>
    Here are is the template to be used for the note in Vol. 88 texts:
    <note place="end">  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 88 TEXT]">Two sets of folio references have been included in this translation due to a discrepancy    in volume 88 (<foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">rgyud ’bum</foreign>, <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">na</foreign>) of the Degé Kangyur between the 1737 <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par      phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings. In the latter case,    an extra work, <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bodhi­maṇḍasyālaṃkāra­lakṣa­dhāraṇī</title> (Toh 508, <title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">byang chub      snying po’i rgyan ’bum gyi gzungs</title>), was added as the second text in the volume,    thereby displacing the pagination of all the following texts in the same volume    by 17 folios. Since the eKangyur follows the later printing, both references    have been provided, with the highlighted one linking to the eKangyur viewer.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT-->  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT]">In the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of the text there is a slight discrepancy in the folio numbering between the 1737 <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings of the Degé Kangyur. Although the discrepancy is irrelevant here, further details concerning this may be found in <ref target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix>   </ref> of the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

    (See an example in the web display for Toh 212 and Toh 520)

    Here are is the template to be used for the note in Vol. 100-103 texts:
    <note place="end">  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 100-103 TEXT]">This text, Toh <fix>###</fix>, and    all those contained in this same volume (<foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">    <fix>XXXX, X</fix>   </foreign>), are listed as being located in volume  <fix>###</fix> of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the    eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Room—list this work as being located in volume <fix>###</fix>.    This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzungs ’dus</foreign> section    are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku    catalog placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the  <title xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Vimala­prabhā­nāma­kālacakra­tantra­ṭīkā</title> (<title xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od</title>,    Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come    right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in    the same volume as the Kangyur <foreign xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar chags</foreign> (catalog). Please note this discrepancy    when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT-->  <p key="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT">Note that there is a discrepancy among various databases for    cataloging the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text within vol. <fix>###</fix> or <fix>###</fix> of the Degé Kangyur. See Toh <fix>####</fix>, <ref target="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix>   </ref>, for    details.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

    (See an example in the web display for Toh 729 and Toh 1001)


    In principle this could be used in regular <p> paragraph outside of the notes as well. Although there has yet to be an example of doing this. Just be sure that if this is ever needed, make sure there aren't any <note>s inside the <p> element that has a key.

  • Inside <foreign> or <mantra> elements:

    Typically this is to show alternate versions of dharanis or mantras which often have small alterations in the formulas of the Sanskrit transliteration. Usually these discrepancies are just stated in notes, but in some cases it may be desirable to display the text differently for each version. We have yet to use this technique, but it should be valid in the schema, and if this mode is used in the future an example will be documented here.

Appendix B.11 Chinese and Scripts

Chinese scripts need to always be tagged with a @xml:lang="zh" if they are in Chinese script, e.g. "漢語拼音", and be tagged @xml:lang="Zh-Ltn" if they are in pinyin or other Roman transliteration e.g. "Hànyǔ Pīnyīn". They may be tagged with the @xml:lang attribute either with a <foreign> or <title>, or a <div> element in the case of a Chinese Summary (Chinese summaries should be placed immediately after the English summary in its own separate <div> with an @xml:lang="zh" attribute. It will not be displayed in the English Reading Room but will on the Chinese site). If they are not tagged like this they will not be displayed correctly in a consistent font. The same goes for any Japanese text, which should be tagged "ja" or "Ja-Ltn" in the same manner. There is one exception where we don't need to worry about the tags and that is the Chinese names often found in the <sponsor> element in the TEI header, these aren't displayed anywhere so they do not need the @xml:lang attribute.

Most of us not knowing Chinese and Japanese will sometimes need to guess according to the context whether the script is "zh" or "ja", however, this is not too important because the parser will display Chinese, Japanese, and Korean in the same CJK-pan. So it's not imperative that they are tagged 100% correctly as long as each instance of CJK unicode is tagged with one of the CJK attributes: either "zh" "ja" or "ko".

The following search codes will allow you to easily locate miss-tagged or missing tags:

  • An XPath Query that will locate any CJK unicode character that does not have an ancestor element with @xml:lang="zh" or "ja": //text()[matches(., '&#x4E00;-&#x9FFF;&#x3040;-&#x309F;&#x30A0;-&#x30FF;&#xAC00;-&#xD7AF;')][not(ancestor::*[@xml:lang=('zh') or @xml:lang =('ja') or @xml:lang=('ko')])]
  • An XPath will locate any Roman letter "a-z" or letter "A-Z" that is mislabelled "zh" or "ja": //text()[matches(., '[a-zA-z]')][ancestor::*[@xml:lang = ('zh') or @xml:lang = ('ja')]]
  • Using the regular CTRL-F search in Oxygen you can also locate Chinese script with the regex pattern: \p{script=Han}+
  • And any Japanese script with: [\p{script=Hiragana}\p{script=Katakana}]+
  • Korean: \p{script=Hangul}+

(See more about searching various unicode scripts using regex patterns here)

Keep an eye out for Chinese in the acknowledgements section and the bibliography where titles and names tend to be missed. Note that when a title is given in both Chinese script and pinyin, then two <title> tags are needed to separate the language codes:
<title xml:lang="Ja-Ltn">Shirukurōdo to kindai nihon no kaikō: sai’iki kodai shiryō to nihon kindai bukkyō</title> <title xml:lang="ja">シルクロードと近代日本の邂逅―西域古代資料と日本近代仏教</title>
It's not indispensable to check for these every time since we will occasionally run these searches on the full TEI translation folder, but it might be a good idea to run the scripts on text that especially heavy in Chinese references in the notes and bibliography.

Appendix C Guidelines for Glossary:
Some Notes About How the Glossary Works

Note, also see the Translator Guidelines V.G. Glossary. There is a definitive explanation for translators on how to create their glossaries and these principles should be carried forward in to markup.

How Reader Handles Plurals:

A term will be matched if it is followed by s, es, 's, or s' and then a non-word character, e.g. Maitreya, Maitreya's, Maitreyas. (Unfortunately, the general marker for non-word characters is not Sanskrit-aware. It handles Sanskrit diacritic characters as non-word characters. While we have handled most of the related issues in this case it can result in a few mistakes, e.g. Maitreyasāyana).

Capitalization

The glossary is not case-sensitive and will link to names and terms regardless of capitalization. However, note that as a standard within the TEI proper names should be capitalized in the English and Sanskrit field but NOT in the Tibetan Wylie field. Although the parser will display all the English and Sanskrit entries in the Reading Room itself as capitalized regardless of the text found in the TEI.

Use of the <term> Tag to Mark the Same Word Used in Different Ways:

Sometimes we will only want certain instances of a string of text to be marked as a glossary term. For example, perhaps we want the term "appropriate" to be linked to this term when it is used as verb but not when it used as an adjective. The translator guidelines [G4] instructs translators to flag instances of glossary terms that are only relevant to specific passages with the “†” symbol. They are also instructed to specify glossary entries as verbs (vb), nouns (n), or adjectives (adj) in cases where the glossary entry is only intended to link to one form of the word and not others, for example "play" or "appropriate" (These should not be left in the text but replaced with the markup described in the following section). However, many of these may be missed and so all the linked terms should be checked in markup. Note, that we are no longer using zero-width-non-joiners to resolve this issue. Instead, we now use the "mode" attribute within the <gloss> element.

In the glossary, <gloss> nodes can be given the attributes mode="match|marked." Match mode will highlight any matches in the text except where they have been marked up with <term type="ignore">, e.g.:
parse this <term type="ignore">but not this</term>

*Note that a term in the definition field of a glossary entry linking to itself is ignored automatically.

Marked mode will only match terms that have been marked up with <term> e.g.
Ignore this <term>but match this</term>.
How Tibetan Is Created from Wylie:

Where a glossary item has a Wylie term but no Tibetan the database will auto-generate the Tibetan. To re-create a Tibetan term simply remove the node, save, and refresh. The Wylie string will also have a trailing space enforced. These will produce the respective syllable separators in the Tibetan. Double underscores in Wylie will be replaced with a single space when output to the reader.
