If later you make a correction to a Tibetan entry, be sure to delete the term with Tibetan Unicode (the one with xml:lang="bo") this will trigger the database to auto-generate a new one from the corrected Wylie entry, but if you leave it as is the error will remain in the Tibetan Unicode.

Links to Paragraphs with Instances:

The reader lists links to each paragraph that includes instances of a glossary term.

For Multiple Tibetan and Sanskrit Forms of Spelling for a Single Term:

In some cases a single <gloss> entry may have multiple forms for spelling the Tibetan, the Sanskrit, or both. In this case each spelling of the term can be listed separately in its own <term> element. However, Tibetan should be listed first, followed by the Sanskrit, as in the following example for the term "karnikara" (note that a Tibetan "bo" term is auto-generated after each instance of Tibetan Wylie "Bo-Ltn"):

<gloss type="term"  xml:id="UT22084-055-001-5217">  <term>karnikara</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">kar ni </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">ཀར་ནི།</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dong ka </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">དོང་ཀ།</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar ni </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">དཀར་ནི།</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">karṇikāra</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">mucilinda</term>  <term type="definition">Pterospermum acerifolium. Other names include bayur, muchakunda,    muchalinda, and dinner-plate tree.</term> </gloss>

(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

Note that in the example above, these spelling variations are supplied by the author but don't actually appear in the translated text. If there are alternative spellings of a term within the text itself, they need to be marked as type="alternative."

Use of Alternatives in the Glossary Entry:

Glossary items can also include <term type="alternative"> nodes to specify other variations in the spelling that should be marked in the text:

<gloss type="term"  xml:id="UT22084-060-005-541">  <term>door of the Dharma</term>  <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">chos kyi sgo </term>  <term xml:lang="bo">ཆོས་ཀྱི་སྒོ།</term>  <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">dharmamukha</term>  <term type="definition">See “Dharma-door.”</term>  <term type="alternative">doors of the Dharma</term> </gloss>

(See in the Reading Room; note that the alternative term isn't listed in the glossary but is linked in the text as the third occurrence).

Alternatives may be added for any related terms that should be linked to the entry such as:

  • When a plural "-s" appears in the middle of the string in certain cases and is not linking (as in the XML example above), or not linking because the plural has an irregular spelling, e.g. "phenomena" and "phenomenon"; "birth-story" and "birth-stories"; etc...
  • Alternate nominal or verbal uses of the same term: appropriate, appropriated, appropriation.
  • Extended names such as "Mañjuśrī" and "Mañjuśrī the crown prince". In this last case only if the simple name is clearly represented in the extended one, otherwise a second <gloss> should be added referring to the primary one, e.g.: The Great Compassionate One -- See Avalokiteśvara.

However, alternatives should not be used for two semantically different English words, even if they are translated from the same Tibetan term and have similar meaning. For example if "offering" and "worship" are both used for "mchod pa / pūjā". They should be given two different glossary entries.

The 84000 translator's guidelines (G4) states this clearly:

If the same Tibetan or Sanskrit word was translated in more than one way, include an entry for each, and place in the definition a reference to the other rendering, e.g. for the entry “Offering” (mchod pa / pūjā): “Also translated here as ‘worship,’ ” (and vice versa for the entry “Worship”).

There are two reasons for this. (1) We don't want readers unfamiliar with Tibetan and Sanskrit clicking on a term like "worship" and having it link to "offering," and (2) Some readers may be reading the text in a PDF format or even someday in print and will need to look up terms alphabetically as the hyperlinks won't be available.

Some of these alternatives may have been entered improperly and will need to be separated into separate entries. This should be handled by copy editors, but in some cases it may be missed and markup editors will be more capable of spotting inconsistencies or issues in the glossary since they will be able to actually click on the links and check them in the Reading Room.

There has been some further discussion regarding whether alternatives should be used when the English words for a glossary entry are used in a different word order. So in the example above for "door of the dharma" one might ask, should this itself be used as an alternative linking to the entry for "dharma-door" or should it be in a separate entry? In this case it isn't such an issue that the reader would click on "door of the Dharma" and see the entry for "Dharma-door" but it is an issue for anyone reading the PDF. However it is quite sensible that the reader would simply search for the term under "dharma" if they did not find it in "door". If there are a just a few instances of these it makes sense to create separate entries, but if the amount of entries with alternate word order is becoming extensive then this could be an issue because it will muddy up the glossary, be difficult for reader to find all the instances of a term from the "passages contain this term" field, and also it could muddy up the cumulative glossary. When there are a lot of such alternatives it may be better to set such phrases as "door of the dharma" as an alternative provided that it would be sensible from the perspective of the reader and there aren't semantically distinct words (e.g., you wouldn't want to add "gateway of the dharma" as an alternative). If there are a lot of such instances, you should also check with the editors about changing the translation to be more consistent (make notes about such instances in the Reading Room Worksheet). This should be taken on a case by case basis and always thought of from the readers perspective.

Further Explanation on the Mode Attribute:

The mode attribute is not required, but when present it can either be "match" or "marked." "Match" is the default (where this attribute is not specified). "Match" will behave in the normal way: the text is scanned for glossary matches and highlighted accordingly.

"Marked," on the other hand, will only consider text strings that have been marked up with <term>. An example for "appropriate" is below:

<!-- Glossary item with mode "marked" --> <item>  <gloss mode="marked" type="term"   xml:id="UT22084-044-003-185">   <term>appropriate</term>   <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">len pa </term>   <term xml:lang="bo">ལེན་པ་</term>   <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ādāna</term>   <term type="definition">See “appropriation.”</term>   <term type="alternative">appropriated</term>  </gloss> </item>
<!-- Only marked up instances in the text will be highlighted --> <p tid="38"> Bhadrapāla said, “Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying person’s limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, <term>appropriate</term> another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it <term>appropriate</term> different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying person’s sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body?” </p>

(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

Linking <term>s in the body of the text to the glossary entry directly with the @ref attribute.

Sometimes, if there are three or more glossary entries with the same exact string, the marked application alone will not be sufficient. In this case the duplicate <gloss> entries should all be tagged mode="marked" and the terms within the body of the text may be linked directly to the proper glossary entry by adding a @ref attribute that points that term to the specific entry attributed to it. For example there are three separate entries for the name "Upananda" in Toh 340. These may be distinguished in the text as follows:

<p tid="2067">He had come to Śrāvastī very late, <ref cRef="F.184.a" type="folio"/> and seeing that the other monks had already gone carrying their alms bowls filled, he thought, “I will ask where I should go to quickly get some alms.” So he went to see Upananda and asked him, <!--...--> </p> <!--...--> <p tid="4741">King Prasenajit implored the Blessed One, “Lord, the Blessed One has tamed vicious nāgas like <term>Nanda</term>, <term ref="UT22084-073-001-5716">Upananda</term>, <!--...--> </p> <!--...--> <p tid="3024">“Now the king had two wise chief ministers, capable, clear-minded, <ref cRef="F.274.a" type="folio"/> trustworthy, shrewd, disciplined, and prudent. Their names were <term ref="UT22084-073-001-5432">Nanda</term> and <term>Upananda</term>.</p> <!--...--> <!--...IN THE GLOSSARY ENTRIES:...--> <item>  <gloss type="person"   xml:id="UT22084-073-001-5519">   <term>Upananda (the monk)</term>   <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">nye dga’ bo </term>   <term xml:lang="bo">ཉེ་དགའ་བོ།</term>   <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Upananda</term>   <term type="definition">A member of the Śākya clan and monk of the      Buddha’s order, he often appears in the vinaya texts, as here, to      exemplify certain wrong behaviors. </term>   <term type="definition">Not to be confused with <term>Upananda</term>,      one of King Mahā­deva's ministers; or with <term ref="UT22084-073-001-5716">Upananda</term>, the nāga.</term>   <term type="alternative">Upananda</term>  </gloss> </item> <item>  <gloss mode="marked" type="person"   xml:id="UT22084-073-001-5520">   <term>Upananda (the minister)</term>   <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">nye dga’ bo </term>   <term xml:lang="bo">ཉེ་དགའ་བོ།</term>   <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">*Upananda</term>   <term type="definition">Along with Nanda, one of King Mahadeva’s two chief ministers      in the city of Mithilā.</term>   <term type="alternative">Upananda</term>  </gloss> </item> <item>  <gloss mode="marked" type="person"   xml:id="UT22084-073-001-5716">   <term>Upananda (the nāga)</term>   <term xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">nye dga’ bo </term>   <term xml:lang="bo">ཉེ་དགའ་བོ།</term>   <term xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">*Upananda</term>   <term type="definition">The name of a certain nāga. </term>   <term type="definition">Not to be confused with “<term>Upananda</term>,”      one of King Mahā­deva's ministers; or with Upananda, the      monk.</term>   <term type="alternative">Upananda</term>  </gloss> </item>

See this example in Reading Room.

***Important Note: if you use a @ref to mark a terms to a glossary entry with mode="marked", be sure to also add @refs to any terms that need to be linked to the other mode="marked" entry(s) otherwise the parser may link all marked terms without @refs to the first mode="marked" entry. So as in the example above, instances of both Upananda the minister and nāga need to be marked with <term> elements with @refs, but Upananda the monk may be left as is because the first entry isn't mode="marked"

Blocking the glossary from linking to entire paragraphs, stanzas, divisions, or mantras

Optionally an @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute may be added to any <p>, <lg>, <div>, or <mantra> element to block all the text within from linking to the glossary. Typically we want to do this for Sanskrit appendices, long Sanskrit quotes, or mantras where the complex Sanskrit spelling declinations will cause terms to be linked inconsistently. Note, the @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute can ostensibly be used on any element in the TEI document although the schema may need to be updated to validate it in particular cases. Email the ODD editor (Celso) if the schema needs to be updated.

Some Final Tips for Polishing the Glossary:
  • Sometimes a term will appear in its own definition. By default the parser will block these from linking to themselves.
  • If there are references in the definition to a term, such as "see also...", they can be placed into a second <term type="definition"> line, to create some visual lightness in the final webdisplay.
  • If a word is not linking in the webdisplay, here are some common causes for instances not being detected by the parser:
    • Plurals in the middle of strings of words (where the "s" doesn't come at the end).
    • An extra space at the end of the term in the glossary.
    • Sanskrit soft-hypens in the term not matching with the glossary entry.
  • Occasionally you will see a word in the text that is similar to a glossary term but isn't linked because it takes as different form. For instance, "appropriate" is in the glossary, but you see "appropriation" in the text. If you see instances like this you can add an <term type="alternative"> to that <gloss> item, but be sure that you are not then linking to other unwanted instances as well.

return to table of contents

Appendix D Guidelines for Entering Milestones into the TEI Document

Milestones are applied to the document with the “<milestone unit="chunk"/>” tag. Because the 84000 reading room does not have page numbers, milestones are particularly important for referencing sections or paragraphs in the text.

Milestones should be applied to the text at places where there is a logical/thematic division in the text. Sometimes, milestones can be placed at the beginning of each paragraph of prose. In cases where paragraphs are very short (only one or two sentences) milestones can be placed one for every two or more paragraphs depending on the context, or a particularly short paragraph can share the milestone with that of a larger previous or later paragraph that shares the same “theme.”

To a large degree the editor should use their own judgment: If the milestones are too frequent, then it will become distracting to the reader on the page. If they are too far apart, it will be difficult to cite particular passages of the text. It is helpful to check the display in the reading room after applying milestones to make sure they appear in a convenient way and to visually check there is general consistency throughout the text.

Often there will be very short paragraphs used during sections of dialogue. A logical way to organize these sections is to allow one question and answer to be given a single milestone. For example, the following passage could be given one milestone:

<milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>The Lord then said to the venerable Śāriputra, “Śāriputra, did you see that universe Abhirati, and the Tathāgata Akṣobhya?”</p> <p>Śāriputra replied, “I saw it, Lord! May all living beings come to live in a buddhafield as splendid as that! May all living beings come to have miraculous powers just like those of the noble Licchavi Vimalakīrti!</p>

(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

If either the question or the answer are very short paragraphs (one or two sentences), then they could be appended to the milestone along with their respective question and answer. However, if both the question and answer are long paragraphs in themselves, they should each be given their own milestone. Of course, there will always be unique situations such as questions being answered with another question and so forth. The editor should in general use their own discretion to decide what frequency of milestones would be the most useful and least distracting to the reader. They should to try to be consistent with their usage.

When entering milestones for lines of verse, the editor should apply milestones in a consistent manner, which will typically be one milestone marker between every line group element <lg>. Usually this will be a verse of four lines in English.

For example, see how milestones are applied to the following verses from The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

<milestone unit="chunk"/> <lg>  <l>Pure are your eyes, broad and beautiful, like the petals of a blue lotus.</l>  <l>Pure is your thought, having discovered the supreme transcendence of all trances.</l>  <l>Immeasurable is the ocean of your virtues, the accumulation of your good deeds.</l>  <l>You affirm the path of peace. O Great Ascetic, obeisance to you!</l> </lg> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <lg>  <l>Leader, bull of men, we behold the revelation of your miracle.</l>  <l>The superb and radiant fields of the sugatas appear before us,</l>  <l>And your extensive spiritual teachings, that lead to immortality </l>  <l>Make themselves heard throughout the whole reach of space.</l> </lg> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <lg>  <l>Dharma-King, you rule with the Dharma your supreme Dharma-kingdom,</l>  <l>And thereby bestow the treasures of the Dharma upon all living beings.</l>  <l>Expert in the deep analysis of things, you teach their ultimate meaning.</l>  <l>Sovereign Lord of Dharma, obeisance to you!</l> </lg>

(See example in reading room.)

One exception to this may occur when a set of verses are introduced by a very short line, such as “The Blessed One said:” In this case use your judgment to place a milestone either before this short line and not the verse, or vice-versa, depending on the spatial and thematic context you are working in:

<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-005-264"/> <p tid="250">When the Blessed One had explained the meaning to them, he spoke these verses:</p> <lg tid="251">  <l>“Some say that what is created is compounded,</l>  <l>While others say that it is uncompounded.</l>  <l>However, as both apprehend phenomena, both are concepts.</l>  <l>Such conceptual elaborations are called impure.</l> </lg> <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-005-266"/> <lg tid="252">  <l>“Phenomena are not created by anyone, nor does anything destroy them.</l>  <l>No one sees them, knows them, or is close to them.</l>  <l>Such untenable domains of imputed thought—</l>  <l>All are designated empty.</l> </lg>

(See example in reading room.)

In another case the editor may encounter short sentences used in a debate-like dialogue. For example, in this following dialogue found in The Teachings of Vimalakīrti:

<milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>Mañjuśrī: What is the great compassion of a bodhisattva ?</p> <p>Vimalakīrti: It is the giving of all accumulated roots of virtue to all living beings.</p> <p>Mañjuśrī: What is the great joy of the bodhisattva?</p> <p>Vimalakīrti: It is to be joyful and without regret in giving.</p> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>Mañjuśrī: What is the equanimity of the bodhisattva? </p> <p>Vimalakīrti: It is what benefits both self and others.</p> <p>Mañjuśrī: To what should one resort when terrified by fear of life?</p> <p>Vimalakīrti: Mañjuśrī, a bodhisattva who is terrified by fear of life should resort to the magnanimity of the Buddha.</p>

(See example in reading room.)

A similar passage in The Absorption of the Thus-Gone One’s Wisdom Seal:

<milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-005-220"/> <p tid="206">“Blessed One, to what do the terms <distinct>unchanging</distinct> and <distinct>nonconceptual</distinct> refer?”</p> <p tid="207">“Noble sons, <distinct>unchanging</distinct> and <distinct>nonconceptual</distinct> refer to <distinct>nonreferential</distinct>.”</p> <p tid="208">“Blessed One, to what does <distinct>nonreferential</distinct> refer?”</p> <p tid="209">“Noble sons, <distinct>nonreferential</distinct> refers to <distinct>inexhaustible</distinct>.”</p> <milestone unit="chunk"  xml:id="UT22084-055-005-224"/> <p tid="210">“Blessed One, to what does <distinct>inexhaustible</distinct> refer?”</p> <p tid="211">“Noble sons, <distinct>inexhaustible</distinct> refers to <distinct>unborn</distinct>.”</p> <p tid="212">“Blessed One, to what does <distinct>unborn</distinct> refer?”</p> <p tid="213">“Noble sons, <distinct>unborn</distinct> refers to <distinct>uninterrupted</distinct>.”</p>

(See example in reading room.)

<milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of virtuous application. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who live by all virtuous principles will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is the magnificence of the conception of the spirit of enlightenment. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who are actually participating in the Mahāyāna will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <milestone unit="chunk"/> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of generosity. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who give away all their possessions will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <p>“A bodhisattva’s buddhafield is a field of morality. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who follow the path of the ten virtues with positive thoughts will be born in his buddhafield.</p>

(See example in reading room.)

Here the editor might place a milestone for each item in the list depending on the length of each paragraph. It might also be appropriate to place the milestones according to logical groupings in the list, for example place one milestone for the four immeasurables, one milestone for the six paramitas, etc. Finally, if the list becomes overburdened by milestones, the editor can add the milestones for every two or four items in the list. In this case it might be worthwhile to check how many items there are in the list then seek a reasonable way to divide it up evenly.

If the editor is not sure about the frequency for applying milestones, he or she can refer to some of the other texts in the reader and see how frequently the milestones are used in other texts. For now, Toh 131 is a good example.

While editing in oXygen, it can be easier to edit milestones while in "author mode" (go to "Author" in the menu bar and click on "Switch to Author Mode." This will show the layout of the text more clearly and you can remove the milestones by double clicking on them and hitting delete.) This is a useful way to quickly edit milestones, but should not be a substitute for checking visually in the Reading Room.

There are a few places where we always want to have a milestone: (1) trailers (both at the end of chapters and any concluding trailer to the entire text); (2) the opening homage and the following paragraph; and (3) in ancillary sections (summary, acknowledgement, colophon, etc.).

return to table of contents

Appendix E Guidelines for Entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit

Note that only editors with a basic understanding of the spelling and sandhi rules of Sanskrit should proceed with this step. You don't need to be an expert in Sanskrit, as most words can be looked up in online references, however, for this step editors will need to have a clear grasp on how the sandhi rules in Sanskrit work. If not please request that another editor with this skill to complete this task.

  • Look for long Sanskrit chains, and add optional soft-hyphens at points where there are chains that are 15+ characters long. Optional soft-hyphens are created with the character code:
    &#173;
    Note that after you save the XML these will look like regular hyphens, but if you move the blinking cursor to the space just before the hyphen you will notice there is a different character code displayed at the bottom of the oXygen screen.
  • The long Sanskrit chains can be found easily by going to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder, then in the XPath/XQuery Builder window type the following code and press the red play button://*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn'] You can save this query for later by clicking on the star and choosing "add to favourites."
  • Note that texts that have Sanskrit appendixes will not be checked by the code above because these sections aren't marked with an @xml:lang attribute. Generally, the Sanskrit appendixes such as the one in Toh 437 does not need soft hyphens because it is not anticipated that they will be read on small devices. However, occasionally there may be extremely long strings in the appendices that will fill the screen even on a regular web browser. For the appendices our current limit is any strings longer than 40 continuous characters without as space. To search the appendices, press CTRL/SHIFT/H to "search in files" then check the "regular expression" box, in the scope select "All open files", and in "Restrict to XPath:" enter the code: //text(). Finally, in the search field enter the following regex code: (^|\s|-­)[^\s-­]{40,}($|\s|-­). This should give you a list of all the 40+ strings while ignoring tags, spaces, or hyphens.
  • Be careful when adding the soft hyphens as they should only be placed at certain points in the words where they do not interfere with the Sanskrit rules of sandhi. When adding the soft hyphens please follow the following guidelines:
  • Guidelines for Adding Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit:

    • 1. As we are not using full justification anyway, (a) most Sanskrit words don’t need hyphenation unless they are longer than 5 or 6 syllables, but (b) may be necessary for shorter words especially in text titles on the title page. I therefore tend to place soft hyphens in all of the text titles, in verse passages, in the bibliography entries, and in notes and glossary entries (which require shorter lines in general).

    • 2. Place a soft hyphen (a) only between the words of a compound; (b) even then only when there are no changes brought about by sandhi (because putting a hyphen would logically mean undoing the sandhi, and the hyphens we’re talking about may or may not appear); and (c) avoiding confusing remnants.

      A couple of examples:

      Ratnagotravibhāgottaratantraśāstra would be Ratna-gotra-vibhāgottara-tantra-śāstra. If we divided the 5-syllable sequence in the middle, that would have to undo the sandhi and become -vibhāga-uttara-, which only works in the presence of a hard hyphen. Theoretically we could put a hyphen at vi-bhāga, but that would risk leaving us with -gotravi-, which would be potentially confusing to read.

      The maximum we could hyphenate antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhisaṃdhisamuccedaka would be antānanta-ḍṛṣṭi-vāsanābhi-saṃdhi-sam-ucchedaka, because antānanta and vāsanābhi-saṃdhi would become anta-ananta and vāsana-abhi-saṃdhi. In a case like that, I would also prefer to avoid ending up with antānantaḍṛṣṭivāsanābhi-saṃdhisamuccedaka, because the abhi- really belongs with the saṃdhi; it’s a possible break but is confusing to read.

    • One resource that is helpful for determining the breaks in Sanskrit chains in the online Cologne Sanskrit Dictionary. This one is really helpful because it has a drop down menu of similarly spelled words when you hit the enter key, however, I think this only works when you use the Kyoto-Harvard Transliteration scheme "KH." You might try the other ones but I found that this is the only one that gave the drop down list for me. Then when you find a big word in the dictionary in the definition entry you will see * whenever there is sandhi, though this isn't 100% reliable. Sometimes it is missing for some reason, so be careful if the spelling looks weird.
    • In certain cases there may be long 15+ Sanskrit chains that cannot be broken due to the sandhi, or long Sanskrit compounds whose pieces cannot be easily determined with online resources. If this is the case make a list of problematic instances to note for the leading editors, and also check these instances to see if the pose any major difficultly for the web display. These instances are rare, but they do come up now and then.
    • It is acceptable to add an optional hyphen at the end of "mahā-" as in "mahā-yāna" even though technically the long ā would be lost, as this is a well known word and unlikely to be misread.
    • Note that when you add the optional hyphens to a glossary item where the translation uses the Sanskrit (This will mainly be in the “Persons” and “Places” section of the glossary) the hyphens will have to match all those instances within the body of the text or they will not link to the glossary term, so it is best to start from the glossary and work your way backwards. For all of these person and place terms do a search and replace so that the hyphens match in all the instances of that term (be cautious when doing large search-and-replaces that you don’t make any unintended changes).

return to table of contents

return to checklist for 84000 TEI markup editors step 8

Appendix F Learning TEI/XML

If you are learning TEI or XML from the beginning, or would like to review some of that training, here are some useful places to begin:

  • What is the TEI? And why should I care? (A brief introduction for classicists)

    This is an introductory slide show explaining what TEI is.

  • An Introduction to XML

    This is a basic introduction to XML.

  • TEI by Example

    This a tutorial along with interactive examples and tests. This is a good place to begin if you are just getting started.

  • The TEI Guidelines

    This is the official manual on TEI and a good place to look up references, as it has all the standards in one place.

  • TEI's Github, Issues Section

    This is the TEI forum for the general TEI community. After you have some experience working with TEI, this is a good place to go for any troubleshooting or issues.

  • More Tips for Oxygen XML Editor

    Here is a short video for 84000 Markup Editors showing a few tips and tricks for using the Oxygen XML Editor.

Appendix G GitHub

84000 GitHub
This is a link to the 84000 GitHub. This is where all our TEI files may be accessed, and any of our data related resources are publicly available for access and discussion.

Appendix H Guidelines for Using an XSLT Conversion Script

This is the method that bypasses the process of running the .docx through Project Management.

If you need to convert a word .docx created from our template into TEI you will need to first run the file through the oXgarage website or it's mirror site. Convert the file to a "TEI P5 XML Document" and then run our own .xslt script on the document.

Here are instructions for using an XSLT script in oXygen:

  • A. Click on “Configure Transformation Scenarios” (it should be a wrench with a red arrow on the oXygen ribbon).
  • B. Select “New” > “XML transformation with XSLT.”
  • C. For the XSL URL: click on the drop down menu next to the folder and select “Browse Data Source Explorer.”
  • D. Select the appropriate .xsl document from the database. For example the script for transforming a .docx created from the 84000 template can be found in: 84000 Collaboration > apps > import-84000-data > xsl > oxGto84000.xsl.
  • E. Click on the “Output” tab and check the box that says “Open in Editor.”
  • F. Click okay, and then select “apply associated” (the transformation scenario you just made should be ticked under “projects”).

Appendix I Guidelines and Checklist for Updating the Schema and ODD

Note that updating the schema and ODD is a bit more complicated, so this should be handled by the lead editors or technicians. Otherwise, if you are working on a markup and notice that the schema needs to be updated (i.e., there is some markup needed but you are getting a schema error for that markup), then make this a point to send to the lead editors in your final list of questions and issues for finalizing the text. Please disregard the following instructions unless you are a lead editor or technician.

  • This appendix gives a brief explanation and checklist for how to update the ODD. However, you may need to refer to the 22nd chapter of the TEI guidelines for a more detailed explanation on how the elements in the ODD work. You may also need to refer to the 23rd chapter of the TEI guidelines which contains information on the content models, attribute customizations, and TEI conformance.
  • Most of the restrictions in the ODD are defined in the element specifications. In order to create documentation, an <elementSpec> has been created for all of the elements we use. There are also some schema restrictions defined in class specifications, <classSpec>, and macro specifications, <macroSpec>. In our ODD's XML the <classSpec>s are listed first followed by the <macroSpec>s followed by the <elementSpec>s all in alphabetical order. If you need to jump to a specific element, they can easily be found by searching for their ident attribute. For example, to find the <elementSpec> for the "front", search for
    c ident="front"
    and this will take you to that section of the ODD.
  • Adding new elements will require creating a new <elementSpec> and adding it to the ODD. Adding or modifying attributes can be done in that specific element's <attList>. For example here is the <attList> for the <title> element:
    <attList>  <attDef ident="type" mode="change">   <desc>classifies the title according to the TBRC typology.</desc>   <desc>classifies the title according to the 84000 typology.</desc>   <valList mode="replace" type="closed">    <valItem ident="mainTitle"/>    <valItem ident="longTitle"/>    <valItem ident="otherTitle"/>   </valList>  </attDef>  <attDef ident="xml:id" mode="delete"/>  <attDef ident="level" mode="delete"/>  <attDef ident="xml:lang" mode="change"   usage="req"/> </attList>
    The <attDef> defines a particular attribute for <title>, along with a description <desc>. The <valList> defines what values are allowed in the "type" attribute. Since we don't use the default "xml:id" and "level" attributes in our <title>s they have been set to "delete" so they won't appear in our documentation. We want the "xml:lang" to be required for all <title>s so the usage has been set to "reg". More details should can be found in the TEI guidelines.
  • When a language needs to be added to the schema, the language list is actually found in the class specification for "att.global" that defines the "xml:lang" attribute. It should be added here so it will apply to all the elements that use "xml:lang". To find this section search for
     attDef               ident="xml:lang" 
  • Content Models: The structure for the schema--i.e., what elements are allowed to be nested in what elements--are contained in the ODD content models, <content>. Each element used in our TEI has a content model defined in its element specification, or if it isn't stated then the default TEI content model will be used when the schema is generated in from Oxgarage. You can look up the default content model in the appendix of the TEI Guidelines Because the 84000 schema is very restrictive, we use often directly use relax ng code within the ODD to define content models for the structure of the text. That is why you will see the prefix "rng:-" before many of the elements there. When the content model needs to be updated, that is the rules which govern how the elements are to be nested, look for the <content> element in the ODD for that element's <elementSpec>. If is a global rule for that element it will be found there. However, keep in mind if it is a rule specific to the order or structure found in the <front>, <body>, or <back>, then the content model will be found in those element's content models.
  • To avoid writing repetitive code, there are also some content models declared in the <marcroSpec> these may be referred to in other content models, which will look something like this:
    <rng:ref name="paragraph"/>
    In this example the rng element points to the content model of our basic paragraph. And if that needs to be updated in can be done so in the <macroSpec> for "paragraph".
  • Note there are also many descriptions, <desc>, as well as examples <egXML> contained in all the specifications. It is not required to update these for the generation of the schema, but when you make in update, it would be good to update these as well so that our documentation can be most up to date. Also consider whether an update is something that the markup editors need to be aware of during their work flow. If it is, please add some explanation and/or protocol for the markup editors in the "Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors". This appendix is found in the <back> of the ODD.
  • Occasionally, we may add a new element to our schema that is already included in one of the standard TEI modules. Note, that these standard elements are all declared at the beginning of the ODD in the <moduleRef>. This happened to me, I couldn't figure out why the <hi> element wasn't validating even though it was declared in an <elementSpec>. The reason was I had assumed it was declared as a part of the "core" module, but had forgotten to add it to the list within the <moduleRef>.
  • If you can't figure out why an added element or attribute isn't validating properly for a schema update. A good technique is to paste that element into a TEI document apply the schema, and read the schema error message at the bottom of the oXygen window. It should tell you what the schema is expecting and based on that you can determine where and which content model needs to be updated. Also keep in mind that any element from the standard TEI modules will have the default content model if a new one isn't declared, so you may need to look up the element in the TEI guidelines to find its default content model as well as its other parameters.
  • To summarize here is a brief checklist for any updates for the ODD/schema.
    • 1) Make any changes to the element that needs update in that elements <elementSpec>
    • 2) Does this change need to be reflected in the content model? If so make the appropriate corrections to the <content> found within the <elementSpec>s for the <teiHeader>, <front>, <body>, <back>, or possibly one of the <macroSpec>s
    • 3) Update examples, <egXML> and/or descriptions <desc> if needed.
    • 4) Update the markup editor's checklist if needed.

Appendix J XPath Codes and Other Useful Tips for Using the oXygen XML Editor:

  • Further Useful Tips for using the XPath/XQuery Builder
    • The Xpath/XQuery builder is a useful tool for searching for unwanted stuff in the glossaries like brackets, slashes and so on. To open, go to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder
    • For example to search for a bracket withing the glossary use the following code: //gloss/term[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(text(), "(")] The "(" at the end is what determines the bracket. Enter this into the XPath/XQuery Builder and press the play button to perform the search.
    • To find an opening square bracket in the glossary use the following code: //gloss/term[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(text(), "(") or contains(text(), "[")]
    • By using backslashes and element names you can also look for specific terms within particular elements, for example to search for a certain "word" within the <note> elements, you could use this code: //note[contains(data(), 'word')] Here 'word' is what you are looking for. // means search everywhere, //note means search everywhere for <note>s.
    • You can save your search codes for later by clicking on the star icon.
    • To learn more about XPath syntax and how it works. There is a good tutorial here.
    • Also this section of the tutorial here, explains some syntax, which you should be able to use with the XPath/XQuery Builder.
  • XPath Codes
    • Find footnote by index (e.g. 12): //note[@xml:id eq //*:end-note[@index eq '12']/@id]
    • Find glossary by index (e.g. 12): //gloss[@xml:id eq //*:gloss[@index eq '12']/@id]
    • Find Sanskrit string length 15 or more: //*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn']
  • Searching through the Text
    • You may notice that when you search for certain phrases in the XML, the phrase may not be found in the "Find/Replace" dialog. This is because the search tool is very precise so it will not find phrases with two or more words that are separated by a line break unless you specify it to do so. One way around this is to use the "Find in files" (click the second smaller magnifying glass in the ribbon or CTRL/SHIFT/H). Then select "All opened files" (It will ask you to save before it searches) and make sure "Ignore white spaces" is checked ("Regular expressions" must be unchecked for it to work). It will then ignore the line breaks.
    • The method above doesn't work with regular expressions. If you need to search in this way with regular expressions, then try replacing the spaces in your code with: \s+, e.g. search "door of dharma" with "door\s+of\s+dharma"
    • On occasion you may want to search the XML while ignoring all the tags. To do this, again use "find in files" CTRL/Shift/H and in the field that says "Restrict to XPath;" enter the code //text()
    • This will ignore the tags in your search results. Note, it will ignore the tags but it can't search over tags if a tag appears in the middle of a searched phrase, so for instance it won't fine "vidyā being" in the XML for
      <term>vidyā</term> being

Appendix K Guidelines for Updating Versions of the TEI Document

Version Numbering:

The three digit version numbering (e.g., "v 1.2.1") we are using here refer respectively to "major", "minor", and "revision" changes to the text (This emulates software versioning standards).

Any changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual updates that don't substantially affect the text (typos, minor markup/formatting consistencies, etc.). A change from 1.2.1 to 1.2.2 signals to the reader that there is no need to download it. Any change in the second decimal relates to a minor, but more significant changes within the text itself as well as to significant markup changes. For example, a missing stanza has been added, or a misspelled term has been corrected throughout the text. A change from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0 indicates that readers should download the latest version to have an improved version of the text. Any change in the first decimal would be a major change to the text, so 1.3.1 to 2.0.0. would be a clear sign that it should be downloaded.

To summarize:

  • Changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.3.5
  • Changes in the second decimal relate to minor, but more significant textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.4.0
  • Changes in first decimal relate to major text changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 2.0.0
Text Numbering Workflow

Most texts that have not been started in the translation process have no version number. When a text receives its first update it will change to

0.0.1

When markup is started, the text gets an initial version number:

0.1.1

From that point on, version numbers will increase every time editors feel it’s necessary as they work on the text. As noted before, changes made to the second decimal point are reserved for more significant textual and markup edits, and changes made to the third decimal point are reserved for minor textual and markup edits. Theoretically, a text could go through many versions before it is ready for publication, eg

0.0.1 to 0.0.2

0.0.2 to 0.1.0

0.1.0 to 0.1.1 etc

When the text is ready for publication then the version number is set by John or Mike to

1.0.0

When updating the TEI to a published translation please use the following procedure:
  • (1) When you make changes to a text, first check that the latest version is on distribution. If not, notify Mike or John that you are making changes to the text and to not push it to distribution until you are finished. This way a text that you are working on won’t be pushed to distribution until it is ready. Even if it is a relatively minor update, it is important to let admin know in case they are in the middle of pushing the texts to the published distribution database, in which case the changes may be incomplete or even just the version number could be missed.
  • (2) Save your changes from Oxygen.
  • (3) If you changed any of the markup, run the automated tests on the individual file by clicking on "run tests" next to the text title from the Utilities page (Note: don't run the automated tests from the "tests" tab unless it is necessary to check all the texts, as this will uses up a lot of the server's resources). Correct any issues related to failing test results or inform tech (Dom) about any test updates that may be needed.
  • (4) Finally, after saving the TEI from Oxygen, the version number needs to be updated separately on the project management page. This is important to keep track of any changes we've made to the published text: From the project management page, find the text according to its "text status," then click on "edit headers." From here, update both the version number (as described in the guidelines above) and if necessary the version's date (entering for the date only a four digit year, e.g., "2019"). Note, the "Publication Date" refers to the date of the original publication, so please leave this unchanged. Please also add a brief note in the "Add a note about this version" field about what changes were made. Now, click the "Update" button. Updating the version number in this way will simultaneously update the <editionStmt>'s version and date within the TEI file, upload the latest version to the Github repository, and generate the newest version of the eBook and PDF (this last part of the update only occurs if it is status="1").
  • (5) Inform the lead markup editor (Mike), so that the updated files may be moved from collaboration to distribution.

Global Changes:

Occasionally, global changes will need to be made for all the texts, usually performed with a script or a search-and-replace in the translations folder (By the way if you make global search-and-replaces to a folder be sure that Oxygen's "Make back of files with extension" box is unchecked, as this will cause problems in the database). Since it would be time consuming to update each text manually, please follow this protocol for updating the texts manually:

  • 1.) Make the global change (using script or find and replace). Make sure that the operation has worked correctly.
  • 2.) Ask tech (Dominic) to run a script to update version numbers and add a descriptive note.
  • 3.) Take a snapshot to capture version history for git (This is on the Utilities page menu: "Make a Data Snapshot").
  • 4.) Assess whether pdfs, epubs, and html need to be republished immediately. If so, then do it manually using utilities. If not, then wait for the next change that warrants a republishing of the text. Especially minor changes may not warrant updating all the publications as texts will be updated periodically, and the change will be added eventually.

Whenever you make changes to a published text, you should always change the version number from project management. When you start working on a text in markup use a version number beginning with 0.1.1. Generally, we don't need a versioning history while the text is in the markup process, however, if the markup for a text is particularly complex, e.g., it is a very large text, it includes attributes that require us to come up with new markup language, it includes a complex outline structure, etc., you should occasionally update the version (e.g., 0.1.2) from project management as you processes different stages of the markup. In such cases, it would also be a good idea to occasionally save a backup locally to your computer. This way we can track the text, and especially have a way of knowing what version it is in case something goes wrong (which does happen from time to time).

Appendix L Guidelines for Checking Older Versions of the TEI Documents in the Github Repository:

Sometimes there may have been an edition or correction that was made in an earlier version of a TEI file that was made in error or for some other reason we need to check that changes that were made in an earlier version of a document. In such cases, all the older versions of the XML are saved as snapshots in 84000's Github repository. To check older versions of the TEI please follow these steps below:

Read or Download Archived Files on Github
  • Go to the translations folder on 84000's Github repository using this link. You do not need a Github account to check the version history.
  • From there you will be able to navigate to the TEI file you need. The repository should have the same outline and structure as the TEI database we work from on Oxygen.
  • Once you navigated to the file you need click on the "History" button. This will take you to a new screen showing you a history of all the snapshots of the file, called "commits" on Github.
  • By clicking on each commit, it will show you all the additions and deletions that were made to the file at that time. The version number update should be close to the top of the page. From here, it is very convenient to see what changes have been made to the file for each version update.
  • Or you can simply download that version of the TEI file by first clicking on the three dots ... to the right of the file name of that version, click "view file", the new screen click on the "download" button. (Note that some browsers will just open the XML on a new page, so you might need to right-click "Save Link As..." to download the actual file.

All the older versions of the files should be here since the time we begin syncing this Github repository. Note that sometimes there may have been a few version updates before a commit, but there should be a record of all the differences between the version at the time of the commit and the previous one.

View Archived TEI in the Reading Room Display
  • If needed, it is also possible to see how older versions of the TEI display in the Reading Room. First download the desired version of the TEI from Github following the instructions above.
  • From the database explorer go to the folder in Collaboration/db/apps/84000-data/archived/tei/reference, then right click on the folder and select "import files." Select the file from your computer that you downloaded from Github.
  • The following URL, with the Toh number entered into the TohXXX will load the archived file to the Reading Room on Collaboration: https://read.84000-translate.org/translation/tohXXX.html?archive-path=tei/reference
  • The suffix "?archive-path=tei/reference" will likely work with some of the other formats as well.
  • Note, there is currently an issue with this method; it doesn't work for Toh numbers's with a dash, e.g., "1-1"

There may also be some versions of antiquated formats in the repository, so if you don't see what you are looking for in the translations folder, you can also search in the main branch.

Appendix M Reporting Typos or Errors in the eKangyur:

The eKangyur is typically very precise, but occasionally there may have been an error when they were inputting the text. If you suspect a typo in the eKangyur, please note it in the spread sheet here. This should not include errors in the original block print, which we will leave as is, but there may have been an error in the text input of the eKangyur from the original scanned source. The source of the eKangyur is the scanned LoC edition on tbrc.org, W4CZ5369 (Although it follows the volume order of W22084, the Parphud edition on tbrc.org). Occasionally the print may be illegible due to smudges, and so you may compare with W22084, which as far as I know is nearly identical. Of course, it not really our job to proof read the eKangyur, so don't spend hours checking for typos in the eKangyur; but you may happen to notice an error now and then while checking the source, and in such case you can enter them into the spreadsheet and they can be reported to Esukhia at some point.

Home 
Celso. Date: 2021-06-10
